=== [[Talk:Nissan Caravan#rfc_BF6ABD3|Talk:Nissan Caravan]] expired 2017-02-22 05:01 ===
* Id: BF6ABD3
* User: Mr.choppers
* Date: 2017-01-23 03:49:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|761469280|ECON 761469280}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|766791638|ECON 766791638}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I hope that econ is the correct field for an RFC here. Somebody placed a "distinguish" hatnote on this page, directing users to [[Dodge Caravan]]. At Dodge Caravan, a hatnote also suggests that perhaps the user was looking for [[Cessna 208 Caravan]]. This seems a) illogical and b) against policy, as [[:Template:Distinguish|Distinguish]] is meant to separate articles that might be easily confused through spelling error, ie articles with titles that are very similar. This clearly falls afoul of [[Wikipedia:TRHAT|trivial uses]]. [[User:Kevjonesin|Kevjonesin]] argues that a user unfamiliar with cars would somehow get here by searching for "caravan", but such a search would take them to the disambiguation page, from where they could easily find the correct article. Thus, no need for these tags that litter pages for no reason. From [[WP:HAT]]: "''Only mention other topics and articles if there is a large possibility of a reader arriving at the article either by mistake or with another topic in mind''." Thank you, sorry to waste anyone's time on this. <span style="background:#ff0000;font-family:Times New Roman;">[[User:Mr.choppers|<span style="color:#FDEE00;">'''&nbsp;Mr.choppers&nbsp;&#124;&nbsp;'''</span>]][[User talk:Mr.choppers|<span style="color:#FDEE00;">✎&nbsp;</span>]]</span> 03:49, 23 January 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_3B71F7B|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-02-23 05:01 ===
* Id: 3B71F7B
* User: WhatamIdoing
* Date: 2017-02-22 21:13:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|766944651|UNSORTED 766944651}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|766965276|UNSORTED 766965276}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
...200+ comments, 24,000+ words, and yet nobody even mentioned the existence of [[WP:Notability (high schools)]] (a failed proposal, now tagged as an essay).  [[User:WhatamIdoing|WhatamIdoing]] ([[User talk:WhatamIdoing|talk]]) 21:13, 22 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Katherine Johnson#rfc_1867F15|Talk:Katherine Johnson]] expired 2017-02-24 05:01 ===
* Id: 1867F15
* User: Flyer22 Reborn
* Date: 2017-01-25 04:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|761852912|BIO 761852912}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|761852914|HIST 761852914}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|761852916|MEDIA 761852916}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|761852917|SOC 761852917}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|767141106|BIO 767141106}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|767141110|HIST 767141110}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|767141116|MEDIA 767141116}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|767141121|SOC 767141121}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
One view is that the article should use Johnson's maiden name for her contributions before marrying and that we should use her married name for her contributions after marrying; this is so that we are paying respect to Johnson's legacy as separate from her husband. The other view is that "Johnson" is her common name and current surname and that we should consistently use that throughout the article (unless using her maiden name is clearer for a certain part); doing so is not taking away from Johnson's legacy since she is commonly known as Katherine Johnson whether her contributions prior to marrying are being discussed/noted or not. 

Note: If you are seeing this on the RfC page or from your talk page via an RfC alert, you can look at more detail on the matter at [[Talk:Katherine Johnson#WP:SURNAME]]. [[User:Flyer22 Reborn|Flyer22 Reborn]] ([[User talk:Flyer22 Reborn|talk]]) 04:10, 25 January 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox song#rfc_B5D5E04|Template talk:Infobox song]] expired 2017-02-25 16:01 ===
* Id: B5D5E04
* User: Ojorojo
* Date: 2017-02-03 19:59:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|763532423|MEDIA 763532423}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|763532431|TECH 763532431}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|767383624|MEDIA 767383624}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|767383626|TECH 767383626}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The parameter <code>Form=</code> is a carryover from the merger from Template:Infobox standard.  "Form" refers to a song's musical structure, e.g., repeating verses, sections, etc. (see [[Musical form]] for an explanation).  This is different than "Format" and "Genre", both of which have separate fields.  The Form parameter has little use and is often used incorrectly in place of genre or to mean style ("Jazz standard", "Ballad", etc.).  Very few articles discuss musical form or reference it.  Should it be removed? —[[User:Ojorojo|Ojorojo]] ([[User talk:Ojorojo|talk]]) 19:59, 3 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of YouTubers#rfc_ADE16ED|Talk:List of YouTubers]] expired 2017-02-25 22:01 ===
* Id: ADE16ED
* User: Beeblebrox
* Date: 2017-01-26 20:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|764606643|MEDIA 764606643}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|767430530|MEDIA 767430530}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I see from the edit notice that the current standard for inclusion on this list is coverage in reliable sources, per a discussion here in 2011. I think it may be time to review that decision and consider a simpler approach. Therefore I propose the following:

*'''All entries must have their own Wikipedia article. Entries with no article, or where the article has been deleted, will be removed. It will no longer be necessary to add sources when adding a new entry, a link to the Wikipedia article is sufficient."

Why is this better? It aligns this page with the [[WP:GNG]] and eliminates the need for debate here on the validity of an entry. If it can't support its own article, it will end up deleted, the link turns red, and it can be removed without controversy. If a new article is created with better sourcing that will stand up to scrutiny, it can be added back. All these discussion templates and so forth in  use here, like this was a noticeboard, can just be swept away as they won't be needed anymore. The edit notice and the notice at the top of this page can be reduced to ''one simple sentence that is not open to interpretation''. In short, it puts the onus on those wanting to add new entries to insure that the subject is sufficiently notable according to our long-accepted guidelines for inclusion ''before'' they are added here, thus eliminating the need for debate on this talk page, pushing it over to [[WP:AFD]] which is exactly where discussions of notability are supposed to take place. [[User:Beeblebrox|Beeblebrox]] ([[User talk:Beeblebrox|talk]]) 20:43, 26 January 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Conflict of interest#rfc_5B00ED3|Wikipedia talk:Conflict of interest]] expired 2017-02-26 04:01 ===

It strikes me that we have three broad options for investigating suspected COI (whether it be paid editing or other advocacy), and we now have a discrepancy between [[WP:Harassment#Posting of personal information|outing policy]], and the [[Wikipedia:Wikimedia Foundation statement on paid editing and outing|WMF's new essay]] on paid editing. We really need to gain an idea of what the broad consensus is on this. To whit, this RfC. [[User:Casliber|Cas Liber]] ([[User talk:Casliber|talk]] '''·''' [[Special:Contributions/Casliber|contribs]]) 03:17, 27 January 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Donald Trump#rfc_CD064BB|Talk:Donald Trump]] expired 2017-02-26 18:01 ===
* Id: CD064BB
* User: Bodhi Peace#top
* Date: 2017-02-26 08:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|767502696|UNSORTED 767502696}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|767570990|UNSORTED 767570990}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Please comment if you can support the following new wording for the end of the election summary paragraph in the lede.
1. {{talkquote|...and the fifth president to have lost the popular vote.}}
Reasoning: I think "the fifth ___" is too abbreviated. "to have lost" because "to lose" implies he we president before he lost the popular vote. "losing the popular vote" is wording that many sources use even though it is not a contest to be won or lost or even part of any criteria for being president.
If you do not support, please say why. <small class="autosigned">—&nbsp;Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Bodhi Peace|Bodhi Peace]] ([[User talk:Bodhi Peace#top|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/Bodhi Peace|contribs]]) 08:16, 26 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Username policy#rfc_4B195CD|Wikipedia talk:Username policy]] expired 2017-02-26 22:01 ===
* Id: 4B195CD
* User: Beeblebrox
* Date: 2017-01-27 21:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This guy: {{UAA|a}}

This is an exemption to the username policy that doesn't actually exist. It was made up by an admin who used to be very active here and just kind fo crept in to the process. The one time it was seriously discussed is [[Wikipedia:Username policy/RFC#"Only edits are to AFC submission"|here]], where a consensus was arrived at that it was not a valid exemption, but no actual action came from that. However, it does seem to have fallen out of favor and isn't really used anymore. I'd like to have this option removed from ResponseHelper as an invalid an mostly unused response, but have been asked to provide a more recent consensus not to use it first. Thoughts? === [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_57D07CD|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-02-27 02:01 ===
* Id: 57D07CD
* User: Zackmann08
* Date: 2017-02-06 19:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|764052001|POLICY 764052001}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|767634423|POLICY 767634423}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In recent months I have come across two separate templates that were written in German to facilitate the copying and pasting of Infoboxes from the German Wiki to the English Wiki: [[Template:Infobox Fluss]] (German Rivers) and [[Template:Infobox Schienenfahrzeug]] (German Railway Vehicles). I am really having a hard time understanding the logic behind having a template on the ENGLISH wiki where the parameters are in German. The argument in favor of this, that multiple editors have made, is so that one can easily copy and paste data from the German wiki. That is an absurd reason IMHO. You can't copy and paste the whole page anyway because it has to be translated. The same should be true for the Infobox. This whole infobox should be in English. I feel that this opens up a dangerous precedent as you could make that same argument with any page, in any topic and any language... For example, I would like to be able to copy and paste soccer teams from the Spanish Wiki... So do we now create a [[Template:Infobox football club]] that is in spanish so that I can copy and paste this data? 

Additionally, why are you copying and pasting data from another Wiki?? Other Wikis are certainly not [[WP:RS]]... Now I want to be super clear here, before anyone [[WP:ABF]], this has nothing to do with being anti-german or anything like that! What this actually grew out of was me converting Infoboxes to use {{tl|Infobox}} as a base. I had a hard time with these two templates because the parameters were completely foreign to me (not speaking any German myself). 

My goal here with this policy request is to establish a firm policy around whether or not foreign languages can be used in Infoboxes. There are obvious exceptions and this is not a debate about whether we are using "color" or "colour"... but I feel strongly that having entire Infoboxes written with all parameters in a foreign language is not good practice for an English Wiki. 

'''If''' the decision is made to implement a policy that all Infoboxes should be written in English, then I will commit to converting not only all templates that are in a foreign language, but also to converting all transclusions. I don't think the fact that these transclusions already exist should be part of the discussion as to whether or not they should continue to be used. I should also say that if there are certain individuals who feel the need to continue to copy and paste templates from foreign language wikis, I don't see any reason that custom templates cannot be written that once substituted are converted to their English equivalent. 

I also want to be clear that this discussion is NOT about merging templates. There are separate conversations about whether [[Template:Infobox German railway vehicle]] and [[Template:Infobox locomotive]] should be merged (for example). That is NOT the topic here! This is simply about whether or not to use foreign language in the Infobox. 

I look forward to hearing discussion on both sides. --[[User:Zackmann08|<span style="color:DarkTurquoise;">Zackmann08</span>]] (<sup>[[User_talk:Zackmann08|Talk to me]]</sup>/<sub>[[Special:Contributions/Zackmann08|<span style="color:orange;">What I been doing</span>]]</sub>) 19:11, 6 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_95DA2AF|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-02-27 12:01 ===
* Id: 95DA2AF
* User: J947
* Date: 2017-02-25 23:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|767446919|POLICY 767446919}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|767694837|POLICY 767694837}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is an rfc on the definition of the second indent of WP:OVERLINK.
There are three options:

A: Remove the guideline of not linking to major geographic features.

B: Leave the guideline as it is. (Right now it says {{tq|The names of major geographic features, locations (e.g. United States, London, New York City, France, Berlin...)}})

C: Propose limits on the use of the guideline. (specify your reasoning)

See also: [[User talk:J947]].

<s>I will add to this proposal once I am off mobile.</s> '''<font color="#1009bf">[[User:J947|J]]</font><font color="#137412">[[User talk:J947|947]]</font>''' 23:40, 25 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_7008561|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2017-02-27 21:01 ===
* Id: 7008561
* User: J947
* Date: 2017-02-27 18:27:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|767749614|PROP 767749614}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|767768399|PROP 767768399}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is an [[WP:RFC|RfC]] concerning the first sentence of BLP articles, specifically the '(born XXXXX)' part of it. If there gets consensus to implement option '''B''' or '''C''' it will cause widespread change across [[Wikipedia]]. Currently it says ''''Example place-holder''' (born XXXXX) is a(n)...'. What I propose here is to do either

* '''Option A''' – Keep the current version (e.g. ''''Example place-holder''' (born XXXXX) is a(n)...'),
* '''Option B''' – Change to ''''Example place-holder''' (XXXXX–present) is a(n)...', or
* '''Option C''' – Change to ''''Example place-holder''' (XXXXX–) is a(n)...'.

'''<font color="#1009bf">[[User:J947|J]]</font><font color="#137412">[[User talk:J947|947]]</font>''' 18:27, 27 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not#rfc_6B69DF3|Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not]] expired 2017-02-27 23:01 ===
* Id: 6B69DF3
* User: BrightRoundCircle
* Date: 2017-01-29 21:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|762626780|POLICY 762626780}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|767784802|POLICY 767784802}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
5. '''Merely-verifiable listings of information'''. Listings beside or within prose should be put in context with [[WP:RS|sourced]] explanations ([[WP:NAVLIST|navigational lists]] are excepted). [[WP:LISTN|Stand-alone lists]] should either have [[WP:LISTCRITERIA|clear selection criteria]] that's unambiguous and supported by reliable sources, or inline citations for each item. [[WP:ONUS|Verifiability does not guarantee inclusion]].{{pb}}Should [[WP:INDISCRIMINATE]] be expanded to include the above? [[User:BrightRoundCircle|BrightRoundCircle]] ([[User talk:BrightRoundCircle|talk]]) 21:37, 29 January 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_BF437C2|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2017-02-28 11:01 ===
* Id: BF437C2
* User: Magioladitis
* Date: 2017-02-28 07:23:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|767844181|UNSORTED 767844181}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|767861530|UNSORTED 767861530}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per [[WP:COSMETICBOT]] and [[WP:NOTBROKEN]] many tasks as bypassing redirects, removing whitespace, simplifying links should not be done on their own. Should we ask bot owners to modify their bots so they perform secondary "cosmetic" tasks while making a primary task? Recently, Yobot one of the main syntax fixing bots had all it tasks revoked which results in need to find another ways to perform these tasks. Any action would require clear community consensus. This is an action to raise awareness of the problem. -- [[User:Magioladitis|Magioladitis]] ([[User talk:Magioladitis|talk]]) 07:23, 28 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion#rfc_8185751|Wikipedia talk:Criteria for speedy deletion]] expired 2017-02-28 20:01 ===
* Id: 8185751
* User: SoWhy
* Date: 2017-01-29 19:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|762626780|POLICY 762626780}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|767932306|POLICY 767932306}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Currently the policy reads {{xt|Users nominating a page for speedy deletion [...] should notify the page creator and any major contributors.}} I propose we change this to read {{xt|Users nominating a page for speedy deletion [...] must notify the page creator and should notify any major contributors}} or something similar, maybe only for certain criteria where notification is useful (like G12, G11, A7, A9, A11 etc.). There is [[Wikipedia:Administrators'_noticeboard/Incidents#Not_notifying_users_about_their_pages_being_deleted|a current discussion at AN/I]] about one user nominating >500 pages in a month for speedy deletion without notifying a single user which imho highlights the problem. As {{ul|Primefac}} points out at AN/I, not notifying users can both be BITEy and lead them to repeat their mistakes over and over again because no one told them otherwise. With plenty of tools doing the job of tagging and notifying at the same time (like Twinkle), there is no real reason why we can't change the policy to require such notifications. Regards '''[[User:SoWhy|<span style="color: #7A2F2F; font-variant:small-caps">So</span>]][[User talk:SoWhy|<span style="color: #474F84; font-variant:small-caps">Why</span>]]''' 19:16, 29 January 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Planet of the Apes (2001 film)#rfc_618C6BE|Talk:Planet of the Apes (2001 film)]] expired 2017-03-01 16:01 ===

Which of the following should be the last sentence of the article{{clarify}}?

A.  He looks up to see a statue of General Thade in what otherwise appears to be the Lincoln Memorial.

B.  He looks up at the Lincoln Memorial, only to find a monument to General Thade

C.  Leo crashes in front of what appears to be the Lincoln Memorial, only to find a monument honoring General Thade.

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_A03D4E3|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2017-03-03 03:01 ===
* Id: A03D4E3
* User: Beeblebrox
* Date: 2017-02-10 00:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|764627336|PROP 764627336}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|768321667|PROP 768321667}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
<div id="talk" class="plainlinks" style="border: 1px solid #CC9; margin: 1em 1em 1em 1em; text-align: left; padding:1em; clear: both; background-color: #F1F1DE">
The [[Wikipedia:Reference desk]] is a set of pages that are for users to ask questions that are then answered by other users. It does not function like a real-world library reference desk and does not follow a number of Wikipedia policies, notably [[WP:NOTFORUM|Wikipedia is not a discussion forum]].  Users may ask virtually any question, and other users may provide any answer they see fit. There is also persistent debate about questions that may be asking for medical or legal advice.

Previous attempts to bring the refdesks into line with practices followed on the  remainder of the site or to make it work more like a real reference desk, providing only referrals to the relevant material as opposed to open-ended answers subject to no particular guidelines have failed, largely due to resistance from regulars at the refdesks.

Therefore, this proposal '''will not attempt to change the basic functioning of the reference desks'''. The subject of the discussion shall be if we should require all reference desk pages to be tagged with templates identifying the key differences between them and the rest of Wikipedia, and also if any question that might be construed as requesting legal or medical advice be tagged with a special template before answers are posted. [[User:Beeblebrox|Beeblebrox]] ([[User talk:Beeblebrox|talk]]) 00:20, 10 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Nintendo Switch#rfc_E716506|Talk:Nintendo Switch]] expired 2017-03-04 02:02 ===
* Id: E716506
* User: Dbsseven
* Date: 2017-02-02 01:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|763242416|SCI 763242416}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|768482447|SCI 768482447}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am trying to find an consensus for a standard of inclusion of specifications about the chip inside the [[Nintendo Switch]], though it is unconfirmed by the manufacturer. The reputability of the source publication has not been questioned. However the disagreement appears to be between:

* Include final and verified specs from the manufacturer, perhaps conveyed by a reliable source. Include specs from a credible third party with physical access to the final product.
* Include reported information of products prior to release from a reliable source. 

I believe this has already be addressed in the [[Talk:Jaguar_(microarchitecture)#PS4_Neo_APU_Specs|RfC here]]. However, my proposed compromise language based on this RfC has being rejected. 

The discussion began [[Talk:Nintendo_Switch/Archive_1#SoC_Specs|in December]] and has continued [[Talk:Nintendo_Switch#SoC_details|in February]] [[User:Dbsseven|Dbsseven]] ([[User talk:Dbsseven|talk]]) 01:11, 2 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Voting system#rfc_258200B|Talk:Voting system]] expired 2017-03-04 05:01 ===
* Id: 258200B
* User: Homunq
* Date: 2017-02-23 17:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|767052966|SCI 767052966}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|767052970|POL 767052970}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|768500354|SCI 768500354}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|768500365|POL 768500365}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is a requested move for this article. Consensus seems to be that a move is in order, but there is debate on the new title between "electoral system" and "voting rule". All parties agree that of those two options, "electoral system" is the more common term, but there is debate as to whether it precisely covers the scope of the article, either inclusively or exclusively. In the normal course of events, simply picking one of the options and closing the requested move, with a note that further debate is not out of order, would be acceptable; but since this move would mean moving several templates and categories, and possibly minor edits to the text of dozens of articles, it's probably worth broadening the discussion and getting a more-lasting consensus the first time. [[User:Homunq|Homunq]] ([[User talk:Homunq|࿓]]) 17:36, 23 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:United_States_presidential_election,_2016#RFC_on_including_Russian_influence_into_the_election|here]] expired 2017-03-05 00:03 ===
* Id: 
* User: Casprings
* Date: 2017-03-04 02:41:00
* RFC Text:
, I would like to add a mention of [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|Russian Interference]].

The proposed opening paragraph would read:

{{talkquote|Trump won the general election on November 8, 2016, in a surprise victory against [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] candidate [[Hillary Clinton]]. He became [[List of Presidents of the United States by age|the oldest]] and [[List of Presidents of the United States by net worth|wealthiest]] person to assume the presidency, the first without [[List of Presidents of the United States by previous experience|prior military or government service]], and [[United States presidential elections in which the winner lost the popular vote|the fifth elected with less]] than a [[plurality (voting)|plurality]] of the [[Popular vote (representative democracy)|national popular vote]]. Additionally, the United States government's intelligence agencies concluded the [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections|Russian government interfered in the 2016 United States elections]] and developed a clear preference for Trump."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Blake|first1=Aaron|title=The 11 most important lines from the new intelligence report on Russia’s hacking|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/01/06/the-most-important-lines-from-the-new-intelligence-report-on-russias-hacking/|publisher=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=January 7, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Miller|first1=Greg|last2=Entous|first2=Adam|title=Declassified report says Putin ‘ordered’ effort to undermine faith in U.S. election and help Trump|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/intelligence-chiefs-expected-in-new-york-to-brief-trump-on-russian-hacking/2017/01/06/5f591416-d41a-11e6-9cb0-54ab630851e8_story.html?utm_term=.b29bd22b831a|work=Washington Post}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Fleitz|first1=Fred|title=Was Friday's declassified report claiming Russian hacking of the 2016 election rigged?|url=http://www.foxnews.com/opinion/2017/01/07/was-fridays-declassified-report-claiming-russian-hacking-2016-election-rigged.html|website=Fox News|date=7 January 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=EICHENWALD|first1=Kurt|title=Trump, Putin and the hidden history of how Russia interfered in the U.S. presidential election|url=http://www.newsweek.com/trump-putin-russia-interfered-presidential-election-541302|website=Newsweek|language=en|date=10 January 2017}}</ref> 
 }}


{{Hat|Reference list}}
{{Ref talk}}
{{Hab}}

The questions for the RFC are:

1. Should a short mention of Russian interference in the election be added to the paragraph?

2. Should the suggested wording above be added? [[User:Casprings|Casprings]] ([[User talk:Casprings|talk]]) 02:41, 4 March 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums#rfc_95FDECA|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Elections and Referendums]] expired 2017-03-05 03:01 ===
* Id: 95FDECA
* User: MB298
* Date: 2017-02-03 01:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|763408010|POL 763408010}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|768666990|POL 768666990}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
For several years, the commonly-accepted but unofficial threshold for inclusion in the infobox of U.S. election articles has been receiving 5% of the vote. I am not aware of the exact discussion that established this policy (a link would be appreciated), but I will cite some similar past discussions: [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia_talk:WikiProject_Elections_and_Referendums/Archive_6#5.25_Threshold_rule_needs_a_vote this one] from 2010 regarding inclusion based on poll results, and two at [[Talk:United States Senate election in Illinois, 2010]] relating to the same topic.

This issue was brought up by [[Talk:United States presidential election in the District of Columbia, 2016|a recent RfC]] at the talk page of [[United States presidential election in the District of Columbia, 2016]] regarding the inclusion of [[Donald Trump]] in the infobox. Trump received 4% of the vote in the District.

Here are the options:

'''Question 1'''<br>
''What should be the standard for inclusion in the infobox of U.S. election articles?''
* A) Candidate must receive 5% of the vote
*B) Candidate must receive 4% of the vote ([[Talk:Vermont gubernatorial election, 2014#Libertarian candidate|see here]])
*C) Candidate must receive 5% of the vote or be the nominee of a major party (Democratic, Republican)

'''Question 2'''<br>
''If only one candidate meets the yet-to-be-defined-threshold, should the second-place contender be included?''
*A) If only one candidate meets the threshold, then the second-place contender should be included
*B) If only one candidate meets the threshold, then the second-place contender should not be included

pinging {{ping|Dennis Bratland}} as he provided the options for question 1.

[[User:MB298|MB298]] ([[User talk:MB298|talk]]) 01:46, 3 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Taiwan#rfc_7051099|Talk:Taiwan]] expired 2017-03-05 12:01 ===
* Id: 7051099

{{rfcquote|text=
Because the article [//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Republic_of_China_(1949%E2%80%9371)&oldid=742916489 Republic of China (1949-71)] redirects to [[Taiwan after World War II]], I am proposing this article needs to be restored since it held the UN seat after it lost the mainland to the CCP until the PRC replaced the ROC. However, the [[:Category:Treaties of the Republic of China (1949–71)]] article matches it all. Any suggestions or comments.[[Special:Contributions/2607:FEA8:61F:F0AB:4EF:D86A:11F0:ECD1|2607:FEA8:61F:F0AB:4EF:D86A:11F0:ECD1]] ([[User talk:2607:FEA8:61F:F0AB:4EF:D86A:11F0:ECD1|talk]]) 19:54, 8 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Chemistry#rfc_BE1B164|Talk:Chemistry]] expired 2017-03-05 12:01 ===
* Id: BE1B164
* User: Jayron32
* Date: 2017-03-04 02:51:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|768488682|SCI 768488682}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|768722969|SCI 768722969}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This RFC is narrowly focused on the singular question of whether the inclusion of the text [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Chemistry&type=revision&diff=768463502&oldid=768406640 in this diff] is appropriate for the lead of this article.  It is not about the truth of the statement, the need to have the information in Wikipedia in general, or any other question other than simply this question: "Does this text belong in the lead of this one article".  --[[User:Jayron32|<span style="color:#009">Jayron</span>]][[User talk:Jayron32|<b style="color:#090">''32''</b>]] 02:51, 4 March 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Daddy Yankee#rfc_625DC5F|Talk:Daddy Yankee]] expired 2017-03-05 13:01 ===
* Id: 625DC5F
* User: L3X1
* Date: 2017-02-03 18:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|763521304|BIO 763521304}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|763521307|MEDIA 763521307}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|768729646|BIO 768729646}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|768729651|MEDIA 768729651}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have seen several editors attempt to remove or add "rapper" to his BLP. However, the sources are contradictory.
*I am not going to accept this source http://www.famousbirthdays.com/people/daddy-yankee.html because it appears to just be facts aggregated from Wikipedia, and it neither confirms nor denies him being a rapper. It calls him a "World Music Singer" and a "Popular Latin recording artist".
*Google displayed this hit: http://www.axs.com/the-top-10-best-daddy-yankee-songs-83194. It says ''"For anybody that says that reggaeton is not really rapping, let us point you to “Gata Gangster.” This single is basically Puerto Rican rap, and that’s a good thing as the track is easily listenable and likeable, unlike most of the gangster rap that’s out today."'' That is what it says for number 9. check out the desc. for 7 and 4. ''Daddy Yankee may be the closest thing to a Spanish gangster rapper since, well, anybody.…though most of his tunes were geared towards “Latin gangster rap,”…''
*Billboard in 2012 called him both "Daddy Yankee, Puerto Rican Rapper" and "Reggaeton star Daddy Yankee " and "The Grammy-winning rapper" and "said the rapper". <ref>http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/branding/1099489/daddy-yankee-puerto-rican-rapper-to-release-signature-headphones</ref>
So it is obvious to me at least that these music sites consider him to be a rapper, either because of his work, or because they consider Reggae/reggaeton to be rap. I am calling this RfC (my second) to see what yall think, and to save me having to prove this over and over again as editors attempt to change one way or the other. Nominator has very little bias towards or against the subject. [[User:L3X1|L3X1]] [[User talk:L3X1|My Complaint Desk]] 18:35, 3 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[User talk:L'honorable#rfc_08581B5|User talk:L'honorable]] expired 2017-03-05 14:01 ===

* User: L'honorable#rfc_08581B5

* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|768686808|UNSORTED 768686808}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|768736916|UNSORTED 768736916}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{ping|PhilKnight}} much obliged you unblocked me on [[English Wikipedia]], for which I am '''most grateful''' indeed. Despite protestations by some to the contrary, it seems to me that the stigma of being blocked on one Wiki can cause reputational damage on other Wikis? I can well understand that for really bad eggs, such protective measures provide swift mechanisms to ensure careful safe-guarding throughout Wiki's pages. But, unless I am thoroughly mistaken, this could also provide a mechanism for grudge-blocking, thereby possibly creating vicious circles (or downward spirals), ''ie.'' a '''domino effect'''?

I hope these general comments avoid immediate recrimination(s), and I can elaborate once I know with whom to liaise in more detail. Perhaps you or someone else in authority on the relevant Wiki could guide me as how to treat [[User:Steinsplitter|Steinsplitter]]'s summary block of [[:commons:User talk:L'honorable|me]]? which provides absolutely no right of reply, incl. Talk Page ''etc'' on [[Wikimedia Commons]] (I have emailed, but to no avail). Many thanks in advance for your co-operation. Best, [[User:L&#39;honorable|L&#39;honorable]] ([[User talk:L&#39;honorable#top|talk]]) 01:24, 26 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Disputed status of Gibraltar#rfc_28B7BD1|Talk:Disputed status of Gibraltar]] expired 2017-03-05 17:01 ===
* Id: 28B7BD1
* User: Asilah1981
* Date: 2017-02-03 15:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|764024986|HIST 764024986}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|764024992|POL 764024992}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|768760718|HIST 768760718}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|768760724|POL 768760724}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This article describes the territorial dispute between the United Kingdom and Spain over Gibraltar. Within it there are three sections. The Spanish position, the British Position and the Gibraltarian Position. They each objectively describe the official position or Point of View of each party regarding this conflict.

It has been consistently argued by an editor that the official Spanish position summarized in English on the Spanish government website should not be included or referenced as a source because it is a Primary source and because it is POV.  A secondary source from the BBC summarizing the Spanish position and mirroring the Primary source has also been consistently deleted by the same editor. I strongly object to the validity and underlying logic of both arguments. As has been mentioned in the prior RfC by other uninvolved editors, Primary Sources can be used in such cases. Secondly, a section which aims to describes the Point of View of X party can hardly be written off as Point of View. We are describing the Spanish position, which IS inherently a Point of View, as are the British and Gibraltarian positions. 

The two sources which are considered unacceptable by the editor in question are the following:
*http://www.lamoncloa.gob.es/lang/en/gobierno/news/Paginas/2016/20160511--visits-gibralta.aspx (Spanish government website official position)
*http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-23617910 (BBC online feature summarizing respective British and Spanish positions)

The question is: Should their content be excluded from the section and on what basis?

[[User:Asilah1981|Asilah1981]] ([[User talk:Asilah1981|talk]]) 15:20, 3 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_C9410BA|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-03-06 07:01 ===
* Id: C9410BA
* User: Beeblebrox
* Date: 2017-02-14 23:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|765537473|POLICY 765537473}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|770215627|POLICY 770215627}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
<div id="talk" class="plainlinks" style="border: 1px solid #CC9; margin: 1em 1em 1em 1em; text-align: left; padding:1em; clear: both; background-color: #F1F1DE">
See [[:Category:Years in the future]] 

This is a follow-up on the discussion of the recent years guidelines further up the page. While looking into that mater, I discovered that we have articles on years in the future, going all the way up to [[2099]], and articles are future millennia going all the way up to the [[10th millennium]]. In addition to general information about predicted astronomical events and so forth, these articles contain speculative material as well as useless minutia such as what software may stop working properly  75-8,000 years in the future. While having articles for years in the immediate future seems reasonable, having articles for years that most of us will not even live to see, and cannot possibly predict, seems .... well frankly it just seems a bit silly. Should we develop a policy that prohibits articles on some future years? If so, what should be the cutoff? [[User:Beeblebrox|Beeblebrox]] ([[User talk:Beeblebrox|talk]]) 23:53, 14 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Appalachian English#rfc_5D7698B|Talk:Appalachian English]] expired 2017-03-06 16:01 ===
* Id: 5D7698B
* User: Wolfdog
* Date: 2017-02-04 14:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|763666960|LANG 763666960}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|768928649|LANG 768928649}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Studies suggest that "Ozark English" and "Appalachian English" are the same dialect (one an "extension" or separated "island" subset of the other); features of both traditional Ozark and Appalchian English may be declining, as evidenced by a lack of much Ozark-focused dialect research since the middle of the 1900s, as well as the recent classification of both the Ozark and (especially) Appalachian regions under the [[Southern American English|Southern dialect]] region by the 2006 ''[[Atlas of North American English]]''. Any sources that don't directly equate the two do consistently highlight their similarities, yet never their differences. 

The merging of the two articles has never happened, though I proposed it in the past on the [[Southern American English]] talk page. In that discussion, one user opposed without further discussion (even when asked to elucidate), one user brought up a single argument I feel I countered, and one user supported without further discussion. No full discussion was ever had over the course of at least 9 months, though I found and included later evidence to bolster my points. Below is my evidence in full supporting the merger: 
{{collapse top|title=Evidence|left=y}}
*The 1948 article "Southern Mountain Dialect", for example, refers to an Appalachian-Ozark variety as a single dialect with as much slight internal variation as any dialect: "Though fairly consistent in the isolated districts (with which we are mainly concerned), the dialect may vary slightly with the locality, and even from family to family." It lists "four main divisions" geographically, which include "the Blue Ridge of Virginia and West Virginia, the Great Smokies of Tennessee and North Carolina, the Cumberlands of Kentucky and Tennessee [all three constituting the Appalachian region], and the Ozarks of Arkansas and southern Missouri" [p. 46]). This passage unifies Appalachian and Ozark English.
*Here is what the more recent research that I could find has to say on Ozark English:
**[[John C. Wells]]' (1982) ''Accents of English'' lists "Ozarks" in the index with a "see also 'southern mountain'". Wells clearly centers "southern mountain" speech on Appalachian and "upland states", which "form a transition zone between the south and midland dialect areas; their southern mountain speech is classified as south midland by Kurath, but popularly regarded as a variety of southern accent" (527). This passage unifies Appalachian and Ozark English.
**"Variation and Change in Geographically Isolated Communities: Appalachian English and Ozark English" (1984), a 200-page comparative study, does initially speak of Appalachian and Ozark English as two different dialects or "varieties", yes, but the entire goal of the study is to unearth more about the relationships between the two. The conclusion states that the study considered "the descriptive detail of the [grammatical] structures we have examined, [and] the frequency with which the various structures are used" (p. 235). The findings of the study: "that there are no descriptive differences in the representative structures we have examined here" (p. 235) and then: "the frequency relationships between the varieties also shows fairly close parallels, with some non-significant differences" (p. 235). This passage unifies Appalachian and Ozark English.
** ''World Englishes'' (2013) plainly says "The Ozark Mountains can be seen as an extension of the Appalachian English dialect" (48). This passage unifies Appalachian and Ozark English. [[User:Wolfdog|Wolfdog]] ([[User talk:Wolfdog|talk]]) 14:37, 4 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox single#rfc_80D7483|Template talk:Infobox single]] expired 2017-03-07 17:01 ===
* Id: 80D7483
* User: Ojorojo
* Date: 2017-03-06 16:14:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|768937493|MEDIA 768937493}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|768937497|TECH 768937497}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|769110602|MEDIA 769110602}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|769110608|TECH 769110608}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Currently, there are a number of articles about singles sung and/or titled in a language other than English.  Would it be useful to include fields in the singles infobox to identify these?  Other music infoboxes use the following parameters:
*{{tl|Infobox song}}: <code>English_title=</code> and <code>Language=</code>
*{{tl|Infobox musical composition}}: <code>translation=</code> (explained as "title in English"), <code>native_name=</code> ("native title, if the common name is English"), and  <code>native_name_lang=</code> ("language of the native title/common title not in English")
*{{tl|Infobox song contest entry}}: <code>Language=</code> and <code>Languages=</code> (for lyrics in more than one language)
Please indicate '''Add''' or '''Oppose'''. —[[User:Ojorojo|Ojorojo]] ([[User talk:Ojorojo|talk]]) 16:14, 6 March 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_9E7CFEB|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2017-03-07 17:02 ===
* Id: 9E7CFEB
* User: Magioladitis
* Date: 2017-02-28 07:23:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|767861525|STYLE 767861525}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|767861529|TECH 767861529}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|769528075|STYLE 769528075}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|769528080|TECH 769528080}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Per [[WP:COSMETICBOT]] and [[WP:NOTBROKEN]] many tasks as bypassing redirects, removing whitespace, simplifying links should not be done on their own. Should we ask bot owners to modify their bots so they perform secondary "cosmetic" tasks while making a primary task? Recently, Yobot one of the main syntax fixing bots had all it tasks revoked which results in need to find another ways to perform these tasks. Any action would require clear community consensus. This is an action to raise awareness of the problem. -- [[User:Magioladitis|Magioladitis]] ([[User talk:Magioladitis|talk]]) 07:23, 28 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_0EEFA4E|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2017-03-07 17:02 ===
* Id: 0EEFA4E
* User: Samwalton9
* Date: 2017-02-05 16:21:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|764061059|PROP 764061059}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|769110609|PROP 769110609}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
=== Background '''

Our [[Wikipedia:Long-term abuse|Long-Term Abuse]] (LTA) pages are an extremely valuable repository for Wikipedians doing anti-vandalism work - they inform editors on how particular vandals edit, even when those edits may seem innocent when taken out of context, let them know what to look out for in certain areas of the encyclopedia, and contain suggestions on how to treat certain users; no editor can know about the behaviour of every regular vandal. The records are also used for tracking purposes, informing edit filters for example.

But these pages aren't without their drawbacks. Vandals are often drawn to this system, either by aiming to become an LTA as some kind of badge of honour, trying to live up to their name once listed as an LTA, or by new vandals attempting to emulate the well documented vandalism methods. We should be doing a better job of [[Wikipedia:Deny recognition|denying recognition]] to these vandals, but this is hard to do whilst also keeping a comprehensive open record of their actions on Wikipedia. The other issue with having these records in a public space is not being able to properly document the vandals' edit patterns or our counter measures to avoid [[Wikipedia:BEANS|BEANS]] issues, leaving out information that could be valuable to anti-vandal editors.

''' Proposal '''

We are therefore proposing a new tool for Wikipedians, called the LTA Knowledgebase, which would be an off-wiki database of LTA records, available for viewing and editing to only (probably approved) experienced editors. [[User:Samtar|Samtar]] has been working on this for a little while now, and you can see a proof-of-concept version [[toollabs:lta/publicdemo/|here]]. With this database vandal fighters will be able to both log information on more recurring vandals as well as covering their editing habits and what we're doing in response in more detail (documenting how relevant targeted edit filters work for example). This will be especially beneficial for those LTAs who we don't even document in order to fully deny recognition. LTAs won't know whether they have an entry, nor what that entry contains.

This tool will not be for extra personal information on these users; it will only encourage more behavioural details, and rules will need to be in place for tool admins to remove any personal information that is added. Requirements for access can be debated in another RfC, but the approach would likely be that users would require manual approval from a tool admin with the needed experience level somewhere between that of [[Wikipedia:NPP|NPP]] and [[Wikipedia:Volunteer Response Team|OTRS]], requiring sufficient time and experience working on anti-vandalism work to be trusted. Future RfCs could also decide on criteria for the addition of an LTA to the tool and whether all users are able to add an entry or whether new entries might require approval by a tool admin, for example.

Subsequent discussions can be held to clarify the details and specifics so these needn't be debated here beyond suggestions and initial discussion. [[User:Samwalton9|'''S'''am '''W'''alton]] ([[User talk:Samwalton9|talk]]) and ''[[User:Samtar|Samtar]]'' <sup>[[User talk:Samtar|talk]] &middot; [[Special:Contributions/Samtar|contribs]]</sup> 16:21, 5 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Melania Trump#rfc_421BEF3|Talk:Melania Trump]] expired 2017-03-08 07:02 ===
* Id: 421BEF3
* User: Coretheapple
* Date: 2017-02-08 17:52:00

{{rfcquote|text=
As reported in multiple sources, Mrs. Trump has brought libel suits in the U.S., most recently in New York, concerning allegations originally published in ''[[The Daily Mail]]''. These new developments are not a simple rehash of the original, inflammatory allegations, but rather delve into how Mrs. Trump is protecting her brand. Multiple reliable sources are reporting on this, including ''[[The New York Times]]'' [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/07/us/politics/melania-trump-libel-suit-daily-mail.html in this article] and accompanying editorial[https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/07/opinion/melania-trump-inc-imperiled.html].

The questions we need to address is 

1. whether the libel suits should be mentioned 

2. if so, to what extent, if at all, should the original allegations published by the ''Mail'' be mentioned? 

3. Should they be included as a separate section or subsection?

--[[User:Coretheapple|Coretheapple]] ([[User talk:Coretheapple|talk]]) 17:52, 8 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Emmett Till#rfc_902CBC6|Talk:Emmett Till]] expired 2017-03-08 17:01 ===
* Id: 902CBC6
* User: ResultingConstant
* Date: 2017-02-06 17:00:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|764024983|BIO 764024983}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|764024986|HIST 764024986}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|764024989|MEDIA 764024989}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|764024992|POL 764024992}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|764024993|SOC 764024993}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|769290568|BIO 769290568}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|769290573|HIST 769290573}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|769290576|MEDIA 769290576}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The lead sentence/paragraph of the Emmett Till article currently reads : {{tq|Emmett Louis Till (July 25, 1941 – August 28, 1955) was an African-American teenager who was murdered in Mississippi at the age of 14 after reportedly flirting with a white woman.}}. 

Recently (interview in 2007, published in 2017), the "white woman", Carolyn Bryant, revealed that she had lied regarding the events at the store. {{tq|“That part’s not true,” she told Tyson, about her claim that Till had made verbal and physical advances on her. As for the rest of what happened that evening in the country store, she said she couldn’t remember. }}

{{collapsetop|sources for updated information}}
* http://www.vanityfair.com/news/2017/01/how-author-timothy-tyson-found-the-woman-at-the-center-of-the-emmett-till-case
* http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/ct-emmett-till-accuser-false-testimony-20170128-story.html
* https://nypost.com/2017/01/27/emmett-tills-accuser-admits-it-was-all-a-lie/
* http://people.com/crime/emmett-till-carolyn-bryant-interview/
* https://www.nytimes.com/2017/02/06/opinion/black-lives-white-lies-and-emmett-till.html
* https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/27/us/emmett-till-lynching-carolyn-bryant-donham.html
* http://www.theroot.com/woman-who-caused-emmett-tills-death-admits-to-lying-1791698393

And many more. Ultimately most of these are reporting from the book by [[Timothy Tyson]] "The Blood of Emmett Till" https://www.amazon.com/Blood-Emmett-Till-Timothy-Tyson/dp/1476714843
{{collapsebottom}}

'''How should the lead sentence/paragraph deal with this updated information?
* A) No change. 
* B) Remove "after reportedly flirting with a white woman"
* C) Include information in the lead sentence/paragraph which provides the new context.
[[User:ResultingConstant|ResultingConstant]] ([[User talk:ResultingConstant|talk]]) 17:00, 6 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Quebec City mosque shooting#rfc_F5FD434|Talk:Quebec City mosque shooting]] expired 2017-03-08 23:01 ===
* Id: F5FD434
* User: Lumbering in thought
* Date: 2017-03-02 09:00:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|768184220|BIO 768184220}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|769342741|BIO 769342741}}
* RFC Text:

=== [[Talk:Richard B. Spencer#rfc_0C1FC2C|Talk:Richard B. Spencer]] expired 2017-03-09 05:03 ===
* Id: 0C1FC2C
* User: JRBx45x
* Date: 2017-02-08 15:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|764376255|BIO 764376255}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|769384423|BIO 769384423}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Requesting a "request for comment" on this issue. Question is whether Richard B. Spencer should be referred to exclusively as a "white supremacist," exclusively as a "white nationalist," or as both a "white nationalist" and a "white supremacist" in the first line of the article. One opinion is that Spencer should ONLY be referred to as a white supremacist because there are numerous media outlets that report him as such ([https://www.google.com/search?q=%22Richard+Spencer%22&oq=%22Ric&aqs=chrome.0.69i59j69i57j69i59.1063j0j7&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8#safe=off&tbm=nws&q=%22Richard+Spencer%22+%22white+supremacist%22]). Another is that Spencer is more identifiable as a white nationalist (again, because multiple media outlets report on him as such [https://www.google.com/search?q=%22Richard+Spencer%22&oq=%22Ric&aqs=chrome.0.69i59j69i57j69i59.1063j0j7&sourceid=chrome&ie=UTF-8#q=%22Richard+Spencer%22+%22white+nationalist%22&safe=off&tbm=nws]), with reference to fact that he is referred to as white supremacist by some other sources. Major issues to consider is that Spencer has repeatedly publically stated that he does NOT identify as a "white supremacist" (this is a [[WP:BLP]] article). Another issue is that some editors claim there is no difference between [[white nationalism]] and [[white supremacy]] so the distinction is meaningless. Looking for alterate opinions. [[User:JRBx45x|JRBx45x]] ([[User talk:JRBx45x|talk]]) 15:32, 8 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Revision deletion#rfc_510AFB4|Wikipedia talk:Revision deletion]] expired 2017-03-09 05:03 ===
* Id: 510AFB4
* User: Josve05a
* Date: 2017-02-07 04:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|764118839|POLICY 764118839}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|769384425|POLICY 769384425}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I've read [[WP:RD1]] a few times, and requested deletions for it with {{tl|copyvio-revdel}}. Many users understand what to do, but some user do not wwish to fufill such request, since another user may have edited the article while the bad content was still there, and that there attribution needs to be kept. The fact is that only the username needs to be attributed, not the diff of the edit. Therefore, I ask for a clearer wording of [[WP:RD1]] as following:
{{Talkquote|Blatant copyright violations that can be redacted without removing attribution to non-infringing contributors. <u>If redacting a revision would remove any contributor's attribution, this criterion cannot be used.</u> Best practices for copyrighted text removal can be found at WP:Copyright problems and should take precedence over this criterion.}}
to
{{Talkquote|Blatant copyright violations that can be redacted without removing attribution to non-infringing contributors. <u>Redacting a revision should not remove any contributor's attribution. Usernames and IP addresses should not be hidden, only the revisions themself.</u> Best practices for copyrighted text removal can be found at WP:Copyright problems and should take precedence over this criterion.}}
<span style="background: turquoise;font-family: 'Segoe Script', 'Comic Sans MS';">([[User talk:Josve05a|'''t''']])&nbsp;[[User:Josve05a|<span style="color:white;">'''Josve05a'''</span>]]&nbsp;([[Special:Contributions/Josve05a|'''c''']])</span> 04:31, 7 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Sirius#rfc_DF01529|Talk:Sirius]] expired 2017-03-09 13:03 ===
* Id: DF01529
* User: LlywelynII
* Date: 2017-02-08 15:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|764376257|HIST 764376257}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|764376263|LANG 764376263}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|764376265|SCI 764376265}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|764376284|SOC 764376284}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|769423584|HIST 769423584}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|769423586|LANG 769423586}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|769423589|SCI 769423589}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|769423592|SOC 769423592}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Merge from [[Sothis]] to [[Sirius]] and/or [[Sopdet]]. There are weasel words in its article but Sothis ''is'' (and is universally regarded by {{sc|rs}} as) the star Sirius, as already mentioned and sourced in the article Sirius. It is also ridiculous that the §{{nbsp}}''Cultural significance'' section of the article Sirius currently has a paragraph on Theosophy, two subsections on minor African ethicities, and a Harry Potter shoutout but no discussion of its central importance to ancient Egyptian culture. 

''If'' it is felt important to maintain an entirely separate article on the ancient Egyptian cultural aspects of Sirius, it should occur at the star's ancient Egyptian name (typically reconstructed as [[Sopdet]]) and not at the romanization of the hellenization of that name. The current treatment there of the star as an Egyptian goddess should simply form a subsection of such an article, since she is simply a personification of the star within their culture. In that case, the §{{nbsp}}''Cultural significance'' section of Sirius should still have an overview of the material being forked out and links to it.&nbsp;—&nbsp;[[User talk:LlywelynII|<span style="text-shadow:#BBBBBB 0.1em 0.1em 0.1em; class=texhtml">Llywelyn<font color="Gold">II</font></span>]] 15:10, 8 February 2017 (UTC)}}

* Date: 2017-02-07 14:13:00

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|764183060|MEDIA 764183060}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|769436743|MEDIA 769436743}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
At [[K-pop#Social_media]] we have the "List of 20 most viewed K-pop music videos on YouTube". While we have an older source which gives a version of this list, we do not have a single source for the current list. Instead, editors have taken the earlier list, updated the numbers from various sources, and added and removed songs as needed. - 14:13, 7 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Ben Swann#rfc_C74FC55|Talk:Ben Swann]] expired 2017-03-10 19:01 ===
* Id: C74FC55
* User: DrFleischman
* Date: 2017-02-08 18:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|764410543|MEDIA 764410543}}

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following sentence:
{{talkquote|After leaving WXIX-TV in 2013, Swann regularly appeared on [[RT America]], '''part of the publicly-funded Russian TV network''' [[RT (TV network)|RT]]...}}
Be changed to:
{{talkquote|After leaving WXIX-TV in 2013, Swann regularly appeared on [[RT America]], '''a division of Russian propaganda outlet''' [[RT (TV network)|RT]]...}}
citing the following sources (or others):
{{collapse top|title=sources}}
*[[Julia Ioffe (journalist)|Julia Ioffe]],[http://www.cjr.org/feature/what_is_russia_today.php?page=all What Is Russia Today?], ''[[Columbia Journalism Review]]'', September–October 2010.
*Beth Knobel [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/russian-news-english-accent-11-12-2005/ "Russian News, English Accent: New Kremlin Show Spins Russia Westward"], ''[[CBS News]]'', December 12, 2005
*{{cite news|author=Benjamin Bidder|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/business/putin-fights-war-of-images-and-propaganda-with-russia-today-channel-a-916162.html|title=Putin Fights War of Images and Propaganda with Russia Today Channel|work=Spiegel Online|date=August 13, 2013|accessdate=August 14, 2013}}
{{collapse bottom}}

--[[User:DrFleischman|Dr. Fleischman]] ([[User talk:DrFleischman|talk]]) 18:54, 8 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Opinion polling for the German federal election, 2017#rfc_6355BF4|Talk:Opinion polling for the German federal election, 2017]] expired 2017-03-10 21:01 ===
* Id: 6355BF4
* User: Mélencron
* Date: 2017-02-25 14:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|767377057|STYLE 767377057}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|769650356|STYLE 769650356}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
[[MOS:DASH]] specifies that two dates with at least one space in them should be separated by a spaced, not unspaced, en dash. However, opinion polling articles have often not complied by MOS:DASH in the past – whether intentionally or simply because [[Opinion polling for the next Turkish general election|users]] [[Opinion polling for the Ukrainian parliamentary election, 2019|aren't]] [[Opinion polling for the next Slovak parliamentary election|aware]] ([[Opinion polling for the next Slovenian parliamentary election|i.e.]], [[Opinion polling for the Norwegian parliamentary election, 2017|that]] [[Opinion polling for the Czech legislative election, 2017|hyphens]] [[Opinion polling for the Czech presidential election, 2018|or]] [[Opinion polling for the next Croatian parliamentary election|em]] [[Opinion polling for the Czech legislative election, 2017|dashes]] shouldn't be used to separate dates). I also don't believe there isn't a good reason not to comply by this policy on opinion polling articles, especially as it doesn't cause any particular disruption (only in a few cases do columns have to be adjusted, say, 5px at most).

#Should we comply by [[MOS:DASH]] (i.e., use spaced en dashes) between two dates with at least one space?
#Should we not use spaced en dashes between two dates with at least one space?

Impru and I have already articulated our positions on this issue – I'd be more interested in hearing the viewpoints of others rather than us two continuing to litigate this between ourselves. [[User:Mélencron|Mélencron]] ([[User talk:Mélencron|talk]]) 14:54, 25 February 2017 (UTC)}}

'''Proposals:''' 
*A. The swastika at the top of the sidebar should be reduced to 60px.
*B. The swatiska should stay at 87px, which it has been at since December 25, 2016.
*C. The swatiska should be returned to 100px, which was the result of the earlier RfC.
*D. Remove the swastika entirely.

=== [[Talk:Album-oriented rock#rfc_243B93F|Talk:Album-oriented rock]] expired 2017-03-14 10:06 ===
* Id: 243B93F
* User: Cunard
* Date: 2017-02-12 09:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|765041085|MEDIA 765041085}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|770254239|MEDIA 770254239}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Should this information be included?'''
:{{tq|"Album-oriented rock" (or "album-oriented radio")<ref>{{cite book|title=The Chambers Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pz2ORay2HWoC&pg=PA68|year=1998|publisher=Allied Publishers|isbn=978-81-86062-25-8|page=68}}</ref> may be deployed interchangeably with "adult-oriented rock".<ref>According to:
*{{cite book|title=The Chambers Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pz2ORay2HWoC&pg=PA68|year=1998|publisher=Allied Publishers|isbn=978-81-86062-25-8|page=68}}
*{{cite book|last=Miles|first=Barry|authorlink=Barry Miles|title=The Greatest Album Covers of All Time|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OXkgDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT245|year=2016|publisher=Pavilion Books|isbn=978-1-911163-36-7|page=245}}
*{{cite book|editor-last=Cateforis|editor-first=Theo|title=The Rock History Reader|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=F7o5Wj9-EGYC&pg=PA161|year=2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-0-415-89212-4|page=161}}
*{{cite book|last=Bruford|first=Bill|authorlink=Bill Bruford|title=Bill Bruford: The Autobiography : Yes, King Crimson, Earthworks, and More|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=z_7VsmxN0sYC&pg=PA118|year=2009|publisher=Jawbone Press|isbn=978-1-906002-23-7|page=118}}
*{{cite book|last=Kernfeld|first=Barry|title=Pop Song Piracy: Disobedient Music Distribution since 1929|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9AK28kNS4O0C&pg=PA120|year=2011|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-43184-0|page=120}}
*{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Chris|title=The Greenwood Encyclopedia of Rock History: From arenas to the underground, 1974-1980|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QiIKAQAAMAAJ|year=2006|publisher=Greenwood Press|isbn=978-0-313-33611-9|page=226}}</ref> In 1978, [[KGOU]] manager Roy Lamberton identified "adult-oriented rock" as a mellower version of album-oriented rock.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Herbeck, Jr.|first1=Ray|title=Vox Jox|journal=[[Billboard]]|date=February 11, 1978|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6yMEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PT28}}</ref>}}

As of Jan 9, [[Adult-oriented rock]] redirects to [[Album-oriented rock]] even though "adult-oriented rock" doesn't appear in this article. The dispute over including these sentences comes from the fact that "adult-oriented rock" is a loosely defined term, sometimes also referring to [[Arena rock]] or [[Yacht rock]], which are not radio formats. Some sources (cited above) say that the terms are regionally dependent, and that "album-oriented rock" was the format as it was known in the US. Other people claim (without sources) that "album-oriented rock" was the official name of the radio format described in this article, and that "adult-oriented rock" is a meaningless term that ought to denote [[Adult album alternative]] (this notion is also contradicted by music industry textbooks).<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=tdgdAQAAMAAJ&q=%22adult-oriented+rock%22+%22adult+album+alternative%22&dq=%22adult-oriented+rock%22+%22adult+album+alternative%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjOxenWs7bRAhWE7yYKHa-lAFoQ6AEIJDAB</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=HOaBAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA111 ''Understanding the Music Industries'' by Chris Anderton, Andrew Dubber, Martin James]</ref>
RfC relisted. [[User:Cunard|Cunard]] ([[User talk:Cunard|talk]]) 09:36, 12 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Today's featured article#rfc_4275F40|Wikipedia talk:Today's featured article]] expired 2017-03-14 12:06 ===
* Id: 4275F40
* User: Mike_Christie
* Date: 2017-02-12 12:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|765059774|PROJ 765059774}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/WikiProjects_and_collaborations|prev|770266602|PROJ 770266602}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The "Today's featured article" (TFA) slot on the main page showcases a different featured article (FA) every day.  FAs are not being produced as fast as the TFA slot uses them.  The number of available featured articles is also reduced by the fact that many older FAs have degraded to the point where they are no longer suitable for TFA.  See [https://tools.wmflabs.org/bambots/cwb/bycat/Featured_articles.html this listing] of FAs marked for cleanup, and the [[Wikipedia:Featured article candidates/Featured log|featured article log]] to see the rate of production of FAs.

A separate issue is the need for variety of subjects in the TFA slot.  Because some productive FA writers have written a large number of FAs in narrow subject areas, it is getting harder to avoid some repetition in the type of articles showcased on the main page.
:Just realized I never signed this, so: [[User:Mike Christie|Mike Christie]] ([[User_talk:Mike Christie|talk]] - [[Special:Contributions/Mike_Christie|contribs]] -  [[User:Mike Christie/Reference library|library]]) 12:06, 12 February 2017 (UTC)}}

[[Paul Roderick Gregory]], a [[Hoover Institution]] economist contends that it was written, not by the alleged author, Steele, but more likely by a Russian intelligence officer.<ref name="Gregory">{{cite web|url=http://www.forbes.com/sites/paulroderickgregory/2017/01/13/the-trump-dossier-is-false-news-and-heres-why/#6e9421ae55f1|title=The Trump Dossier Is Fake -- And Here Are The Reasons Why|first=Paul Roderick|last=Gregory|publisher=}}</ref>}}

=== [[Talk:Ben Affleck#rfc_B2685B6|Talk:Ben Affleck]] expired 2017-03-19 12:02 ===
* Id: B2685B6
* User: Popeye191
* Date: 2017-03-19 09:54:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|771068585|MEDIA 771068585}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|771080122|MEDIA 771080122}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
It is proposed to add the following sentences to Affleck's article:

:In 2014, Affleck engaged in a discussion about the relationship between liberal principles and Islam. He objected to jihadism, the imposition of the death penalty for apostasy and the punishment of women, but said that those actions were not representive of "more than a billion" Muslims. He later said, "We’ve killed more Muslims than they’ve killed us, by an awful lot. We’ve invaded more Muslim countries than they’ve invaded ours, by an awful lot. And yet somehow we’re exempted from these things because they’re not ''really'' a reflection of what we believe in."<ref>{{cite web|title=Ben Affleck, Sam Harris and Bill Maher Debate Radical Islam | Real Time with Bill Maher (HBO)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vln9D81eO60|accessdate=19 March 2017}}</ref>

There was a very long debate the wording [[Talk:Ben_Affleck#Maher_and_Harris_debates|here]].

* Does the above wording accurately represent Affleck's position during the discussion?
* Does it avoid misrepresenting the views of other living persons i.e. Bill Maher and Sam Harris?[[User:Popeye191|Popeye191]] ([[User talk:Popeye191|talk]]) 09:54, 19 March 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (geographic names)#rfc_1E27345|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (geographic names)]] expired 2017-03-19 13:01 ===
* Id: 1E27345
* User: HerkusMonte
* Date: 2017-02-17 12:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|766007527|STYLE 766007527}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|771085857|STYLE 771085857}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Is it established [[WP:CONSENSUS]] to mention relevant foreign names (in this case German names of Pomeranian villages) in the WP:LEAD section? 

{{ping|Rockypedia}} deleted several dozens of German placenames from such articles (e.g.[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wyszog%C3%B3ra&oldid=prev&diff=765663992], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Krajnik&oldid=prev&diff=765663769], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Drzyma%C5%82owice&oldid=prev&diff=765663644],[https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Kie%C5%82cze&oldid=prev&diff=765663078], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Z%C4%99bowo,_Pomeranian_Voivodeship&oldid=prev&diff=765661470], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=D%C4%85bie,_Szczecinek_County&oldid=prev&diff=765661372], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Czechy,_West_Pomeranian_Voivodeship&oldid=prev&diff=765661354], [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Stary_Przybys%C5%82aw&oldid=prev&diff=765661319], 
For a complete overview see [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Special:Contributions/Rockypedia&offset=&limit=100&target=Rockypedia]
I already pointed out [[WP:PLACE]] and the Gdansk vote [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User_talk:Rockypedia&diff=763645326&oldid=761904728] but Rocky removed my message from his talk page [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=User_talk:Rockypedia&diff=764970007&oldid=764862464] and instead continued to delete foreign names [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=S%C5%82awa,_West_Pomeranian_Voivodeship&oldid=prev&diff=765661285]. [[User:HerkusMonte|HerkusMonte]] ([[User talk:HerkusMonte|talk]]) 12:43, 17 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:User categories#rfc_59C40CF|Wikipedia talk:User categories]] expired 2017-03-19 16:02 ===
* Id: 59C40CF
* Date: 2017-02-17 15:10:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|765990306|POLICY 765990306}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|771107115|POLICY 771107115}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am proposing that the current text in the section '''[[Wikipedia:User_categories#Inappropriate_types_of_user_categories|Inappropriate types of user categories]]''' regarding joke categories be removed. The text reads:
<div style="border:1px solid black;">
:;Categories which group users on the basis of '''irrelevant likes'''
::This includes any grouping of users on the basis of shared preferences that are irrelevant to encyclopedia-building (e.g. [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/User/Archive/August 2007#Category:Wikipedians who like red foxes|Wikipedians who like red foxes]], [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/User/Archive/September 2006#Wikipedians by diet|Wikipedians by food preference]]).
:...
:;Categories that are '''jokes/nonsense'''
::This includes any grouping of users that are patently false (e.g. [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/User/Archive/June 2007#Category:Wikipedians who are zombies|Wikipedians who are zombies]], [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/User/Archive/July 2007#Category:Wikipedians in their 780s|Wikipedians in their 780s]]), nonsensical (e.g. [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/User/Archive/December 2007#Category:Userpages That Are Full Of LOL|Userpages That Are Full Of LOL]]), undecipherable (e.g. [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/User/Archive/September 2007#Category:Wikipedians who Watch animals from their POV|Wikipedians who Watch animals from their POV]]), or created primarily for humourous or satirical purposes (e.g. [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/User/Archive/April 2007#Category:Wikipedians who are one of an infinite number of monkeys|Wikipedians who are one of an infinite number of monkeys]]).<ref>A list of precedents is available at [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/User/Archive/Topical index#Nonsense/joke/humour categories]].</ref><noinclude>
</div>
I am proposing that it be removed from this section and replaced with something '''similar to''' the following, in the section '''[[Wikipedia:User_categories#Appropriate_types_of_user_categories|Appropriate types of user categories]]''':
<div style="border:1px solid black;">
:;Categories which foster a genial atmosphere
::This includes joke categories, categories pertaining to likes that do not directly address the encyclopedia and other categories not covered in the list of inappropriate categories below. (e.g. [[:Category:Wikipedians who are "out to get you" and/or your garage band]]). This does not include joke or interest categories which are broadly perceived as offensive or which contain offensive language.
</div>
There is also a question of whether or not to organize such categories into a separate master cat to keep them out of the way of other such categories, but that can be discussed once there is a consensus on this question. <span style="text-shadow:grey 0.118em 0.118em 0.118em; class=texhtml">[[User:MjolnirPants|<font color="green">'''ᛗᛁᛟᛚᚾᛁᚱPants'''</font>]] [[User_talk:MjolnirPants|<small>Tell me all about it.</small>]]</span> 15:10, 17 February 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Smith & Wesson M&P15#rfc_268F585|Talk:Smith & Wesson M&P15]] expired 2017-03-19 20:02 ===
* Id: 268F585
* User: 52.56.171.93
* Date: 2017-02-28 18:42:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|768264792|ECON 768264792}}
