=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_A1C9A59|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2017-04-28 03:01 ===
* Id: A1C9A59
* User: Obsidi
* Date: 2017-04-27 23:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|777594885|PROP 777594885}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
<big>'''Introduction'''</big>

The Arbitration Committee process is great for disputes among large numbers of editors where there are multiple possible remedies that could occur for a large number of editors. It doesn’t succeed as well for requests to desysop due to the bureaucratic nature, the long timelines, and the lack of community input. It is also not as successful for long term low-level abuse of tools where the admin has lost the trust of the community. I wish to propose a slight change to the current system.

I believe by giving the community a way they can start the process, along with a simplified procedure, that it will improve the system along with the trust of the community in giving people the bit more often.

<big>'''Proposed Community Based De-adminship'''</big>

If there is a consensus for De-adminship of a given administrator by the community at [[WP:Administrators' noticeboard]], then a motion will be made on behalf of the community to the [[WP:Arbitration Committee]] to desysop the admin. It will still be up to the [[WP:Arbitration Committee]] to evaluate the evidence presented at the [[WP:Administrators' noticeboard]] and to evaluate if the administrator failed to act in a manner appropriate for an administrator to the extent of requiring desysop or to get any additional evidence or information needed to make that decision.

Thank you for considering this proposal. -[[User:Obsidi|Obsidi]] ([[User talk:Obsidi|talk]]) 23:15, 27 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Microscope#rfc_7895A8F|Talk:Microscope]] expired 2017-04-28 05:01 ===
* Id: 7895A8F
* User: 2601:648:8503:4467:F4B3:6D6C:9DCC:DC06
* Date: 2017-04-01 20:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|773341934|SCI 773341934}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|777606942|SCI 777606942}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This article says, "Scanning optical and electron microscopes, like the confocal microscope and scanning electron microscope, use lenses to focus a spot of light or electrons onto the sample '''then analyze the reflected or transmitted waves.'''"

I changed it to, "Scanning optical and electron microscopes, like the confocal microscope and scanning electron microscope, use lenses to focus a spot of light or electrons onto the sample '''then analyze the signals generated by the beam interacting with the sample.'''"

This contradicts the Wikipedia article on [[Scanning electron microscope]]s (and all reliable sources), which says," The electrons interact with atoms in the sample, producing various signals that contain information about the sample's surface topography and composition."

Also, the major optical methods work differently, and this is a poor misrepresentation of both [[Confocal laser scanning microscopy]] and [[Near-field scanning optical microscope]], but I haven't gotten near those.

Please discuss, and please provide references.

--[[Special:Contributions/2601:648:8503:4467:F4B3:6D6C:9DCC:DC06|2601:648:8503:4467:F4B3:6D6C:9DCC:DC06]] ([[User talk:2601:648:8503:4467:F4B3:6D6C:9DCC:DC06|talk]]) 20:58, 1 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_B9E5872|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-04-28 16:01 ===
* Id: B9E5872
* User: ProgrammingGeek
* Date: 2017-04-26 14:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|777329112|POLICY 777329112}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|777672502|POLICY 777672502}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
=== Proposal '''

Speedy deletion criteria [[WP:A7|A7]] and [[WP:A9|A9]] should be removed.

''' Rationale '''

Wikipedia encourages us to [[WP:Don't bite the newbies|don't bite the newbies]]. However, when some new users attempt to create an article, it is tagged for an A7 or A9 deletion within minutes, before they can add appropriate sources. Although some users create an article in [[WP:AFC|draftspace]], where 'A' criteria do not apply, those who publish in articlespace find their submissions deleted in minutes.

A7 and A9 should be removed because:
*Other deletion criteria address urgent concerns. [[WP:G3|G3]] covers hoaxes, [[WP:G11|G11]] covers advertising, [[WP:G12|G12]] covers copyvios, [[WP:CSD|etc]].
*A true discussion of notability should take place at [[WP:AFD|Articles for deletion]]. This gives users time to prove [[WP:GNG|notability]].
*Tagging an article as A7 or A9 can make Wikipedia's promise of "the free encyclopedia that anyone can edit" seem like a lie.
*If an article is an unsourced BLP, it can be [[WP:BLPPROD|PRODed]]. Indeed, it can be [[WP:PROD|PRODed]] even if it isn't a BLP. At least this allows users to add sources, '''then''' contest the PROD.
*"Contesting a speedy deletion" is rarely useful - if a user goes away for even an hour they can find their article deleted without being able to contest.

[[User:ProgrammingGeek|'''<span style="color:Green">Programming</span><span style="color:Orange">Geek</span>''']][[User talk:ProgrammingGeek|<sup><span style="color:Green"> talk</span><span style="color:Orange">to</span>me</sup>]] 14:05, 26 April 2017 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_F82945A|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-04-28 16:01 ===
* Id: F82945A
* Date: 2017-04-23 00:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|776745401|POLICY 776745401}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|777672502|POLICY 777672502}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I propose amending the [[WP:BLP|biographies of living persons]] policy to avoid misrepresenting people. I think that there should be a rule prohibiting editors from labeling a person differently than they describe themselves. In other words, we shouldn't say that Caitlyn Jenner is a man even though she describes herself as a woman, we shouldn't say that Richard Spencer is a white supremacist even though he rejects that label, we shouldn't say that Donald Trump is a liberal even though he obviously is not. (Those are all just hypothetical scenarios). Even if sources describe a person differently, I think that their own self-description should outweigh everything else. That way, we can avoid controversy and accusations of defamation ('''NOT a [[WP:NLT|legal threat]]'''). In a nutshell, I think that if someone rejects a certain label, we shouldn't call them by that label on Wikipedia, no matter what. My proposal is flexible and I'm all ears to anyone willing to comment. Let me know what you guys think. <span style="color:blue">'''THE DIAZ'''</span> 00:18, 23 April 2017 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Non-admin closure#rfc_B71C92F|Wikipedia talk:Non-admin closure]] expired 2017-04-28 16:01 ===

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the current wording of the lead:

be changed to:

(emphasis in original) [[User:Timothyjosephwood|<span style="color:#a56d3f;font-family:Impact;">Timothy</span><span style="color:#6f3800;font-family:Impact;">Joseph</span><span style="color:#422501;font-family:Impact;">Wood</span>]] 21:18, 31 March 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_E04E3CA|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2017-04-28 16:01 ===
* Id: E04E3CA
* User: Headbomb
* Date: 2017-04-14 09:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|775350516|PROP 775350516}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|777672507|PROP 777672507}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Some pages like [[WT:NJournals]] are tagged only with a banner and nothing else. I think it's pretty reasonable to say that people who link to [[WT:NJournals]] expect to have people be taken to the same place [[Wikipedia talk:Notability (academic journals)]]. [This is true in Wikipedia talk space, just like in any other talk spaces, whether mainspace, category space, etc... This can be confusing to editors, because they are told "comment here", and the page doesn't redirect to the discussion they were meant to be taken.

So I propose that we have a bot with the following logic
*If ''nothing but banners'' is found on [[Talk:Barfoo]]
*''and'' [[Barfoo]] redirects to [[Foobar]]
*Redirect [[Talk:Barfoo]] to [[Talk:Foobar]] (but preserve banners)

For an example where this is already done, see [[WT:NJOURNALS]]. <span style="font-variant:small-caps; whitespace:nowrap;">[[User:Headbomb|Headbomb]] {[[User talk:Headbomb|t]] · [[Special:Contributions/Headbomb|c]] · [[WP:PHYS|p]] · [[WP:WBOOKS|b]]}</span> 09:37, 14 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_92D2F62|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2017-04-28 18:01 ===
* Id: 92D2F62
* User: Jytdog
* Date: 2017-03-30 00:07:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|772899550|POLICY 772899550}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|772899554|TECH 772899554}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|777749475|POLICY 777749475}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|777749478|TECH 777749478}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This stems from discussion at [[Wikipedia:Administrators%27_noticeboard/Incidents#Hard_to_detect_mobile_vandalism]] and  [[Wikipedia:Village_pump_(technical)#Discussion_at_ANI_about_Wikidata_use_in_mobile_view]]

Do you support the following statement:  "The description taken from Wikidata that is currently being loaded in mobile views of en-WP pages, must be immediately removed from mobile views of en-WP pages" 

Please !vote "support" or "oppose". [[User:Jytdog|Jytdog]] ([[User talk:Jytdog|talk]]) 00:07, 30 March 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox religious text#rfc_D4E0FA6|Template talk:Infobox religious text]] expired 2017-04-29 00:01 ===
* Id: D4E0FA6
* User: Capankajsmilyo
* Date: 2017-04-27 13:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|777491801|UNSORTED 777491801}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|777742890|UNSORTED 777742890}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
We should go ahead with adding wikidata params, along with options to enable editors to suppress them. This will enable improvement of both wikidata and wikipedia by synchronizing the information and reducing edit-wars on wikipedia, as controversial params can be fetched from wikidata, which do not support un-linked content for most fields. {{u|Ms Sarah Welch}} {{u|Frietjes}} -- Pankaj Jain ''[[User:Capankajsmilyo|Capankajsmilyo]] <span class="plainlinks">([[User talk:Capankajsmilyo|talk]] '''·''' [[Special:Contribs/Capankajsmilyo|contribs]] '''·''' [//tools.wmflabs.org/xtools-ec/?user=Capankajsmilyo&project=en.wikipedia.org count])</span>'' 13:18, 27 April 2017 (UTC)}}

The article contains the following statement cited to Anthony Summers's book ''Not in Your Lifetime'':
:''In 1978, William Gaudet, a 20-year CIA informant who had worked out of an office at the [[International Trade Mart]] in New Orleans, told investigator [[Anthony Summers]] that Ferrie "was with Oswald," although Gaudet did not state where or when, or whether he knew this directly or by hearsay. Gaudet also said, "Another vital person is Sergio Arcacha Smith. I know he knew Oswald and knows more about the Kennedy affair than he ever admitted."''
Should the above statement be included in the article? 05:25, 8 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Erik Prince#rfc_D65B809|Talk:Erik Prince]] expired 2017-04-30 20:01 ===
* Id: D65B809
* User: DrFleischman
* Date: 2017-04-06 04:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|774086484|BIO 774086484}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|774086486|POL 774086486}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|778954842|BIO 778954842}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|778954847|POL 778954847}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following content be added to the article (or something similar)?
:{{tq|In 2016 Prince supported [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] candidate [[Donald Trump]] for [[President of the United States]]. Prince had no formal role in [[Presidential transition of Donald Trump|Trump's transition]]. In December 2016 Prince visited the transition team offices in [[New York]]. In April 2017 as part of a broader investigation into [[Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections]] the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] is investigating a January 11, 2017 meeting in the [[Seychelles]] at which Prince presented himself as an unofficial representative of Trump.<ref name=wapo20170403>{{cite news |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=April 3, 2017 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/national-security/blackwater-founder-held-secret-seychelles-meeting-to-establish-trump-putin-back-channel/2017/04/03/95908a08-1648-11e7-ada0-1489b735b3a3_story.html |title=Blackwater founder held secret Seychelles meeting to establish Trump-Putin back channel |first1=Adam |last1=Entous |first2=Greg |last2=Miller |authorlink3=Kevin Sieff |first3=Kevin |last3=Sieff |authorlink4=Karen DeYoung |first4=Karen |last4=DeYoung |accessdate=April 4, 2017}}</ref>}}
{{reflist-talk}}
For reference, here's an incomplete list of additional sources covering the same story: [http://www.cbsnews.com/news/report-trump-donor-blackwater-founder-erik-prince-in-secret-meeting-with-russian-close-to-putin/ CBS News], [http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/blackwater-founder-repped-trump-secret-meeting-overseas-sources-n742266 NBC News], [http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/327074-blackwater-founder-held-meeting-to-establish-trump-russia The Hill], [http://www.esquire.com/news-politics/politics/news/a54292/erik-prince-russia-seychelles/ Esquire], [http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/erik-prince-create-secret-trump-russia-dialogue-report-article-1.3018024 NY Daily News], [http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2017/04/04/ex-trump-adviser-carter-page-met-with-russian-intel-operative-in-2013.html Fox News], the [https://www.nytimes.com/aponline/2017/04/03/us/politics/ap-us-trump-russia.html AP], [https://www.bostonglobe.com/news/nation/2017/04/05/what-meeting-between-blackwater-founder-and-russian-means-for-trump/m7SXCdWDncRDCZYdQw6JUP/story.html Boston Globe]. --[[User:DrFleischman|Dr. Fleischman]] ([[User talk:DrFleischman|talk]]) 04:36, 6 April 2017 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:Erik Prince#rfc_05DB175|Talk:Erik Prince]] expired 2017-04-30 20:01 ===
* Id: 05DB175
* User: DrFleischman
* Date: 2017-03-31 19:12:00

{{rfcquote|text=
Is the following paragraph balanced? 

:{{tq|Prince serves as vice president of the [[Prince Foundation]], which his family founded.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2016/10/22/blackwater-founder-erik-prince-loves-anti-iraq-war-donald-trump0.html|title=Blackwater Founder Erik Prince, Who Got Rich Off Of Iraq, Now Backs 'Anti-War' Donald Trump|publisher=[[The Daily Beast]]|date=October 22, 2016|first=Betsy|last=Woodruff}}</ref> In 2001 the foundation donated $10 million to [[Calvin College]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.calvin.edu/news/2001-02/fallboard.htm |title=Calvin College: Calvin News |publisher=Calvin.edu |date=October 29, 2001 |accessdate=August 25, 2013}}</ref> a Christian institution in Grand Rapids, Michigan.}}

Feel free to add more if you find them. --[[User:DrFleischman|Dr. Fleischman]] ([[User talk:DrFleischman|talk]]) 19:12, 31 March 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject College football#rfc_29EB679|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject College football]] expired 2017-05-01 02:01 ===
* Id: 29EB679
* User: Corkythehornetfan
* Date: 2017-04-01 01:30:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|773224248|BIO 773224248}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|773224255|SOC 773224255}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|778090461|BIO 778090461}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|778090465|SOC 778090465}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Since I posted about this in [[:Wikipedia talk:WikiProject College football/Archive 17#Navigation boxes in coaches articles|a year ago]] (and had posted it at [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject College Basketball]] as well with the discussion held there by another user's choice), a certain user (Jweiss11) has decided that there is no consensus (which is clearly wrong.) I had posted the discussion at the College Basketball WikiProject an [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject College Basketball/Archive 6#Navigation boxes in coaches articles|hour after the College football post]]. That user decided to hold the discussion there. The post read:
<blockquote>''Something needs to be done with navigation boxes like in the [[William McAvoy#External links|William McAvoy]] article. There is simply <u>way</u> too many to not be grouped together. Personally, I'd like to see them grouped like in [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=William_McAvoy&diff=prev&oldid=713085527 this diff]. No color is needed since the coaches are at various schools. I don't care if you want to leave the default name <code>Links to related articles</code> as the title or something like <code>''Name'' coaching positions</code>, etc. [[Robert L. Mathews|This article]] is another example.''</blockquote>

During the discussionUsers had three options: 
# Group the navboxes '''all together''';
# Group the navboxes '''separately''';
# '''do not group''' the navboxes at all; or
# a different option.
Out of the participants (Me, {{ping|Jweiss11|Sphilbrick|Bagumba|Rikster2|UCO2009bluejay|Lizard the Wizard|MisterCake|Jrcla2|Littlekelv}}), the consensus was clear (for those who !voted) – '''group them all together''' (5–1). Jrcla2 expressed he didn't "feel strongly about this but we may as well just lump everything together so keep pages cleaner." Jweiss expressed, and the user who keeps going against consensus, he's in favor of "Leaving all positional navboxes ungrouped and putting all championships, awards, and honors navboxes in one collapsed grouping." Something Rikster2 said – and I happen to agree with – is "I just fail to see why coach tenure navboxes are necessarily more important than others and am tired of the overloaded navboxes of the [[Larry Brown (basketball)|Larry Brown]]'s and [[Mysterious Walker]]'s of the world. At the end of the day, coach tenures should be in the infobox anyway so it isn't like the information is being hidden - it is still available on quick scan." After the consensus, edits were made to reflect it, but Jweiss keeps reverting. I'm tired of it and would like others to jump in to voice their opinions. Thanks, <span style="background:black; color:#FFFFFF; border:1px solid black">Corkythe</span><span style="background:#BB8D0A; color:#FFFFFF; border:1px solid black">[[User talk:Corkythehornetfan|<span style="color:white">hornetfan</span>]]</span> (ping me) 01:30, 1 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:John Fleming (American politician)#rfc_8C3D969|Talk:John Fleming (American politician)]] expired 2017-05-01 15:01 ===
* Id: 8C3D969
* User: Tomuchtalk
* Date: 2017-04-01 14:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|773292276|POL 773292276}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|778167888|POL 778167888}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There was lengthy discussion in 2012/13 regarding a brief posting of a link to a satire site (The Onion) on Congressman Fleming's Facebook page. Though it was never determined whether Fleming or a staff member actually posted the link, it was reported as one of many accidental references to satirical sites by politicians, editors and news anchors. Ultimately it was determined that it was not suitable for the article and has been deleted since then. There has been no further disclosures or incidents, but a single editor has posted it again to the article creating a disagreement as to whether it would improve the article when no new information or incidents have been reported.  I request comment from other editors as to whether the new posting of the same information from 2012 should be re-added to the article.[[User:Tomuchtalk|Tomuchtalk]] ([[User talk:Tomuchtalk|talk]]) 14:57, 1 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Lead section#rfc_1C0EC0F|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Lead section]] expired 2017-05-02 14:01 ===
* Id: 1C0EC0F
* User: Pasta3049
* Date: 2017-04-02 13:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|773453080|STYLE 773453080}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|778334508|STYLE 778334508}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
From above:

There seems to be inconsistency in the way that sponsored names are handled in the lead section of articles. On some articles (including [[Dean Court]] and [[Queen's Club Championships]]) the sponsored name is written in bold. On some other articles (including [[London Eye]] and [[The Boat Race]]) the sponsored name is not in bold.

Should a consistent policy be adopted across English Wikipedia, either:
# making the sponsored name bold on all articles, or
# requiring that the sponsored name is not written in bold?
[[User:Pasta3049|pasta3049]] ([[User talk:Pasta3049|talk]]) 13:26, 2 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Blue Army (Poland)#rfc_270D848|Talk:Blue Army (Poland)]] expired 2017-05-02 18:01 ===
* Id: 270D848
* User: E-960
* Date: 2017-04-02 17:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|773483022|HIST 773483022}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|773483024|POL 773483024}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|778365785|HIST 778365785}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|778365789|POL 778365789}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the Introduction paragraph continue to display a reference source from Encyclopedia Judaica (reference source citation [1]) when it was taken down by the website, and is a dead link (currently retained by use of Wayback Machine). Also, should the same reference source citation display the entire paragraph from the encyclopedia? 

Full statement reads, as it is currently displayed in the WP article's reference citation:

{{quote box
| border=2px
| align=center
| bgcolor =
| title=
| halign=left
| quote=
Encyclopedia Judaica. Retrieved 5 October 2015. Haller's army ("Blue Army"), force of Polish volunteers organized in France during the last year of World War I, responsible for the murder of Jews and anti-Jewish pogroms in Galicia and the Ukraine… Foreign officers and the ties with France kept Haller's forces independent of the official Polish command, a fact exploited by Haller's soldiers (called the "Hallerczycy") for undisciplined and unbridled excesses against Jewish communities in Galicia. Attacks on individual Jews on the streets and highways, murderous pogroms on Jewish settlements, and deliberate provocative acts became commonplace. While these may have been on the initiative of individual soldiers, they were known to their officers, if not openly supported by them. In 1920, during the Polish offensive toward Kiev resulting from the Pilsudski-Petlyura alliance, anti-Jewish pogroms occurred in the region.|}}

Voting options:
# '''Remove''' - ''entirely'' 
# '''Keep''' - ''but remove the excessive quotation of the entire paragraph''
# '''Keep''' - ''entirely''
--[[User:E-960|E-960]] ([[User talk:E-960|talk]]) 17:53, 2 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Requests for comment/MOS:GENDERID for genderqueer people#rfc_C05406E|Wikipedia:Requests for comment/MOS:GENDERID for genderqueer people]] expired 2017-05-03 04:01 ===
* Id: C05406E
* User: Feminist
* Date: 2017-04-14 14:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|775391248|POLICY 775391248}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|775391249|PROP 775391249}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|778441721|POLICY 778441721}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|778441727|PROP 778441727}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I propose adding the following section to [[MOS:GENDERID]]:
{{divbox|gray|2=People who do not identify as male or female|3=
If neither male nor female pronouns are appropriate for use in a biographical article, including biographies of people falling under the [[genderqueer]] umbrella, avoid the use of pronouns whenever possible. Instead, refer to the person by name if required, e.g. on a biography for a [[non-binary]] person named Chris Doe, avoid {{!xt|They have written many novels and their work has been featured in many publications}} and instead use {{xt|Doe has written many novels and Doe's work has been featured in many publications}}. This makes it easier for readers to follow the article, including both readers who do not accept [[singular they]] and readers who do not accept incorrect pronouns.
}}

[[MOS:GENDERID]] currently does not specify how biographies of people who identify as neither male nor female should be handled. I have seen inconsistencies with the use of pronouns on articles of such people; some use singular they, others avoid the use of pronouns and instead refer to the person by name. I have previously edited the [[Grace Dunham]] and [[Zoë Quinn]] articles, both of whom are people who transitioned from a female identity to a non-binary identity, to avoid the use of pronouns, and was met with [[WP:SILENCE|silent consensus]], indicating that no editor objected to such usage. This proposal avoids the use of pronouns on such articles altogether, which is an appropriate compromise between Wikipedia editors, a demographic affected by [[WP:Systemic bias]] and therefore more exposed to gender issues, and many readers who may still find singular they to be hard to follow and/or consider that to be incorrect grammar. Singular they is commonly used when the gender of a person is unknown, but this is not the case with genderqueer people, and the use of singular they to refer to a specific person may come off as unnatural to far more people. [[User:Feminist|<span style="color:DarkMagenta">f</span>]][[Special:Contributions/Feminist|<span style="color:DarkMagenta">e</span>]][[User talk:Feminist|<span style="color:DarkMagenta">minist</span>]] 14:01, 14 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Requests for comment/RfC to adopt a default gender neutral style for policy, guidelines and help pages#rfc_3A9CFD2|Wikipedia:Requests for comment/RfC to adopt a default gender neutral style for policy, guidelines and help pages]] expired 2017-05-04 23:01 ===
* Id: 3A9CFD2
* User: Fæ
* Date: 2017-04-07 15:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|774309125|POLICY 774309125}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|774309128|PROP 774309128}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|779176301|POLICY 779176301}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|779176308|PROP 779176308}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This proposal is to add to policy so that gender neutral language becomes a default for Wikipedia policies, help and guidelines. It will make Wikipedia a more welcoming environment for all genders, including [[non-binary]] readers and contributors who may feel excluded by avoidable emphasis on gendered words and phrases, such as "he or she". The proposal does not apply to articles, any type of discussion page, or individual users referring to themselves or others. -- [[User:Fæ|Fæ]] ([[User talk:Fæ|talk]]) 15:02, 7 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of manufacturers by motor vehicle production#rfc_388A405|Talk:List of manufacturers by motor vehicle production]] expired 2017-05-05 11:01 ===
* Id: 388A405
* User: Rayukk
* Date: 2017-04-09 18:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|774633885|ECON 774633885}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|778813949|ECON 778813949}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
* '''Option 1:''' Take the production numbers directly from the (highly reputable) source [[Organisation Internationale des Constructeurs d'Automobiles|OICA]], which may in some cases not accurately represent the current market as the production numbers of subsidiaries are not (always) included in the parent company's numbers.
* '''Option 2:''' Add the numbers of all the subsidiaries of a parent company together and provide the sum, thus altering the original source material.<br />–[[User:Rayukk|rayukk]] &#124; [[User talk:Rayukk|talk]] 18:43, 9 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Harassment#rfc_BA561FE|Wikipedia talk:Harassment]] expired 2017-05-06 05:01 ===
* Id: BA561FE
* User: Jytdog
* Date: 2017-05-05 15:39:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|778866152|POLICY 778866152}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|778954855|POLICY 778954855}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
After extensive discussion above, am proposing we add the following two bits of content to this policy, to catch it up with community practice - the work that oversighters and others do every day in removing harassing content about RW people added to WP.  This proposal attempts to address that gap in the written policy, and no more.   There are larger issues afoot with the [[Wikipedia:Community health initiative]] which is looking to develop new policy around harassment. This is not that.

{{quote frame|text=Wikipedia must never be misused to harass anyone, whether or not the subject of the harassment is an editor here.}}

And a new main-level section, immediately following [[WP:OWH]]:

{{quote frame|text='''Harassing those outside of the editing community'''<p>In alignment with the protection of editors from harassment described throughout the rest of this policy, edits that harass living or recently deceased people who are not members of the Wikipedia community are also prohibited. Per the [[WP:OVERSIGHT|oversight policy]], harassing content will be deleted or suppressed. Editors who post such material in any namespace may be indefinitely blocked.<p>Where content is added or comments are made about a living person for a ''direct, legitimate encyclopedic purpose'', such as in an article about a notable person or event or in a relevant talkpage discussion including discussions of sources, all aspects of the policy on [[WP:BLP|biographies of living persons]] must be observed, and in the event of any disputes, the procedures described in that policy must be followed.}}

Thoughts? [[User:Jytdog|Jytdog]] ([[User talk:Jytdog|talk]]) 15:39, 5 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Jewish diaspora#rfc_F4A37DE|Talk:Jewish diaspora]] expired 2017-05-06 18:01 ===
* Id: F4A37DE
* User: Dailycare
* Date: 2017-04-06 18:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|774175585|HIST 774175585}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|779044296|HIST 779044296}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is an ongoing discussion here, relating to how to describe the expert opinion on the reasons behind the diaspora esp. about whether the diaspora is a result of forced expulsion.  
The operative sources are as follows:
{{collapse top|Sources}}
*  "in the popular imagination of Jewish history, in contrast to the accounts of historians or official agencies, there is a widespread notion that the Jews from Judea were expelled in antiquity after the destruction of the temple and the "Great Rebellion" (70 and 135 CE, respectively). Even more misleading, there is the widespread, popular belief that this expulsion created the diaspora." ([https://books.google.com/books?id=80j612aFo_4C&pg=PA159&hl=en&sa=X&ei=mj54UYakNJCM4gSK9ICwCQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false 'No Return, No Refuge'' (Howard Adelman, Elazar Barkan, p. 159]))
*"Although the myth of an exile from the Jewish homeland (Palestine) does exist in popular Israeli culture, it is negligible in serious Jewish historical discussions."([https://web.archive.org/web/20090416045211/http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/999386.html Israel Bartal, dean of humanities at the Hebrew University])
*"Experts dismiss the popular notion that the Jews were expelled from Palestine in one fell swoop in A.D. 70." ([http://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/24/books/24jews.html?pagewanted=2 New York Times])
*""the dispersal of the Jews, even in ancient times, was connected with an array of factors, none of them clearly exilic" ([https://books.google.com/books?id=gg0m24wY_lUC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Ten+Lost+Tribes:+A+World+History&hl=en&sa=X&ei=vca7UOzWM_D34QS5mYDgAQ&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=The%20Ten%20Lost%20Tribes%3A%20A%20World%20History&f=false Israel Yuval, in  ''The Ten Lost Tribes: A World History'' (Zvi Ben-Dor Benite, Oxford University Press 2009] p.17-18))
* "Focus on the consequences of the Temple's destruction, however, overlooks a fact of immense significance: the diaspora had a long history prior to Rome's crushing of Jerusalem. (...) Compulsory dislocation, however, cannot have accounted for more than a fraction of the diaspora", [[Erich S. Gruen]], "Diaspora: Jews Amidst Greeks and Romans", pages 2-3)
*This text is cited in the section to Ilan Ziv: "The majority of Jewish people were already living in the Diaspora before the destruction of the Second Temple, with perhaps as many as a million in Alexandria for example" (I haven't separately verified this last source) 
{{collapse bottom}}

The options are:<br />

*A: The widespread popular belief that there was a sudden expulsion of Jews from Judea/Syria Palaestina that led to the creation of the Diaspora is not accepted by historians''' <br />

*B: However, some scholars argue against the idea that the diaspora is entirely the result of a sudden mass expulsion of Jews from Judea/Syria Palaestina''' <br />

*C: (list the scholars cited) argue that the widespread popular belief that there was a sudden expulsion of Jews from Judea/Syria Palaestina that led to the creation of the Diaspora is not accepted by historians'''.

:<small>A corresponds to the version of the text that has been in the article for several years.</small> [[User:Dailycare|Dailycare]] ([[User talk:Dailycare|talk]]) 18:01, 6 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Menstrual disc#rfc_F00C952|Talk:Menstrual disc]] expired 2017-05-07 10:01 ===
* Id: F00C952
* User: Lmschulte
* Date: 2017-04-24 01:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|776907184|PROP 776907184}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|777934445|SCI 777934445}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|779157266|SCI 779157266}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|779157275|PROP 779157275}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The menstrual cup page states several facts which are not true of menstrual discs. Specifically, the menstrual cup page states that (the following are verbatim quotes as of the time of this posting):

* A menstrual cup is a type of feminine hygiene product which is usually made of '''medical grade silicone''', shaped like a bell and is flexible. [emphasis added]<ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menstrual_cup]</ref>
* Manufacturers have different recommendations for when to replace the cups, but in general they can be '''reused for five years or more'''. [emphasis added]<ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menstrual_cup]</ref>
* It is '''reusable''' and '''designed to last for up to 10 years'''.  [emphasis added]<ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menstrual_cup#Types]</ref> 
* After about 4–12 hours of use (depending on the amount of flow), the cup is removed by '''reaching up to the stem of the cup''' in order to find the base. [emphasis added] <ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menstrual_cup#Use]</ref>
* Menstrual cups '''must be removed before penetrative vaginal sex'''. [emphasis added] <ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menstrual_cup#Use]</ref>
* This is not a quote, but the menstrual cup page uses this graphic to show that this is how a cup is inserted: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Menstrual_cup_inserted.png/220px-Menstrual_cup_inserted.png

This independent, 3rd-party source states the following about menstrual discs: http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/pdfplus/10.1089/jwh.2009.1929 The source calls Softcup, a menstrual disc brand, a "menstrual cup", which is the biggest point of confusion, but goes on to state the following facts (the following are verbatim quotes from the source):

* The Softcup (Instead, Inc., San Diego, CA) is a simple single-size '''disposable''' over-thecounter (OTC) menstrual cup that compresses to tampon shape to facilitate insertion and '''can be worn during coitus'''. [emphasis added]
* Because the Softcup is aligned along the long axis of the vagina, '''intercourse can take place''' below the cup, avoiding contact with the rim and minimizing risk of displacement. [emphasis added]
* It is composed of a '''proprietary blend of soft biocompatible polymer compounds''' in conformance with the United States Pharmacopoeia XIX Class VI criteria for plastics [emphasis added]
* Once inserted, it opens to an oval shape, '''positioned between the posterior fornix and the notch behind the pubic bone''', covering the cervix. [emphasis added]
*  Removal is accomplished by '''hooking a finger over the rim''' behind the pubic bone. [emphasis added]

The last two facts about insertion and removal contradict the graphic shown on the menstrual cup page on insertion. The graphic in fact shows the menstrual cup sitting in the vaginal canal not the vaginal fornix -- it does not touch the pubic bone at all.

Page 3 of the above source also shows an image of a menstrual disc. The disc does not have a stem like menstrual cups.

Signed,
[[User:Lmschulte|Lmschulte]] ([[User talk:Lmschulte|talk]]) 01:35, 24 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Monroeville, Alabama#rfc_73B71A2|Talk:Monroeville, Alabama]] expired 2017-05-07 11:01 ===
* Id: 73B71A2
* User: Yellowmellow45
* Date: 2017-05-06 01:23:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|779157262|HIST 779157262}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|779157268|MEDIA 779157268}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|779157271|SOC 779157271}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Banco de Ponce (disambiguation)#rfc_6CD7962|Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Banco de Ponce (disambiguation)]] expired 2017-05-10 13:01 ===
* Id: 6CD7962
* User: Doncram
* Date: 2017-05-10 05:40:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|779685388|STYLE 779685388}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|779685389|POLICY 779685389}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|779698143|STYLE 779698143}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|779698145|POLICY 779698145}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
:'''Keep'''.  Thank you for notifying me and for linking to the past proposal (which got archived rather than closed).  The disambiguation page is an orphan, as most are;  disambiguation pages should mostly not have inbound links (an exception being from "See also" of other dab pages).  About this and other 2-item disambiguation pages, and where hatnotes between the two articles exist, in my opinion there need not be any link to the disambiguation page from the articles (perhaps that requires a change in bureaucratic policy, i am not sure).  If/when sufficient more items get added to the disambiguation page (and here I have the impression in this case that there exist other Banco de Ponce branches which can be listed in the future possibly) so that hatnotes between the pages become unwieldy, only then does the disambiguation page get linked from any non-disambiguation mainspace article.  There's no cost to readers; they pretty much cannot find their way to the disambiguation page.  However it would be linked from "See also" at, say, "Banco de Pence (disambiguation)" if such existed, and the like.  Keeping the disambiguation page hurts no one and has us further developed.  Its Talk page and edit history keep the record of debates about whether certain items are partial matches or not, and about redlink topics and so on, and about AFDs about the disambiguation page.  If the disambiguation page is deleted there is no gain, and some cost (on a good percentage of the cases) where the disambiguation page is recreated in the future.  If this one happens to be a low traffic topic where few I.P. editors are coming and adding partial matches or redlinks or whatever, great, but the value of keeping the disambiguation page is higher the more churn there has been.  Fight forgetting boring info about what disambiguation is needed, or possibly needed if only something else happens like a redlink being created in context in some article per requirement of [[wp:DABRL]].  Fight churn, which turns off prospective and experienced editors.  Fight against fights to delete stuff for no purpose! --[[User:doncram|<font color="maroon">do</font>]][[User talk:Doncram|<font color="green">ncr</font>]][[Special:Contributions/doncram|<font color="maroon">am</font>]] 05:40, 10 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Eugenics#rfc_96876CC|Talk:Eugenics]] expired 2017-05-13 01:01 ===
* Id: 96876CC
* User: Dimadick
* Date: 2017-05-12 10:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|779958039|UNSORTED 779958039}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|780108713|UNSORTED 780108713}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Just noting this because it seems this user has a clear PoV, is less than a month old.

Political participation does not hold any water in scientific endeavors. How you can expect others to take you seriously when you insert an "Alt right" sidebar, which includes many uneducated (and arguably some illiterate) people, is beyond me.

To suggest that uneducated individuals adoption of a scholarly field in order to bolster their bigoted and uneducated world-views (such as those included in the sidebar the user attempted to insert) is sufficient for an insertion is clearly false.

To suggest that large media exposure, and usage of this exposure to declare a belief in a scholarly field, is sufficient for insertion, is also false.

This user just runs around making scientific articles political on a whim, and unchecked. Something needs to be done. There are some serious scholars who put their career on this field, and while I am no fan of [[Richard Dawkins]], his gushing over [[Ronald Fisher]] here is sufficient to convey the calibre and pedigree of pioneers in the field.
* Just because [[User:PerfectlyIrrational]] doesn't like eugenics, or feels it is "racist" (nothing new here), it does not mean the people who are truly contributors to the field are anything like what he believes eugenics to be (where his belief is clearly wrong).

In this case I do not think scholarly opinions and uneducated opinions are all that different. The main goal remains to improve the "genetic quality of the human population". How do you define quality may be disputed and the suggested methodology may vary, but they are still part of the same field. Eugenics would frankly be a historical footnote if it did not have popular and political support. 

The main problem is the association of a 20th-century movement with the [[alt-right]], a rather vague and ill-defined grouping of right-wing ideologies and their supposed followers. The connections seems very weak to me. Some of these people are self-described monarchists. That does not require us to redefine monarchism as an alt-right idea. [[User:Dimadick|Dimadick]] ([[User talk:Dimadick|talk]]) 10:58, 12 May 2017 (UTC)}}

* User: Launebee
* Date: 2017-05-10 23:11:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|779792265|POLICY 779792265}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|780277763|POLICY 780277763}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the lead contain the following text:
{{quotebox|align=left|text=Sciences Po is widely considered to be one of Europe's most prestigious academic institutions and was ranked 4th globally in politics and international studies by the QS World University Subjects Rankings 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.topuniversities.com/university-rankings/university-subject-rankings/2017/politics|title=Politics & International Studies|date=2017-03-02|work=Top Universities|access-date=2017-05-05}}</ref> 
Alumni include many notable public figures, including seven of the last eight [[President of France|French president]]<nowiki/>s, 12 foreign heads of state or government, a former [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|United Nations Secretary-General]], and a number of CEOs of France's 40 largest companies.
{{reflist-talk}}
}}
{{clear}}

 [[User:Launebee|Launebee]] ([[User talk:Launebee|talk]]) 23:11, 10 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_6D8ECFB|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-05-14 11:01 ===
* Id: 6D8ECFB
* User: Fram
* Date: 2017-04-14 10:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|775360938|PROP 775360938}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|780331468|PROP 780331468}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Which sister projects should appear in the search results on enwiki? 

'''Background'''

[[User:CKoerner (WMF)]] announced in [[WP:VPT]] that Cross-wiki Search Results would be released soon: "The release date is expected to be near the end of April 2017 on all Wikipedias." [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Village_pump_(technical)&diff=prev&oldid=774200007] His post has further explanations and useful links to older discussions. The new tool can be easily tested by using [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search?search=rainbow&fulltext=1&cirrusUserTesting=recall_sidebar_results&searchToken=44bxhzfezy56uluyig20gnqk1 this] URL and replacing "rainbow" with the search term you want to test (remember to add the underscore for multi-word searches!).

When testing and discussing this further in [[Wikipedia:Village pump (technical)#Sister projects search results]], the possibility was raised to use this selectively on enwiki, by disabling or hiding the search results from some sister projects for all searches. Reasons for this might be that the content returned by some projects is too often irrelevant, problematic, outdated, spammy, or in some other way contradictory to the aims and purposes of enwiki and not really what we want to send our readers to. 

Some examples of common search terms (taken from the 100 most popular articles) with potentially unwanted results:
*[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search?search=Ox&fulltext=1&cirrusUserTesting=recall_sidebar_results&searchToken=1u398cwonygdeohyxqyec1wtb ox]
*[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search?search=Rick_and_Morty&fulltext=1&cirrusUserTesting=recall_sidebar_results&searchToken=1u398cwonygdeohyxqyec1wtb Rick and Morty]
*[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search?search=Heath_Ledger&fulltext=1&cirrusUserTesting=recall_sidebar_results&searchToken=26xozbp37iw3s7xy5oppe5q1l Heath Ledger]
*[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search?search=Charo&fulltext=1&cirrusUserTesting=recall_sidebar_results&searchToken=9ek9r9vwte61y5cib7ir8yls1 Charo]
*[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search?search=Facebook&fulltext=1&cirrusUserTesting=recall_sidebar_results&searchToken=3fwgsc6epj2jjcpky34qskffz Facebook]

Other searches either gave no results (apart from enwiki) or at first glance no problematic results. Note that at the moment, this search has a serious layout bug when searching for a term which doesn't have an enwiki page, like [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Special:Search?search=Bll&fulltext=1&cirrusUserTesting=recall_sidebar_results&searchToken=3bl5tft7q6drybsrcv68yjcdh this]. [[User:Fram|Fram]] ([[User talk:Fram|talk]]) 10:19, 14 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Proposed deletion of biographies of living people#rfc_05175D1|Wikipedia talk:Proposed deletion of biographies of living people]] expired 2017-05-15 05:01 ===
* Id: 05175D1
* User: J947
* Date: 2017-04-15 04:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|775482261|POLICY 775482261}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|780449053|POLICY 780449053}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I propose that articles with only references to the Internet Movie Database should still be eligible for BLPPROD. Looking at [[SP:NPF]], we've got a dead person with only an IMDb reference ([[Ken Parry]]), but a quick look doesn't show any living. However, even ''this month'' I have located some.

IMDb consists of user-generated content, which therefore poses risks that the person is a hoax or has information that is incorrect. IMDb is used as an external link in many articles, including quite a few that use it as an only source. IMDb is certainly not reliable, let alone good to be used as an only source. Those are reasons why I have placed this RfC up. If this gets accepted, then bot [[WT:TW|Twinkle]] and [[WT:PC|Page Curation]] should be notified. Additional options could include a short grandfather clause for current article affected, and an extended timeframe between the tagging and the deletion. '''<font color="#1009bf">[[User:J947|J]]</font><font color="#137412">[[User talk:J947|947]]</font>'''<sup><sup><sup>([[Special:Contributions/J947|c]])</sup></sup></sup> 04:46, 15 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Muhammad#rfc_F1E6D20|Talk:Muhammad]] expired 2017-05-15 06:01 ===
* Id: F1E6D20
* User: Vanamonde93
* Date: 2017-04-15 06:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|775491176|HIST 775491176}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|775491178|RELI 775491178}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|775491181|SOC 775491181}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|780453442|HIST 780453442}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|780453444|RELI 780453444}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|780453446|SOC 780453446}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{quote|'''Muhammad'''<ref group="n">[[Arabic name|Full name]]: '''Abū al-Qāsim Muḥammad ibn ʿAbd Allāh ibn ʿAbd al-Muṭṭalib ibn Hāshim''' ({{lang-ar|ابو القاسم محمد ابن عبد الله ابن عبد المطلب ابن هاشم}}, lit: Father of [[Qasim ibn Muhammad|Qasim]] Muhammad son of [[Abd Allah ibn Abd al Muttalib|Abd Allah]] son of [[Abdul-Muttalib]] son of [[Hashim ibn 'Abd Manaf|Hashim]])</ref> ({{lang-ar|محمد}}; {{IPA-ar|muħammad|pron}}; c.&nbsp;570 CE – 8 June 632 CE)<ref name=Goldman>Elizabeth Goldman (1995), p. 63, gives 8 June 632 CE, the dominant Islamic tradition. Many earlier (primarily non-Islamic) traditions refer to him as still alive at the time of the [[Muslim conquest of the Levant#Conquest of Palestine|invasion of Palestine]]. See Stephen J. Shoemaker,''The Death of a Prophet: The End of Muhammad's Life and the Beginnings of Islam,''{{page needed|date=August 2014}} University of Pennsylvania Press, 2011.</ref> is the prophet of [[Islam]] and widely identified as its founder by non-Muslims.<ref>{{Cite encyclopedia|authors=Buhl, F., Welch, A.T., Schimmel, Annemarie, Noth, A. and Ehlert, Trude | year= 2012 | title=Muḥammad |encyclopedia=Encyclopaedia of Islam| edition=2nd|publisher=Brill |editors=P. Bearman, Th. Bianquis, C.E. Bosworth, E. van Donzel, W.P. Heinrichs|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1163/1573-3912_islam_COM_0780|subscription=yes|quote=Muḥammad, the Prophet of Islam.| doi= 10.1163/1573-3912_islam_COM_0780 }}</ref><ref name=OEIW>{{cite encyclopedia|author=Alford T. Welch, Ahmad S. Moussalli, Gordon D. Newby|title=Muḥammad|encyclopedia=The Oxford Encyclopedia of the Islamic World|editor=John L. Esposito|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|year=2009|url=http://www.oxfordislamicstudies.com/article/opr/t236/e0550|quote=The Prophet of Islam was a religious, political, and social reformer who gave rise to one of the great civilizations of the world. From a modern, historical perspective, Muḥammad was the founder of Islam. From the perspective of the Islamic faith, he was God 's Messenger (rasūl Allāh), called to be a “warner,” first to the Arabs and then to all humankind.}}</ref> According to Islamic doctrine, he was God's Messenger (''rasūl Allāh'') sent to confirm the essential teachings of [[tawhid|monotheism]] preached previously by [[Adam in Islam|Adam]], [[Abraham in Islam|Abraham]], [[Moses in Islam|Moses]], [[Jesus in Islam|Jesus]], and other [[Prophets and messengers in Islam|prophets]].<ref name=OEIW/><ref>Esposito (2002b), pp. 4–5.</ref><ref>{{cite book|last= Peters|first= F.E.|title= Islam: A Guide for Jews and Christians|year=2003|publisher= Princeton University Press|isbn=0-691-11553-2|page=9}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last=Esposito|first=John|title= Islam: The Straight Path (3rd ed.)|year=1998|publisher =Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-511234-4|pages=9, 12}}</ref>}}

This is the [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Muhammad&oldid=775355198 current version (15 April 2017, UTC)] of the first two sentences of the article. Several editors, including myself, have expressed dissatisfaction over this formulation, although we are unable to agree on the precise issue. Some others are content with the current version. This RFC is an attempt to forge a consensus on some of the specific points of disagreement, which can then form a basis for a formulation which may or may not be different from the current version. This is intentionally ''not'' a proposal comparing several different versions. The issues are listed below; it would be helpful if folks commenting would express an opinion about each issue, as I have attempted to separate them as far as possible, though I recognize that they are linked. Given that this is a very important article, I am planning to request a formal closure once this has run its course: so I think it's fair to say that detailed opinions and reasoning will not be ignored. [[User:Vanamonde93|Vanamonde]] ([[User talk:Vanamonde93|talk]]) 06:01, 15 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Dismissal of James Comey#rfc_1B6C947|Talk:Dismissal of James Comey]] expired 2017-05-15 08:01 ===
* Id: 1B6C947
* User: Anythingyouwant
* Date: 2017-05-15 03:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|780444076|UNSORTED 780444076}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|780462222|UNSORTED 780462222}}
* RFC Text:

There has been lots of discussion over mentioning the name "Tuesday Night Massacre" in the article. It has been discussed in a few different places in different contexts (in fact some individuals attempted to use that phrase as an excuse to delete this article).

For the record: This phrase is widely used and notable. Certain individuals have attempted to purport that this is an obscure phrase that was invented by a random WP editor. However the widespread usage of this name has been well established:
* WP discussions:
** [[Wikipedia:Redirects_for_discussion/Log/2017_May_10#Tuesday_Night_Massacre Link deletion proposal]]
** [[Talk:Dismissal_of_James_Comey#.22Massacre.22]]
* Usage by the media:
** [http://www.jacksonsun.com/story/opinion/columnists/2017/05/13/trumps-totally-predictable-tuesday-night-massacre/319159001/ Jackson Sun] (May 13)
** [http://www.timesargus.com/articles/with-comey-gone-what-now/ Times Argus] (May 13)
** [https://www.usnews.com/opinion/op-ed/articles/2017-05-12/we-need-an-impeachment-investigation-after-donald-trump-fired-james-comey U.S. News] (May 12)
** [http://www.bostonherald.com/opinion/op_ed/2017/05/rachelle_cohen_fbi_chief_s_firing_flunks_the_smell_test Boston Herald] (May 11)
** [http://www.slate.com/articles/podcasts/gabfest/2017/05/comey_conservatism_under_trump_and_utah_on_the_political_gabfest.html Slate] (May 11)
** [http://nation.foxnews.com/2017/05/11/comeys-firing-rod-rosensteins-justice Fox News] (May 11)
** [https://www.wsj.com/articles/rod-rosensteins-justice-1494458376 Wall Street Journal] (May 10)
** [http://fortune.com/2017/05/09/comey-trump-tuesday-night-massacre/ Fortune] (May 9)
** [http://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/trump-s-tuesday-night-massacre-another-blow-for-american-democracy-1.3077960 The Irish Times]
** [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-05-09/five-things-you-need-to-know-to-start-your-day-j2i44nvw Bloomberg News]
** [http://www.mediaite.com/online/nixons-saturday-night-massacre-and-tuesdaynightmassacre-blow-up-on-twitter-after-comey-firing/ Mediate]
** [http://www.latimes.com/politics/washington/la-na-essential-washington-updates-for-the-second-time-since-trump-took-1494375627-htmlstory.html LA Times]
** [http://www.sfchronicle.com/opinion/editorials/article/Trump-s-Tuesday-night-massacre-11133931.php SF Chronicle]
** [http://www.philly.com/philly/blogs/attytood/Trumps-Tuesday-Night-Massacre-sends-US-teetering-toward-banana-republic-status.html Philadelphia Inquirer]
** [https://thelibertarianrepublic.com/tag/tuesday-night-massacre/], [http://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/trump-s-tuesday-night-massacre-another-blow-for-american-democracy-1.3077960], [https://www.ft.com/content/d7c8215c-3519-11e7-bce4-9023f8c0fd2e], , [https://democrats-judiciary.house.gov/news/press-releases/conyers-condemns-tuesday-night-massacre], [http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-05-10/trumps-tuesday-night-massacre:-president-trump/8514174], [http://mashable.com/2017/05/09/donald-trump-fbi-james-comey-nixon-tuesday-massacre/#wD48T5tlo5qB],  [http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2017/05/10/don-trump-s-does-his-best-dick-nixon-with-tuesday-night-massacre.html], [http://www.haaretz.com/us-news/.premium-1.788407], [http://www.rollcall.com/news/politics/fbi-director-james-comey-dismissed], [https://wonkette.com/tag/pt-tuesday-night-massacre], [http://humanitariannews.org/20170510/trumps-tuesday-night-massacre-puts-us-banana-republic-brink], [http://www.esquire.com/news-politics/news/a54994/trumps-tuesday-night-massacre-brings-the-nixon-comparisons-full-circle/], [http://www.nationalmemo.com/white-house-firing-comey/], [https://thinkprogress.org/tuesday-night-massacre-e850a1d11130]
* Discussions of trending in social media:
** [http://www.latimes.com/politics/washington/la-na-essential-washington-updates-for-the-second-time-since-trump-took-1494375627-htmlstory.html]
** [http://www.mediaite.com/online/nixons-saturday-night-massacre-and-tuesdaynightmassacre-blow-up-on-twitter-after-comey-firing/]
** [http://mashable.com/2017/05/09/donald-trump-fbi-james-comey-nixon-tuesday-massacre/#axUkpNAgt5qt]

Nevertheless, it seems there is an agenda by some individuals to continue trying to hide this name from Wikipedia.

-- MC

'''Survey'''

I am requesting feedback on the following question: "Should the article mention the name ''Tuesday Night Massacre'' in the lead section?" -- MC
*'''Mention it''' - The name ''Tuesday Night Massacre'' is widely used by the media and the general public. Whether or not this name is ''fair'' is irrelevant. Its notability is fact and hiding it is introducing deliberate bias. -- MC
*'''Nope, not in the lead section'''.  Your very first source is an opinion piece in the ''Jackson Sun''.  Opinion pieces are mere primary sources per [[WP:OR]], so you need to focus on reliable secondary sources to be persuasive here.  Per [[WP:OTHERNAMES]], "When this title is a name, significant alternative names for the topic should be mentioned in the article...."  The title of the present article is not a name, and therefore significant alternatives need not be mentioned, and surely should not be in bold.  Go ahead and mention this buzzword in the article body if you like.[[User:Anythingyouwant|&#32;Anythingyouwant]] ([[User talk:Anythingyouwant|talk]]) 03:01, 15 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_0B57CBF|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-05-15 11:01 ===
* Id: 0B57CBF
* Date: 2017-05-15 06:38:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|780462222|UNSORTED 780462222}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|780477894|UNSORTED 780477894}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
.
<br>'''Rationale''':--While the supporters of the proposal on a ''per-se'' basis have outvoted the opposers 2:1, the argument raised by the ''opposers'' make good points:--
*There is a valid concern that the results of enabling such a broad-scoped search contains content not suitable for the general audience. 
:But, that the ''multimedia'' search is not included in a ''general search'' seems to somewhat allay the fears.
*It's a fact that there exists  a massive difference between guidelines followed across different sites.For an example--policies dealing with violation of copyrights are quite strong at en.wiki and is strictly enforced but standards and implementation of the same varies widely across sister-wikis.
:No ''satisfiable answer'' has been posed regarding redressal of the above question.
Overall, the staus for implementation of the ''cross-wiki search'' on a per-project basis is as follows:--
*'''Commons'''--[[WP:SNOW|Snow]] '''oppose'''.<small>The lesser said, the better!</small> Primarily due to NSFW content  and fair use images.
*'''Wikibooks'''--Strong consensus to '''oppose'''.Almost every work is seemingly incomplete.A garble of poorly thought out info at best!
*'''Wikinews'''--Near [[WP:SNOW|Snow]] '''oppose'''.Primarily a failed project with heavily outdated content.
*'''Wikiquote'''--Strong consensus to '''support''' inclusion.Still, concerns of copy-vio remain.
*'''Wikisource'''--[[WP:SNOW|Snow]] '''support''' for inclusion.Search-results ought to be improved.
*'''Wikiversity'''--[[WP:SNOW|Snow]] '''oppose'''.Violates core policy of [[WP:OR|no original research]].
*'''Wikivoyage'''--Strong consensus to '''support''' inclusion on conditions of only {{tq|exact title match}}-es appearing on a search.
*'''Wiktionary'''--[[WP:SNOW|Snow]] '''support''' for inclusion.
*'''Wikispecies/Wikidata'''--Clarified by WMF to be not under the purview of the project.
Signed by-[[User:Winged Blades of Godric|<span style= "color:green">''Winged Blades''</span>]]<sup>[[User  talk:Winged Blades of Godric| Godric]]</sup>  06:38, 15 May 2017 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_7E1DDFE|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-05-15 11:01 ===
* Id: 7E1DDFE
* User: Piotrus
* Date: 2017-04-18 07:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|780462222|UNSORTED 780462222}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|780477894|UNSORTED 780477894}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
== The criteria of [[WP:NSPORT]] here are too inclusive '''

{{User:ClueBot III/DoNotArchiveUntil|1808442053}}
Why is a substub like [[Magdalena Zamolska]] encyclopedic? Because [[WP:NCYCLING]]. I don't agree that participating in some competitions, without winning, or generating any coverage but a mention in the list of participants should suffice. Who decided those and similar exceptions to [[WP:BIO]]? [https://blog.wikimedia.org/2016/01/29/research-newsletter-january-2016/#cite_note-3 Current research] shows that 30-40% of biographies in Wikiepdia are of sportspeople. Most of them are substubs like this, people who did nothing except participate in events. Participation should not be sufficient to be in an encyclopedia; we are turning into a sport stat site. I am hoping the discussion here would be more representative of our community's thoughts than one that could happen at the sports notability talk page (where I'll of course leave a ping). --<sub style="border:1px solid #228B22;padding:1px;">[[User:Piotrus|Piotr Konieczny aka Prokonsul Piotrus]]&#124;[[User talk:Piotrus|<font style="color:#7CFC00;background:#006400;"> reply here</font>]]</sub> 07:55, 18 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Nazism sidebar#rfc_E8C2BF5|Template talk:Nazism sidebar]] expired 2017-05-15 16:01 ===
* Id: E8C2BF5
* User: Director
* Date: 2017-05-10 13:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|779705573|HIST 779705573}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|780513895|HIST 780513895}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Proposing we restore the previous consensus symbol (the 90 or 100px swastika). Or a framed swastika symbol:
<center>[[File:National Socialist swastika (framed in red).svg|90px|26B]] [[File:National Socialist swastika.svg|90px|Nazi Swastika|]]</center>
I call them '''Option 26a''' and '''Option 37-9.''' I don't like the current tiny icon:
*Firstly, its a ''flag'' representation. In terms of simple semiotics, we should use an emblem in this context if possible.
*Secondly, its ridiculously small. I myself can just barely make it out on my work computer. (Maybe I'm getting old, but even if so lets not be ageist on our project ;))
*Thirdly, that was the flag of ''Germany'' between 1933-35. It represents a country first and foremost.
*Ignoring that, its also a flag of the ''German'' Nazi Party. There's plenty other Nazi fistmagnets, both historically and right now.
I started messing around with the image here in ages past, and I'm really sorry for that. I think we should just stop and leave it be. I don't understand what arguments prompted folks to just slap the German flag onto there, but I can't express how weird I find the current state of affairs. Thanks for your time, and again, apologies for opening this up... but this little tiny flag thing just looks terrible to me, as well as objectively inappropriate. <font face="Eras Bold ITC">-- [[User:Director|<span style="color:#353535">Director</span>]] <span style="color:#464646">([[User talk:Director|<span style="color:#464646">talk</span>]])</span></font> 13:15, 10 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (miscellaneous)#rfc_2853A42|Wikipedia:Village pump (miscellaneous)]] expired 2017-05-16 03:01 ===
* Id: 2853A42
* User: PBS
* Date: 2017-05-06 13:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|779011950|HIST 779011950}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|779011954|POL 779011954}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|780600209|HIST 780600209}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|780600211|POL 780600211}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There are a [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?search=Birthday+Honours&title=Special:Search&fulltext=1&searchToken=azikq1xz971b9agr6ju7g2jgh lots of articles] that are Birthday Honours lists. 

Taking two as examples 100 years apart:
*[[1908 Birthday Honours]]
*[[2008 Birthday Honours]]

;They are  copies of the information contained in the [[London Gazette]]:
*1908:
**{{London Gazette |issue=28151 |startpage=4641 |endpage=4648 |supp=y |date=23 June 1908|ref=none}}
2008:
**{{London Gazette |issue=58729 |date=14 June 2008 |startpage=1 |endpage=28 |supp=1 |ref=none}}
** New Zealand:[http://www.dia.govt.nz/MSOS118/On-Line/NZGazette.nsf/6cee7698a9bbc7cfcc256d510059ed0b/0214ea3894106ddbcc257467004d0a83!OpenDocument "The Queen's Birthday Honours 2008"] (11 June 2008) 94 ''[[New Zealand Gazette]] 2561. (used to support a NZ section) 

;Not composite lists:
These lists are different from lists like those of the High Sheriffs eg: [[High Sheriff of Surrey]] that have been created by extracting one line of information from lots of different issues of the London Gazette among other sources, because a Birthday Honours list copy the structure of the Gazette birthday honours list as well as its content.

;Not articles with analysis:
These lists which are laid out nearly identical to the Gazette lists. They are not part of articles where there is an analysis of what is specifically in the list that is different from other similar lists. Eg analysis like this:
{{quote|The first BHL under the New Labour government of 2023 saw a decrease in the number of honours going to members of City firms and an increase in those going to member of the NHS (reliable source). ...
}}  
The [[1920 Birthday Honours]] list/article does not mention the [[Maundy Gregory#Selling honours|selling of honours]] scandal (see [[Honours (Prevention of Abuses) Act 1925]]), nor does the [[2006 Birthday Honours]] list mention the [[Cash for Honours]] scandal (at the time I am writing this note even in a ''See also'' section).  

;What can be done to improve them?
Given the tone of [[Wikipedia:What Wikipedia is not]] and some of its specific comments in it, ought these Birthday Honour Lists (BHLs) be on Wikiepdia, or should the content be moved onto [[Wikisource]]? If they are not to be moved, what can be done to improve them?

-- [[User:PBS|PBS]] ([[User talk:PBS|talk]]) 13:15, 6 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Controversial Reddit communities#rfc_A8AC9E5|Talk:Controversial Reddit communities]] expired 2017-05-16 06:01 ===

Should the "ShitRedditSays" subreddit be included on the list of Controversial Reddit Communities? === [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Songs#rfc_8AB41BB|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Songs]] expired 2017-05-16 17:01 ===
* Id: 8AB41BB
* User: Ilovetopaint
* Date: 2017-05-10 13:50:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|779713275|MEDIA 779713275}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|779713280|SOC 779713280}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|779713282|TECH 779713282}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|779728183|PROP 779728183}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|780693851|MEDIA 780693851}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|780693853|SOC 780693853}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|780693857|STYLE 780693857}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|780693861|TECH 780693861}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|780693865|PROP 780693865}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In the [[#RfC: Should Infobox single and Infobox song be merged?|last RFC, which ended with a consensus to merge Infobox song and Infobox single]], there was discussion about creating a merged album/track/single infobox ({{Template|Infobox sound recording}}) as a contrast to {{Template|Infobox musical composition}}, which is used for traditional songs and classical pieces.

With regards to the separation of Infobox album and Infobox song, two significant points were raised:
* Singles are not defined as "single songs" — they may consist of multiple tracks, just like an album or EP.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jones|first=M.|title=The Music Industries: From Conception to Consumption|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mxkjIcNVhG4C|year=2012|isbn=978-1-137-02706-1|quote=As of [2011] a single has become defined as 'a Record containing not more than 4 tracks' where a 'track' is defined as 'a Recording which reproduces 1 Title whose playing time is not less than 2½ minutes when played at its correct speed}}</ref>
* Both infoboxes share most parameters, just like {{Template|Infobox song}} and {{Template|Infobox single}}: Name, Cover, Caption, Artist, Released, Recorded, Studio, Venue, Genre, Length, Label, and Producer.

'''Note:''' This RfC is purely for consolidating the two templates, not removing one in favor of the other. If the elements that are exclusive to Albums (just three or four parameters) were added to the Songs infobox, there would be no perceptible changes, as in, readers wouldn't notice if Album was redirected to Songs. --[[User:Ilovetopaint|Ilovetopaint]] ([[User talk:Ilovetopaint|talk]]) 13:50, 10 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Non-free content#rfc_2B129DF|Wikipedia talk:Non-free content]] expired 2017-05-17 04:01 ===
* Id: 2B129DF
* User: George Ho
* Date: 2017-05-06 19:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|779059199|POLICY 779059199}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|779059200|PROP 779059200}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|780777423|POLICY 780777423}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|780777426|PROP 780777426}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The current rule about images of deceased persons is:<blockquote>10. '''Pictures of deceased persons, in articles about that person, provided that ever obtaining a free close substitute is not reasonably likely'''. Note that in the case the image is from a press agency or photo agency (e.g., AP, Corbis or Getty Images) and is not itself the subject of critical commentary it is assumed automatically to fail "respect for commercial opportunity".</blockquote>

Seeking a free image of a person has been encouraged. However, the appropriate time to upload a non-free image of a deceased person has not yet been decided. Also, the above rule lacks a supplement <u>or footnote</u>. Which proposal do you support or oppose as the supplement <u>or footnote</u> to the above rule? Why or why not? If you support a proposal but do not agree with its suggested waiting time period, what do you suggest is the best waiting time to upload an acceptable non-free image of a deceased person? If you support neither of the existing proposals, what is your alternative proposal? See more background at "[[Wikipedia talk:Non-free content#Criteria needed for using images of deceased persons?]]" --[[User:George Ho|George Ho]] ([[User talk:George Ho|talk]]) 19:16, 6 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Notability (organizations and companies)#rfc_37F1F5C|Wikipedia talk:Notability (organizations and companies)]] expired 2017-05-17 16:01 ===
* Id: 37F1F5C
* User: SL93
* Date: 2017-04-21 20:06:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|776579012|POLICY 776579012}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|780855850|POLICY 780855850}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I'm participating in an AfD for a publishing company right now and there are several keep votes that are based around the company being notable for publishing notable works. Right now, [[WP:CORP]] says no such thing. My belief is that while authors can be notable for their works per [[WP:AUTHOR]], the publishing company should not have that notability. They didn't research the work or write the work. The company merely published the work. [[WP:CORP]] should be changed if I'm wrong. [[User:SL93|SL93]] ([[User talk:SL93|talk]]) 20:06, 21 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#rfc_D9EAB15|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style]] expired 2017-05-17 23:01 ===
* Id: D9EAB15
* User: Flyer22 Reborn
* Date: 2017-04-17 22:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|775932116|POLICY 775932116}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|780855850|POLICY 780855850}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
One view is that the [[WP:ANDOR]] guideline is too restrictive because there are some instances where using "and/or" is the better and less cumbersome or less awkward option. Editors have noted that stating "and/or" can be more concise and less awkward than stating "[that], [that], or both," or some more elaborate construction. There is the argument that the guideline beginning with "avoid" is usually interpreted to mean "don't ever" when it comes to applying "and/or," and that this has resulted in an unofficial ban on "and/or" on Wikipedia. It has also been noted that the guideline is sometimes interpreted as applying to quotes as well, despite what [[MOS:QUOTES]] states about not usually tampering with quotes. The other view is that the guideline is fine as is, and that "avoid" doesn't mean "never." This view argues that "and/or" should usually be avoided or is rarely needed. This view argues that most and/or constructions can be easily rewritten. If someone is applying the guideline too strictly, then it's a matter that can be worked out on the article's talk page, or handled at an appropriate forum like [[WP:ANI]]. To resolve the dispute with the guideline, softening the guideline to begin with "Avoid unless," instead of "Avoid," has been proposed. One suggestion has been to change the initial wording to the following wording: "Avoid writing {{xt|and/or}} unless ambiguity would result or unless other constructions would be too lengthy or awkward."   

Do you support or oppose softening the WP:ANDOR guideline? And why? For those viewing this from the RfC page or from an alert on their talk page, see [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#The WP:ANDOR guideline|the initial main discussion above for further detail]]. As noted above, a number of Wikipedia pages will be alerted to this RfC since this RfC affects Wikipedia on a wide-scale level. [[User:Flyer22 Reborn|Flyer22 Reborn]] ([[User talk:Flyer22 Reborn|talk]]) 22:32, 17 April 2017 (UTC)}}
