=== [[Template talk:Link language#rfc_999F433|Template talk:Link language]] expired 2017-05-18 06:01 ===
* Id: 999F433
* Date: 2017-04-18 06:00:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|775975560|STYLE 775975560}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|786047166|STYLE 786047166}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This template, so far as I know, is only used in foreign-language external links. It displays the language in some kind of arbitrary gray, bold and slightly smaller style, e.g. "{{#ifexist:Template:ISO 639 name fr
 |<span class="languageicon" style="font-size:0.95em; font-weight:bold; color:#555;">({{ISO 639 name fr}})</span>{{category handler
  |main={{#ifeq:fr|en||[[Category:Articles with {{ISO 639 name fr}}-language external links]]}}
 }}
 |{{error|Invalid language code.}}
}}". This is in contrast with all [[Template:Cite_web#Foreign_language_and_translated_title|other cite templates]], which simply display, in non-formatted text, "(in French)".

I suggest that this template is made consistent in style with the more widely used (and more sober) style of the cite templates. Judging from the comments and discussions referenced above, other people have expressed the same concern.

More specifically, I suggest that the span part of the template be changed to

<blockquote><nowiki>
<span class="languageicon">(in {{ISO 639 name {{{1}}}}})</span>
</nowiki></blockquote>

That is, the style attribute should be removed, and "in " should be added within the brackets. Thanks. 06:00, 18 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of unusual deaths#rfc_913477F|Talk:List of unusual deaths]] expired 2017-05-18 16:01 ===
* Id: 913477F
* User: Usernamekiran
* Date: 2017-05-18 04:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|780953105|UNSORTED 780953105}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|781018812|UNSORTED 781018812}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Topic of this RfC: complete removal of "death of Isadora Duncan (1927)".<br />
Lead section of this article states:


{{quote|This is a list of unusual deaths. This list includes only unique or extremely rare circumstances of death recorded throughout history, noted as being unusual by multiple sources. Note: some of the deaths are mythological or are considered to be unsubstantiated by contemporary researchers. Oxford Dictionaries defines the word "unusual" as "not habitually or commonly occurring or done" and "remarkable or interesting because different from or better than others."}}


A few days ago, I made [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_unusual_deaths&diff=779739120 this edit.] Even though not "noted as being unusual by multiple source", there are way too many similar deaths in Indian subcontinent; making Duncan's death usual. Hence, i think it will be appropriate to remove Duncan's death completely from the article. One can see the citations provided there in the diff, and a few examples are provided below (all [[WP:RS]]). 2-3 sources may cause disturbance by graphics : <br />
;Scientific studies:
*https://www.researchgate.net/publication/240310638_An_accidental_death_due_to_electric_grinder_Dupatta_as_a_strangulation_hazard
*http://www.mlam.in/pdf/Fatal%20Long%20scarf%20syndrome%20-%20A%20case%20report%20of%20unusual%20cause%20of%20death.pdf
*http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1008127517300664

;New articles regarding deaths: 

(Some of the news articles might be repeated somewhere)
*The deaths I am providing sources to, are only from India. And as per this source it is very common in India.<ref>http://zeenews.india.com/news/videos/dna/dna-aiims-issues-warning-about-strangulation-by-dupattas-and-saris-causing-death_1975405.html</ref>. These deaths include but not limited to:
*the drape/scarf getting stuck in wheel of vehichle or some other sort of machinery, and working as a noose.
*drape getting stuck in fast rotating wheel, thus giving violent jerk to neck, and breaking it. Death caused by broken neck, not by strangulation.
*drape getting stuck in wheel, victim falling down, death by blunt force trauma tomthe head from the fall. [http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/pune/School-bus-runs-over-17-year-old-girl/articleshow/51802934.cms] Kindly look second news deah of Pratibha Rajendra Bhosale.
*[http://m.mid-day.com/articles/woman-dies-as-dupatta-gets-stuck-in-bike-but-manages-to-save-baby/16478183 being dragged by vehicle, death by strangulation] on mid-day.
*drape getting stuck in rotating wheel, pulling the victim down. Death by victim's vehichle, or some other vehichle running over victim.


*http://www.deccanherald.com/content/455110/young-girl-chokes-death-dupatta.html
*http://indiatoday.intoday.in/story/woman-dies-after-scarf-gets-stuck-in-escalator/1/340865.html
*http://www.dnaindia.com/india/report-11-year-old-dies-while-playing-swing-with-mom-s-dupatta-2136577


{{quote|Experts at the institute said that in the past 5-6 years, they have witnessed about 30-40 cases where women were accidentally strangled by drapes getting caught in motorcycles, scooters, mixers, table fans, rickshaws and factory equipment. Not just women, even men wearing mufflers and shawls have been strangled in freak accidents, AIIMS forensic experts said.<ref>http://zeenews.india.com/news/videos/dna/dna-aiims-issues-warning-about-strangulation-by-dupattas-and-saris-causing-death_1975405.html</ref>}}


In the light of these recent events of last 100 years, I think Duncan's death should be removed from this article now. If you think there is lack of sources, you will find some more sources in the section above. If you doubt me, or the sources I provided; then kindly search on internet for them.

On the reasoning/sources provided above, kindly provide your comments if death of Isadora Duncan should remain ('''KEEP'''), or should it be removed ('''DELETE''')?

Thank you. —<span style="font-size: 105%; letter-spacing:2pt;"><span style="font-family: monospace, monospace;">usernamekiran[[User talk:Usernamekiran|<span style="letter-spacing:1pt;">'''(talk)'''</span>]]</span></span> 04:32, 18 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Professional Super Smash Bros. competition#rfc_BBA0D4E|Talk:Professional Super Smash Bros. competition]] expired 2017-05-19 16:01 ===
* Id: BBA0D4E
* User: Izno
* Date: 2017-04-19 19:01:00

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|776238912|SOC 776238912}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|781179772|SOC 781179772}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Presently, the material in the [[Professional Super Smash Bros. competition#Tier list|tier list section]], the [[Professional Super Smash Bros. competition#Rankings|rankings section]], and in the [[Professional Super Smash Bros. competition#List of largest Super Smash Bros. tournaments|largest tournaments section]] is not [[WP:V|verified]] by [[WP:RS|reliable, secondary sources]] such that the [[WP:WEIGHT|correct weight of those topics is assigned to these sections]]. The users defending their inclusion [[WP:BURDEN|have not provided the necessary reliable sources]]. A previous discussion began at [[#This page is way too long]] and continued in [[#Clean up]] was not conclusive but appears to indicate that the material should indeed be removed (based on the above-cited policies and guidelines).

Should the content continue to exist as it does in the article at present, or should it be removed until such time as reliable, secondary sources are available? --[[User:Izno|Izno]] ([[User talk:Izno|talk]]) 19:01, 19 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Intercommunal conflict in Mandatory Palestine#rfc_714D2E8|Talk:Intercommunal conflict in Mandatory Palestine]] expired 2017-05-19 17:01 ===
* Id: 714D2E8
* User: Oncenawhile
* Date: 2017-04-19 16:31:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|776212571|HIST 776212571}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|781187300|HIST 781187300}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In 2014, this article was moved without discussion [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Intercommunal_conflict_in_Mandatory_Palestine&diff=597115120&oldid=579777024] from its original title: "[[Zionist and Palestinian Arab attitudes before 1948]]." However, in the intervening three years, little to nothing has been done to fix the fact that 60% of the article -i.e. sections 1, 2 and 3 - are not written in a manner which adequately introduces the subject of "Intercommunal conflict in Mandatory Palestine".

As a result, I propose that the first three sections are slimmed down, with the bulk of the content merged into [[History of Zionism]] and [[Palestinian nationalism]]. Sections 4 and 5 then remain as they are, and form the core of this article.

[[User:Oncenawhile|Oncenawhile]] ([[User talk:Oncenawhile|talk]]) 16:31, 19 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Plummer v. State#rfc_AE8A161|Talk:Plummer v. State]] expired 2017-05-20 17:01 ===
* Id: AE8A161
* User: GregJackP
* Date: 2017-04-20 16:43:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|776386203|POL 776386203}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|781341865|POL 781341865}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the Internet meme section of the article be replaced with the following (between the three dash line on top and bottom):
law
---

''Plummer v. State'', along with ''[[Bad Elk v. United States]]'',<ref>''Bad Elk v. United States'', 177 U.S. 529 (1900).</ref> is cited in Internet blogs and discussion groups but often misquoted.<ref>Robery Cubby, ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20150918181948/http://www.lawenforcementtoday.com/2014/12/10/the-right-to-resist-an-unlawful-arrest/ The Right to Resist An Unlawful Arrest]'', {{Smallcaps|Law Enforcement Today}} (Dec. 10, 2014) (archived from the [http://www.lawenforcementtoday.com/2014/12/10/the-right-to-resist-an-unlawful-arrest/ original]).</ref> The misquote is that "“citizens may resist unlawful arrest to the point of taking an arresting officer’s life if necessary"<ref>Cubby (citing Paul Markel, ''[http://www.theblaze.com/contributions/do-you-have-the-right-to-resist-an-unlawful-arrest-2/ Do You Have the Right to Resist an Unlawful Arrest?]'' {{Smallcaps|The Blaze}} (May 9, 2014)).</ref> although the ''Plummer'' quotation is a fabrication because the quoted text does not appear in the text of the ''Plummer'' opinion.<ref>Cubby.</ref> Several other sources note that ''Bad Elk'' is no longer good law,<ref>Scott H. Greenfield, ''[http://blog.simplejustice.us/2013/02/21/bored-or-crazy-theyre-us/ Bored or Crazy, They're Us]'', {{smallcaps|Simple Justice}} (Feb. 21, 2013); Scott H. Greenfield, ''[https://blog.simplejustice.us/2013/05/21/taser-joe-martinez-meets-the-line/ “Taser Joe” Martinez Meets The Line]'', {{smallcaps|Simple Justice}} (May 21, 2013); ''see also'' Richard G. Kopf, ''[https://herculesandtheumpire.com/2014/08/16/swisher-sweets/ Swisher Sweets]'', {{smallcaps|Hercules and the Umpire}} (Aug. 16, 2014) (U.S. District Judge Kopf and several attorneys discuss ''Bad Elk'' in the comments).</ref> what one legal commenter stated was a "bizarre, irrational or merely grossly wrong understanding of law...."<ref>Scott H. Greenfield, ''[https://blog.simplejustice.us/2013/09/16/curb-your-catharsis/ Curb Your Catharsis]'', {{smallcaps|Simple Justice}} (Sep. 16, 2013).</ref> Modern sources describe ''Plummer'' and ''Bad Elk'' as applying when there is an unlawful use of force rather than when there is an unlawful arrest; under contemporary law in the majority of U.S. jurisdictions, a person may not use force to resist an unlawful arrest.<ref>Andrew P. Wright, ''Resisting Unlawful Arrests: Inviting Anarchy or Protecting Individual Freedom?'' 46 {{smallcaps|Drake L. Rev.}} 383, 387-88 (1997) (covering the common law rule, but noting that as of publication, 36 of the 50 states prohibited resisting unlawful arrests); ''see generally'' Darrell A.H. Miller, ''[http://www.repository.law.indiana.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1014&context=ilj Retail Rebellion and the Second Amendment]'' 86 {{smallcaps|Ind. L.J.}} 939, 953 (2011).</ref>

{{reflist-talk}}

--- </br>
The above was revised based on comments from the initial RfC before I withdrew it to revise it based on the comments by the community. <span style="border:1px solid #900;padding:2px;background:#fffff4">[[User:GregJackP|<span style="color:#900;font-size:110%;font-family:Mistral">GregJackP</span>]]&nbsp;[[User talk:GregJackP|<span style="color:#900;font-size:60%">Boomer!</span>]]</span>  16:43, 20 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:First Cameron ministry#rfc_835AC01|Talk:First Cameron ministry]] expired 2017-05-21 19:01 ===
* Id: 835AC01
* User: Neve-selbert
* Date: 2017-04-21 18:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|776556985|HIST 776556985}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|776556986|POL 776556986}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|776556992|SOC 776556992}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|781521025|HIST 781521025}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|781521028|POL 781521028}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|781521032|SOC 781521032}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Debate has been raging over whether or not the title of this article is adequate for several years now. Most discussants have opposed the status quo in the past, mostly due to a lack of reliable sources supporting it and the fact that it's not the common name for the subject. The trouble is that editors have found it difficult to agree on a better name for this article. I proposed ''Cameron&ndash;Clegg coalition'' above, yet support for it failed to gain much traction. Indeed, the RM itself was mostly ignored until a couple of days ago. Nevertheless, I do believe there is consensus to rename this article, but rename it to what remains an open question. Here are a few alternatives that have been put forth, which all abide by the guidelines set out at [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Politics of the United Kingdom/Ministries]]:
{{colbegin}}
* ''Cameron coalition ministry''
** [https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&q=%22Cameron+coalition+ministry%22 Practically 0 results]
* ''Cameron&ndash;Clegg coalition''
** [https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&q=%22Cameron+Clegg+coalition%22 About 472 results]
* ''Cameron&ndash;Clegg coalition ministry''
** [https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&q=%22Cameron+Clegg+coalition+ministry%22 No results found]
* ''Cameron&ndash;Clegg ministry''
** [https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&q=%22Cameron+Clegg+ministry%22 Practically 0 results]
{{colend}}
I have stated the case as to why I believe ''Cameron&ndash;Clegg coalition'', given its popularity among reliable sources.--[[User:Neve-selbert|Nev&eacute;]][[Special:Contributions/Neve-selbert|&ndash;]][[User talk:Neve-selbert|selbert]] 18:18, 21 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Six-Day War#rfc_0E56426|Talk:Six-Day War]] expired 2017-05-22 07:01 ===
* Id: 0E56426
* User: Oncenawhile
* Date: 2017-04-22 06:32:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|776655388|HIST 776655388}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|781608701|HIST 781608701}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The above sentence in the lead was written [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Six-Day_War&diff=prev&oldid=634654862][https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Six-Day_War&diff=635019165&oldid=634978950] without discussion at the end of 2014.

It is the single most important topic that scholars have argued about non-stop for 50 years. Yet our sentence shows only one side of the debate. The words "in reaction to" and "preemptive" are the Israeli justification. They should not be written in Wikipedia's neutral voice, and the other side of the debate should be noted in the lead.

For those less familiar with the topic, the other (opposite) scholarly perspective is that Israel had coveted Jerusalem ever since the 1948 war (this is undisputed), that Israeli intelligence knew that Jordan had a military treaty with Egypt and that Egypt's actions were chest beating without an intention to attack Israel, and that Israel took the opportunity to launch a war of conquest while blaming the other side for having started it. This is covered in the article [[Controversies relating to the Six-Day War]].

There was significant discussion of this topic many years ago at [[/Archive 5]] and [[/Archive 9]]. For example, the threads: [[Talk:Six-Day_War/Archive_5#Do_we_need_to_qualify_the_statement_.22Israel_launched_a_pre-emptive_attack.22_in_order_to_conform_to_NPOV.3F|Do we need to qualify the statement "Israel launched a pre-emptive attack" in order to conform to NPOV?]] in July 2010 which had 8 votes to 2 in a debate over whether "preemptive" required a qualifier, and [[Talk:Six-Day_War/Archive_9#recent_revert|recent revert]] in March 2012 on a similar debate.

[[User:Oncenawhile|Oncenawhile]] ([[User talk:Oncenawhile|talk]]) 06:32, 22 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:W56#rfc_B6EC3F9|Talk:W56]] expired 2017-05-23 02:01 ===
* Id: B6EC3F9
* User: Vfrickey
* Date: 2017-04-23 01:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|776461757|HIST 776461757}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|776461763|SCI 776461763}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|776461767|POL 776461767}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|781758752|HIST 781758752}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|781758756|SCI 781758756}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|781758758|POL 781758758}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 

At least one undisputed and one potential concern with source reliability exist in our article [[W56]] in the last sentence: "One warhead, owing to its use of high performance but high sensitivity PBX nearly experienced a high-explosive detonation with no nuclear yield in 2005 because an unsafe amount of pressure was applied to the non-insensitive high explosive while it was being disassembled.[3]".   More sources of information on the "W56 mishap" exist, one of which refers to the nuclear detonation hazard and to statements made by workers at the plant where W56 mishap happened.  Which of these sources should be used to provide more nearly accurate coverage of this notable mishap, a danger common to all W56 warheads?. Thanks in advance! [[User:Vfrickey|loupgarous]] ([[User talk:Vfrickey|talk]]) 01:26, 23 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Universal Monsters (2017 film series)#rfc_74378C5|Talk:Universal Monsters (2017 film series)]] expired 2017-05-23 04:01 ===
* Id: 74378C5
* User: 50.232.205.246
* Date: 2017-04-29 16:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|777843746|MEDIA 777843746}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|781770858|MEDIA 781770858}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The page is currently titled "Universal Monsters (2017 film series)". Some editors feel as though the title will suffice until an official title to the franchise is released. Others believe that the page's title is inaccurate, since as one film will be released in 2017, which is ''The Mummy''. A title change to '''Universal Monsters (shared universe)''', or '''Universal Monsters Universe''' is proposed.
--[[Special:Contributions/50.232.205.246|50.232.205.246]] ([[User talk:50.232.205.246|talk]]) 16:18, 29 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Menstrual disc#rfc_A1B2C72|Talk:Menstrual disc]] expired 2017-05-24 02:01 ===
* Id: A1B2C72
* User: Lmschulte
* Date: 2017-04-24 01:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|779176297|SCI 779176297}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|781933561|SCI 781933561}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The menstrual cup page states several facts which are not true of menstrual discs. Specifically, the menstrual cup page states that (the following are verbatim quotes as of the time of this posting):

* A menstrual cup is a type of feminine hygiene product which is usually made of '''medical grade silicone''', shaped like a bell and is flexible. [emphasis added]<ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menstrual_cup]</ref>
* Manufacturers have different recommendations for when to replace the cups, but in general they can be '''reused for five years or more'''. [emphasis added]<ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menstrual_cup]</ref>
* It is '''reusable''' and '''designed to last for up to 10 years'''.  [emphasis added]<ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menstrual_cup#Types]</ref> 
* After about 4–12 hours of use (depending on the amount of flow), the cup is removed by '''reaching up to the stem of the cup''' in order to find the base. [emphasis added] <ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menstrual_cup#Use]</ref>
* Menstrual cups '''must be removed before penetrative vaginal sex'''. [emphasis added] <ref>[https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Menstrual_cup#Use]</ref>
* This is not a quote, but the menstrual cup page uses this graphic to show that this is how a cup is inserted: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Menstrual_cup_inserted.png/220px-Menstrual_cup_inserted.png

This independent, 3rd-party source states the following about menstrual discs: http://online.liebertpub.com/doi/pdfplus/10.1089/jwh.2009.1929 The source calls Softcup, a menstrual disc brand, a "menstrual cup", which is the biggest point of confusion, but goes on to state the following facts (the following are verbatim quotes from the source):

* The Softcup (Instead, Inc., San Diego, CA) is a simple single-size '''disposable''' over-thecounter (OTC) menstrual cup that compresses to tampon shape to facilitate insertion and '''can be worn during coitus'''. [emphasis added]
* Because the Softcup is aligned along the long axis of the vagina, '''intercourse can take place''' below the cup, avoiding contact with the rim and minimizing risk of displacement. [emphasis added]
* It is composed of a '''proprietary blend of soft biocompatible polymer compounds''' in conformance with the United States Pharmacopoeia XIX Class VI criteria for plastics [emphasis added]
* Once inserted, it opens to an oval shape, '''positioned between the posterior fornix and the notch behind the pubic bone''', covering the cervix. [emphasis added]
*  Removal is accomplished by '''hooking a finger over the rim''' behind the pubic bone. [emphasis added]

The last two facts about insertion and removal contradict the graphic shown on the menstrual cup page on insertion. The graphic in fact shows the menstrual cup sitting in the vaginal canal not the vaginal fornix -- it does not touch the pubic bone at all.

Page 3 of the above source also shows an image of a menstrual disc. The disc does not have a stem like menstrual cups.

Signed,
[[User:Lmschulte|Lmschulte]] ([[User talk:Lmschulte|talk]]) 01:35, 24 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Military history#rfc_F22E451|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Military history]] expired 2017-05-24 16:01 ===
* Id: F22E451
* User: Necrothesp
* Date: 2017-04-24 15:33:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|776990323|BIO 776990323}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|776990326|HIST 776990326}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|782035738|BIO 782035738}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|782035741|HIST 782035741}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In the past, we have kept articles on flying aces simply because they were flying aces. [[:Category:British World War I flying aces]] illustrates perfectly how many articles exist simply for this reason; most of these 481 gentlemen would not qualify for articles for any reason other than their status as an ace. Recently two articles on German airmen have been nominated for deletion on the basis that the criteria on [[WP:SOLDIER]] do not include being an ace: [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Hugo Broch]] and [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Erich Handke]]. The latter is unusual in that he was not a pilot, but a radar operator, a member of a two-man crew of a night fighter. Instead of individual aces being nominated at AfD and separate discussions being had for each, it would obviously be more appropriate if we could have a more general discussion as to whether or not being a flying ace gives one inherent notability, as this has certainly been claimed in the past. So, I pose the question:
:Should holding the status of [[flying ace]] (generally accepted as having five or more aerial victories) be generally considered to give a presumption of notability for the purposes of [[WP:SOLDIER]]? And if so, do the 'back-seat' crew (i.e. those not flying as pilots) in two-man fighter aircraft qualify as aces if they have shared in at least five victories? -- [[User:Necrothesp|Necrothesp]] ([[User talk:Necrothesp|talk]]) 15:33, 24 April 2017 (UTC)}}


=== [[Talk:Sheela Murthy#rfc_8F4949B|Talk:Sheela Murthy]] expired 2017-05-24 16:01 ===
* Id: 8F4949B
* User: JoelWhy#top
* Date: 2017-04-24 15:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|777363803|BIO 777363803}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|782035738|BIO 782035738}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There are articles about Sheela Murthy in the New York Times, MSN Money, The Baltimore Sun, The Economic Times, Business Monthly, and The Hindu (among many others.) To be clear - these are articles about her and her work (as opposed to articles that merely quote her while she discusses immigration issues.) Please review the [[Wikipedia:Notability]] standards. She clearly meets these standards.

As for reading like an advert, feel free to make edits and changes as necessary. When I wrote this entry, because I have a [[Wikipedia:Conflict of interest|conflict of interest]], I purposely had it reviewed by an independent third-party editor. (See the history in talk.) But, if you have any specific examples of suggested changes that should be made, please suggest away (or simply make the changes.)    [[User:JoelWhy|<font color="red">Joel</font><font color="blue">Why?</font>]]([[User talk:JoelWhy#top|talk]]) 15:20, 24 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Noël Coward#rfc_8119C9F|Talk:Noël Coward]] expired 2017-05-24 19:01 ===
* Id: 8119C9F
* User: Coretheapple
* Date: 2017-04-24 18:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|777017025|BIO 777017025}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|777017027|HIST 777017027}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|782062551|BIO 782062551}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|782062552|HIST 782062552}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the "Second World War" section be changed so that this passage

<blockquote>In his Middle East Diary Coward made several statements that offended many Americans. In particular, he commented that he was "less impressed by some of the mournful little Brooklyn boys lying there in tears amid the alien corn with nothing worse than a bullet wound in the leg or a fractured arm".[75][76] After protests from both The New York Times and The Washington Post, the Foreign Office urged Coward not to visit the United States in January 1945. He did not return to America again during the war.  </blockquote>

is changed to 

<blockquote>In his Middle East Diary Coward made several statements that offended many Americans. In particular, he commented that he was "less impressed by some of the mournful little Brooklyn boys lying there in tears amid the alien corn with nothing worse than a bullet wound in the leg or a fractured arm".[75][76] ''' The passage set off a furor in the United States when the book was published in November 1944. New York City's mayor Fiorello LaGuardia and other New York officials attacked Coward, and the Brooklyn Daily Eagle commenced a campaign against him.[77] There were protests from the New York City Council, which passed a resolution condemning Coward for "the libel published by his reflecting upon the valour and courage of Brooklyn's fighting forces,"[78]''' as well as The New York Times and The Washington Post. '''Due to the controversy,''' the Foreign Office urged Coward not to visit the United States in January 1945. </blockquote>

The boldface words are additions.  They are sourced to a biography that is currently utilized as a source. See [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=No%C3%ABl_Coward&type=revision&diff=776827049&oldid=776702024 this diff]
[[User:Coretheapple|Coretheapple]] ([[User talk:Coretheapple|talk]]) 18:37, 24 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Film#rfc_EE03E4F|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Film]] expired 2017-05-25 16:01 ===
* Id: EE03E4F
* User: Erik
* Date: 2017-04-25 16:00:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|777396815|POLICY 777396815}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|782217446|POLICY 782217446}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Based on the discussion at WT:FILM [[WT:FILM#Columns, columns everywhere|here]] ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia_talk:WikiProject_Film&oldid=777160062#Columns.2C_columns_everywhere permalink]), I propose an addition of a "Columns" sub-section under "Non-prose components" to outline best practices when working with columns in film articles. Here is a preliminary write-up:
<blockquote>Columns are commonplace in Wikipedia articles about films, most often for "Cast" and "References" sections. If a single column of references or actors and roles takes up vertical space, it can be converted into multiple columns to use horizontal [[white space (visual arts)|white space]] and reduce vertical space as long as there is a noticeable improvement for readers. However, editors should realize that readers view Wikipedia with different screen widths. Therefore, requiring a list to be broken up into a specific number of columns every time may appear unreadable or difficult to read with some screen widths. Instead of setting a specific number of columns, set an [[em (typography)|em]] value instead, which allows the number of columns presenting a list to change based on the reader's screen width. Please see the template documentation below for further guidance:
*'''References:''' {{tl|Reflist}} (See "Columns" section)
*'''Cast list and other lists:''' {{tl|Div col}} (see "Usage" section and {{para|cols}} and {{para|colwidth}} parameters)
The WikiProject Film community prefers 25em to be used as the default value unless there is a compelling reason to use a different value. Per [[WP:RESOL]], editors need to ensure accessibility for resolutions of 1024 pixels wide and upward. The most popular laptop resolution is 1366x768, and the most popular desktop resolution is 1920x1080. The value of 25em allows for there to be two to four columns for all resolutions between 1024 and 1920.
</blockquote>
Thoughts on this? {{ul|Betty Logan}}, {{ul|Millahnna}}, {{ul|MarnetteD}}? [[User:Erik|Erik]]&nbsp;([[User talk:Erik|talk]]&nbsp;&#124;&nbsp;[[Special:Contributions/Erik|contrib]]) <sup>([[Template:Reply to|ping me]])</sup> 16:00, 25 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Rivers#rfc_3FA0E0A|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Rivers]] expired 2017-05-27 04:01 ===
* Id: 3FA0E0A
* User: Dicklyon
* Date: 2017-04-27 03:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|777432726|STYLE 777432726}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|782474588|STYLE 782474588}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the old proposed conventions for how to disambiguate river names be updated, as proposed above? 
In particular, these options are on the table:
* 1.  The old "proposed naming convention", e.g. [[Rio Puerco (Rio Grande)]], [[Rio Puerco (Rio Chama)]]
* 2.  Per recent RM that added "tributary", e.g. [[Rio Puerco (Rio Grande tributary)]], [[Rio Puerco (Rio Chama tributary)]]
* 3.  Political jurisdiction at mouth, e.g. [[Rio Puerco (Valencia County, New Mexico)]], [[Rio Puerco (Rio Arriba County, New Mexico)]]
[[User:Dicklyon|Dicklyon]] ([[User talk:Dicklyon|talk]]) 03:19, 27 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Infobox religious text#rfc_F44538B|Template talk:Infobox religious text]] expired 2017-05-27 14:01 ===
* Id: F44538B
* User: Capankajsmilyo
* Date: 2017-04-27 13:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|777742885|RELI 777742885}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|777742888|TECH 777742888}}

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|782528641|TECH 782528641}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
We should go ahead with adding wikidata params, along with options to enable editors to suppress them. This will enable improvement of both wikidata and wikipedia by synchronizing the information and reducing edit-wars on wikipedia, as controversial params can be fetched from wikidata, which do not support un-linked content for most fields. {{u|Ms Sarah Welch}} {{u|Frietjes}} -- Pankaj Jain ''[[User:Capankajsmilyo|Capankajsmilyo]] <span class="plainlinks">([[User talk:Capankajsmilyo|talk]] '''·''' [[Special:Contribs/Capankajsmilyo|contribs]] '''·''' [//tools.wmflabs.org/xtools-ec/?user=Capankajsmilyo&project=en.wikipedia.org count])</span>'' 13:18, 27 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Antonio Margarito#rfc_8F83D9F|Talk:Antonio Margarito]] expired 2017-05-28 19:01 ===
* Id: 8F83D9F
* User: SVTCobra
* Date: 2017-04-28 18:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|777700737|BIO 777700737}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Biographies|prev|782717367|BIO 782717367}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I and other editors have been unable to resolve our differences regarding how to list the nationality of Antonio Margarito (AM).  I hereby request neutral editors to take an objective look at the issue before it devolves into an all-out edit war.  

'''Nature of issue'''

The following facts are undisputed (I believe):
*AM was born in California, USA
*AM was raised in Mexico
*AM has lived the majority of his life in Mexico
*AM has a US passport and citizenship
*AM is listed by [[BoxRec]] and all major boxing governing bodies ([[WBO]], [[World Boxing Council|WBC]], [[IBF]]) as Mexican

The issue is centered around a single source, namely a January 23, 2009 article in the ''LA Times'': "[http://articles.latimes.com/2009/jan/23/sports/sp-margarito-mosley23 It's safer in the ring for Antonio Margarito]".  In this article, it is established that AM has a US passport, but the article repeatedly refers to him as Mexican and states that AM "is 100% Mexican and he'll continue to be 100% Mexican," even after setting up residence in San Diego, California.

'''Statement by {{User|SVTCobra}}'''

{{User|Danggoshdarn}} (and before him {{User|BrendanFrye}}) insist that since AM was born in USA and has a US passport, AM is American and American only, demanding that other editors produce evidence of AM having a Mexican passport and/or citizenship.  AM's listing by governing bodies are deemed unworthy sources for nationality.  [[Dual nationality]] and concepts of [[national identity]] cannot be considered without producing governmental paperwork, in their view.  All efforts to present AM's nationality with any reference to Mexico have been immediately reverted, pending what I consider an unreasonable burden of proof.  AM, by all accounts, considers himself Mexican and so does every source I can find.

A smaller issue, is whether BoxRec is solid enough of a source to presume that AM moved back to Mexico, following his time in San Diego.  BoxRec is normally considered authoritative, but not good enough for Danggoshdarn, who will only recognize the ''LA Times'' article because it specifically talks about AM moving house and no profile or boxing record can supersede this article.

Thank you for your time.  Cheers, --[[User:SVTCobra|SVTCobra]] ([[User talk:SVTCobra|talk]]) 18:37, 28 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Pratia pedunculata#rfc_7423588|Talk:Pratia pedunculata]] expired 2017-05-29 10:01 ===
* Id: 7423588
* User: Batternut
* Date: 2017-05-26 12:42:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|782365880|SCI 782365880}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|782811897|SCI 782811897}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Most vendors and books call this plant a Pratia, as does the RHS: [https://www.rhs.org.uk/Plants/27272/i-Pratia-pedunculata-i/Details Pratia Pedunculata] versus [https://www.rhs.org.uk/Plants/84821/i-Lobelia-pedunculata-i/Details Lobelia pedunculata].

Wikispecies reckons Lobelia, as does [http://apps.kew.org/wcsp/namedetail.do?name_id=353240 Kew], in contrast to the [https://biodiversity.org.au/nsl/services/name/apni/107189 Australian Plant Name Index] which goes with Pratia. My amateur understanding is that the botanists consider Lobelia correct for these plants rather than Pratia (''{{Wikispecies-inline|Pratia Pedunculata}}'') (discussed at ''{{Wikispecies-inline|Talk:Pratia Pedunculata}}'').

Should Wikipedia follow Wikispecies, or does [[wp:Commonname]] rule here? [[User:Batternut|Batternut]] ([[User talk:Batternut|talk]]) 12:42, 26 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_D43C25E|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-05-29 10:01 ===
* Id: D43C25E
* User: The Diaz
* Date: 2017-05-27 15:01:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|782536220|POLICY 782536220}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|782811902|POLICY 782811902}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Here is a new proposal that would amend the [[WP:MOS|Manual of Style]]'s [[MOS:ENGVAR|National varieties of English]] policy and the format of some articles' titles. While I find nothing prohibiting my proposal, I still seek authorization.

I propose a new way to include any dialect of English in Wikipedia for anything. In other words, we could make certain articles in certain varieties of English and we could note that in the article's title.

For example, [[World War II]] could have two articles, one in American English (using the mdy date format) and one in British English (using the dmy date format). We could note this by making the article's titles look like: ''World War II<sup>US</sup>'' and ''World War II<sup>UK</sup>'' respectively. Searching "''World War II''" would take the user to a dialect selection page that could read:

''For American English, click World War II<sup>US</sup>

For British English, click World War II<sup>UK</sup>

For Canadian English, click World War II<sup>CA</sup>''

We would only need to put the small abbreviation on the title if there was another article with a different dialect of English. We could also put a message on the top of the article saying: "''This article is written in _________ English. For a different dialect, click [[here]].''"

I invite anyone to share their opinion and encourage any editor thinking of opposing my proposal to suggest a way to make it acceptable in their eyes. <span style="color:blue">'''THE DIAZ'''</span> <sup>[[User talk:The Diaz|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/The Diaz|contribs]]</sup> 15:01, 27 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Sciences Po#rfc_6F7FAF9|Talk:Sciences Po]] expired 2017-05-29 19:01 ===

=== [[Talk:Jesus#rfc_D10E048|Talk:Jesus]] expired 2017-05-30 23:01 ===
* Id: D10E048
* User: Oncenawhile
* Date: 2017-04-30 22:08:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|778066557|HIST 778066557}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|778066564|RELI 778066564}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|783067955|HIST 783067955}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|783067957|RELI 783067957}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
An article published three days ago criticized our coverage of Jesus as follows:[http://www.haaretz.com/life/.premium-1.786100]

<blockquote>One famous and telling example is the history of the Wikipedia page for Jesus: as tensions and disagreements grew between believers and nonbelievers, the article was broken up into a number of new ones, splitting into one page for Jesus and another for Historical Jesus. Instead of addressing the issue at hand, Wikipedia attempts to sidestep it altogether, allowing both sides to enjoy their version of the truth.</blockquote>

I have tried to verify this claim. A [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Talk:Historical_Jesus&oldid=19096756 talk page comment] from the late [[Steven Rubenstein]] from 12 years ago summarized it as follows:

<blockquote> Please remember the history: in an attempt to keep the Jesus article NPOV, detailed accounts of a variety of views were added, and the article became too long for many servers. There was a quick consensus to have the article focus on the Christian POV, with sub-articles on other points of view, and very brief summaries with links as subsections of the Jesus article. The main topics spun off were on the historical and cultural context for Jesus, which placed Jesus in the context of what we know about Jewish history and culture; one on the "historicity" of Jesus, meaning, debates over whether or not Jesus actually existed; this article, and I think one or two more on the critical study of the NT and Christology.</blockquote>

I propose we take this criticism seriously and consider whether some restructuring of the various Jesus articles would be appropriate. Things have moved on significantly since 2003-04 when the current structure was created. The suggestion of "Multiple Parallel Narratives" on such a high profile topic is damning to our project.

[[User:Oncenawhile|Oncenawhile]] ([[User talk:Oncenawhile|talk]]) 22:08, 30 April 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (geographic names)#rfc_696C0F0|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (geographic names)]] expired 2017-05-31 05:01 ===

=== [[User:Guy Macon/sandbox#rfc_899EF24|User:Guy Macon/sandbox]] expired 2017-05-31 06:01 ===
* Id: 899EF24
* User: Guy Macon
* Date: 2017-05-30 18:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|783037830|POLICY 783037830}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|783112323|POLICY 783112323}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
What referer information should Wikipedia send to an external website when a reader clicks on a link?

'''Limitations:'''
The Wikimedia foundation is not bound by Wikipedia RfCs, so this RfC is purely advisory.
If there is a strong consensus for a particular referrer policy, a request will be made to the Wikimedia foundation to implement that policy. The request will contains the words "if possible" and "as far as is practical" to make it clear that we are saying what we want, not how to accomplish  it.

'''Background:'''

{{cot}}

'''Previous discussions:'''

* [[meta:Research:Wikimedia referrer policy]]
* [[meta:Research talk:Wikimedia referrer policy#Proposal: be a silent referrer]]
* [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)/Archive 126#Privacy and dark traffic]]

'''Overview:'''

When someone who is reading Wikipedia clicks on an external link their web browser may be given referrer information to be passed on to the external website. Depending on various factors, this information can range from telling the external site exactly what Wikipedia page the reader was on when they clicked on the link, telling them that the link was from Wikipedia but not telling them where on Wikipedia, to telling them nothing at all about the site that the link was on.

For example, consider the case of someone reading the Wikipedia page at [http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bomb-making_instructions_on_the_internet#References Bomb-making instructions on the internet#References] who clicks on the link to [https://aardvark.co.nz/pjet/cruise.shtml The Low Cost Cruise Missile: A looming threat?]. (example ignores our recent switch to HTTPS for clarity). 

Depending on how we configure Wikipedia, the aardvark.co.nz website (and anyone monitoring the connection between the user's browser and aardvark.co.nz) could be told that site/page the link was on (the referrer) was:

* en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bomb-making_instructions_on_the_internet#References (full URL)
* en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bomb-making_instructions_on_the_internet (page)
* en.wikipedia.org (full domain)
* wikipedia.org (partial domain)
* No referrer information (a silent referrer)

Furthermore, Wikipedia might send additional information that some sites may (or may not) choose to honor in various ways. These are discussed in the technical comments section below.

Many web sites have a legitimate desire to know who links to them. Alas, spammers also desire to know who links to them so that they can refine their spamming. Most users desire to send the minimum amount of information that is consistent with them being able to user the website.
{{cob}}

'''What this RfC is not'''

* This RfC is not binding on anyone. It is purely advisory.
* This RfC is not a discussion of the technical details regarding what is and is not possible using current technology, which may change. It is an RfC about policy, not implementation. There is a section on the bottom for technical discussions such as what HTTPS does and does not allow, etc. All comments that focus on "how we should do it" rather than "what should we do" may be moved to the technical discussion section by any user.  
* This RfC is not about links to other Wikipedia pages or to other projects that are under the control of the Wikimedia foundation. It is assumed that, as far as possible/practical, other WMF sites will receive as much information as they want to receive.

''' Questions '''

''' Question 1: As far as possible/practical, should referer information contain full URLs? (en.wikipedia.org/page#section) '''

*'''Support''' example support comment.

''' Question 2: As far as possible/practical, should referer information contain full domains and pages? (en.wikipedia.org/page) '''

*'''Support''' example support comment.

''' Question 3: As far as possible/practical, should referer information contain full domains? (en.wikipedia.org) '''

*'''Support''' example support comment.

''' Question 4: As far as possible/practical, should referer information contain partial domains? (wikipedia.org) '''

*'''Support''' example support comment.

''' Question 5: As far as possible/practical, should referer information contain no information? (silent referer) '''

*'''Support''' Here is the reason why, whenever possible, we should reveal as little as possible about what pages our users read or what links they follow:[http://www.longisland.com/news/08-02-13/locals-questioned-by-scpd-after-googling-backpack-and-pressure-cooker.html][https://www.yahoo.com/news/google-pressure-cookers-backpacks-visit-feds-140900667.html][http://www.thewire.com/national/2013/08/government-knocking-doors-because-google-searches/67864/] --[[User:Guy Macon|Guy Macon]] ([[User talk:Guy Macon|talk]]) 18:37, 30 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Women's Equality Party#rfc_FA6AA07|Talk:Women's Equality Party]] expired 2017-05-31 13:01 ===
* Id: FA6AA07
* User: Helper201
* Date: 2017-05-01 12:47:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|778314140|POL 778314140}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|788924294|POL 788924294}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Nonpartisanism is a lack of affiliation with a political party. Political parties are very rarely affiliated to each other, so I don't think this should be here. I think its being used as a substitute to state that the party does not place itself on the left-right political spectrum, of which I would agree, I just don't think this is relevant and should be removed. [[User:Helper201|Helper201]] ([[User talk:Helper201|talk]]) 12:47, 1 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Syrian Observatory for Human Rights#rfc_257B1BA|Talk:Syrian Observatory for Human Rights]] expired 2017-05-31 22:01 ===
* Id: 257B1BA
* User: EtienneDolet
* Date: 2017-05-01 21:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|778237581|POL 778237581}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|783222945|POL 783222945}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following critique be added in the Accuracy section of this article?

{{quotation|'''A <s>common</s> criticism of SOHR has been that it is "difficult, if not impossible" to fact check SOHR's data since its director, Rami Abdulrahman, "does not share his data or methodology". Syria conflict expert James Miller has criticised the SOHR suggesting that it knew "field reporters who have never encountered a SOHR source in Syria." When presented with a chart showing the number of war dead in April 2014, Miller made several remarked: "There are hundreds, perhaps thousands of examples why [SOHR] is a terrible source" and "Everything about that chart screams BS!"'''}}

The source is [https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2014/12/03/200000-dead-why-syrias-rising-death-toll-is-so-divisive/?utm_term=.56ab0b5ab1ae Washington Post: 200,000 dead? Why Syria’s rising death toll is so divisive]

Also, the entire quote doesn't have to be placed in the article. If you would like a modified rendition of the critique, feel free to propose it. [[User:EtienneDolet|Étienne Dolet]] ([[User talk:EtienneDolet|talk]]) 21:44, 1 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Harassment#rfc_D50B2BB|Wikipedia talk:Harassment]] expired 2017-06-02 04:01 ===
* Id: D50B2BB
* User: Godsy
* Date: 2017-06-01 19:29:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|783363821|POLICY 783363821}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|783414767|POLICY 783414767}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
*'''Question 1''': If an editor regularly introduces pages into the mainspace that have problems (e.g. categories need activated, containing empty sections which should be removed, not in compliance with basic parts of the [[WP:MOS|manual of style]], etc.), and the user is known not to clean up the pages themself, does it constitute harassment for another user to regurlarly fix those problems in said articles?
*'''Question 2''': If an editor moves pages from the userpsace of others to the mainspace that may not be [[WP:STALEDRAFT|suitable for the mainspace]], and has shown a pattern of having pages they move in that manner end up being deleted, does it constitute harassment for another user to seek the restoration of those pages to the userspace per the result of [[WP:UP/RFC2016]] ([[WP:UP/RFC2016#B4|B4]]) (i.e. "<small>If a draft is moved to the mainspace by a user other than its author, then found to be unsuitable for the mainspace for reasons which wouldn't apply in the userspace, it should be returned to the userspace.</small>")?
:<small>—&nbsp;[[User:Godsy|<span style="color:MediumSpringGreen;">Godsy</span>]]<sup>&nbsp;([[User_talk:Godsy|TALK]]</sup><sub style="margin-left:-2.0ex;">[[Special:Contributions/Godsy|<span style="color:Goldenrod;">CONT</span>]])</sub></small> 19:29, 1 June 2017 (UTC)}}

[[User:David.moreno72|<span style="font-family:verdana;color:#ffff00;background:#0040ff">David.<span style="background: #0033cc">moreno<span style="background:#002080">72</span></span></span>]] 07:36, 3 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Lead section#rfc_F8C0819|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Lead section]] expired 2017-06-02 11:01 ===
* Id: F8C0819
* User: Yashovardhan Dhanania
* Date: 2017-05-07 04:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|779128199|STYLE 779128199}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|783448462|STYLE 783448462}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
From above:

There seems to be inconsistency in the way that sponsored names are handled in the lead section of articles. On some articles (including [[Dean Court]] and [[Queen's Club Championships]]) the sponsored name is written in bold. On some other articles (including [[London Eye]] and [[The Boat Race]]) the sponsored name is not in bold.

Should a consistent policy be adopted across English Wikipedia, either:
# making the sponsored name bold on all articles, or
# requiring that the sponsored name is not written in bold?
(NA) '''Relisted''' [[User:Yashovardhan Dhanania|Yashovardhan]] ([[User talk:Yashovardhan Dhanania|talk]]) 04:36, 7 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Alone in the Universe#rfc_F3AD4D0|Talk:Alone in the Universe]] expired 2017-06-02 17:01 ===
* Id: F3AD4D0
* User: Liam Gibson
* Date: 2017-05-03 16:05:00

{{rfcquote|text=
I noticed that this page (in fact, all of the ELO pages) contains two chronologies, one of which is a studio album chronology. Really only 5% of album pages have more than one chronology, and they're only really necessary for collaborations. So, is everyone fine with me re-removing that extra chronology, or will my edit get reverted again? [[User:Liam Gibson|Liam Gibson]] ([[User talk:Liam Gibson|talk]]) 16:05, 3 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Notifications#rfc_F198530|Wikipedia talk:Notifications]] expired 2017-06-03 02:01 ===
* Id: F198530
* User: Steel1943
* Date: 2017-06-02 20:36:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|783521618|PROP 783521618}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|783553257|PROP 783553257}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I propose that editors should receive a notification when another editor or a bot creates a subpage of either their user page or their user talk page. After running across this issue myself, I believe this proposal is beneficial for several reasons, including assisting editors detect possible vandalism or misplaced pages in their user space. [[User:Steel1943|<span style="color: #2F4F4F;">'''''Steel1943'''''</span>]] ([[User talk:Steel1943|talk]]) 20:36, 2 June 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2016 shooting of Dallas police officers#rfc_95A527D|Talk:2016 shooting of Dallas police officers]] expired 2017-06-04 08:01 ===
* Id: 95A527D
* Date: 2017-05-05 07:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|778794520|POL 778794520}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|783730687|POL 783730687}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
A previous RfC was held nearly a year ago at [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:2016_shooting_of_Dallas_police_officers/Archive_3#Request_for_Comment], where the consensus was not to put "Racial Hatred" in the motive section of the perpetrator infobox. The major reasons cited was that at the time of writing, sources were not available on the nature of the motive of the perpetrator, and putting in any motive would be considered speculative. Since then, a year has passed, and reliable sources have called it racial hatred, including then president Obama. I therefore propose that we re-introduce the term "racial hatred", supported by the citations given in the lead infobox, in light of the advances that have occured since the last RfC. [[user:BrxBrx|BrxBrx]]([[user talk:BrxBrx|talk]])<sup><nowiki>(please reply with { {re|BrxBrx}})</nowiki></sup> 07:05, 5 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_DB40A14|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-06-04 13:01 ===
* Id: DB40A14
* User: The Diaz
* Date: 2017-05-05 12:52:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|778828999|POLICY 778828999}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|783754863|POLICY 783754863}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This has been a term that has been debated heavily on Wikipedia forever. Whether or not to call them "illegal immigrants" or "undocumented immigrants". I propose that we settle this debate by creating a policy or a guideline that requires all pages to either use the term "illegal alien" or "illegal immigrant" given that this is the term used by the US government. as seen in ''Arizona v. United States''. Federal district court Judge Andrew Hanen of the Southern District of Texas was quoted as saying: ''The Court uses the phrases ‘illegal immigrant’ and ‘illegal alien’ interchangeably…The Court also understands that there is a certain segment of the population that finds the phrase ‘illegal alien’ offensive. The Court uses this term because it is the term used by the Supreme Court in its latest pronouncement pertaining to this area of the law. See Arizona v. United States, 132 S. Ct. 2492 (2012).'' I am open to amending the details of my proposal and encourage anyone to think before opposing it and suggest how to make it acceptable. <span style="color:blue">'''THE DIAZ'''</span> <sup>[[User talk:The Diaz|talk]] • [[Special:Contributions/The Diaz|contribs]]</sup> 12:52, 5 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (films)#rfc_DB74BAF|Wikipedia talk:Naming conventions (films)]] expired 2017-06-05 18:01 ===
* Id: DB74BAF
* User: 67.14.236.50
* Date: 2017-05-06 17:20:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|779044301|STYLE 779044301}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|779044305|POLICY 779044305}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|783959157|STYLE 783959157}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|783959158|POLICY 783959158}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I propose changing the following in [[WP:NCF#Film series]] from:
{{talkquote|For articles on a series of films, the title of the article should be '''''Series name'' (film series)''' or '''''Series subject'' (film series)''', such as [[Harry Potter (film series)|''Harry Potter'' (film series)]]. […]}}
to:
{{talkquote|<p>For articles on a series of films, the title of the article should be '''''Series name'' (film series)''', such as <ins>[[The Chronicles of Narnia (film series)|''The Chronicles of Narnia'' (film series)]]; if the series has no official name, choose one commonly used by reliable sources, usually the subject of the film series, such as [[Bourne (film series)|''Bourne'' (film series)]]</ins>. […]}}

The goal of this edit is to clarify the intended meaning without altering it. If you feel it fails to do so, please explain why. —[[Special:Contributions/67.14.236.50|67.14.236.50]] ([[User talk:67.14.236.50|talk]]) 17:20, 6 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Big Brother Canada (season 5)#rfc_2303FE9|Talk:Big Brother Canada (season 5)]] expired 2017-06-06 03:01 ===
* Id: 2303FE9
* User: VietPride10
* Date: 2017-05-07 01:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|779109399|TECH 779109399}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|784035035|TECH 784035035}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been debate about whether or not to use the nowrap template on the Big Brother Canada 5 page to keep the voting table consistent (all columns have 2 line breaks instead of 3) Specifically, the edit states "Demetres' choice (br)" which means a line break after "choice", but when the edit is saved, there is a line break after "Demetres'" causing three line breaks. To fix this, I've used the [[Template:Nowrap|nowrap template]] {{tlx|nowrap|Demetres' choice}}, which fixes it from three line breaks back to 2 to be consistent with the entire voting table. However, a specific user has been constantly reverting my edits.  [[User:VietPride10|VietPride10]] ([[User talk:VietPride10|talk]]) 01:18, 7 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_7B31DC1|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-06-06 22:01 ===
* Id: 7B31DC1
* User: Eggishorn
* Date: 2017-06-06 19:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|784157578|UNSORTED 784157578}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|784175144|UNSORTED 784175144}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 There are a number of statements about inclusion of sports figures that essentially come down to either [[WP:ILIKEIT]] or [[WP:IDONTLIKEIT]], none of which are especially useful in evaluating consensus. These statements were partially or fully discounted in our evaluation.

This RFC discussed two related themes.  The first theme was whether the subject notability guidelines given at [[WP:NSPORT]] are being used and interpreted correctly at AFD.  The second theme was whether some of the subguidelines within WP:NSPORT are too inclusive.  

The first theme developed a strong consensus that the GNG is the controlling guideline, while the criteria at NSPORT are useful tools to try to quickly determine the likelihood of an article meeting the GNG. 

The second theme was the question of whether some of the NSPORTS criteria are too inclusive. Significant discussion only occurred for the cycling criteria.  No consensus emerged on any specific adjustment to the cycling criteria, and no other criteria were discussed in sufficient depth for anything resembling a consensus to emerge. 

The conclusions that can be drawn at this point are:

*There is '''clear consensus''' that no subject-specific notability guideline, including [[WP:NSPORTS|Notability (sports)]] is a replacement for or supercedes the [[WP:GNG|General Notability Guideline]]. Arguments must be more refined than simply citing compliance with a substandard of [[WP:NSPORTS]]  in the context of an Articles for Deletion discussion.
*There is a general unhappiness with the permissiveness of some NSPORTS criteria, but '''no consensus in this discussion''' on any specific changes to any of them.
*There is '''rough consensus''' that sources on older athletes are concentrated in print media. Because it is impossible to prove the negative that the sources do not exist to support an article, some intermediate standard is required for determining when an article on these athletes should be deleted due to lack of notability.

Due to the tangential discussion here on some points that have been raised below, there are issues that remain unsettled by this discussion.  Follow-up discussion should be held to determine (in no particular order):
*The appropriate result for an article at AFD about a sportsperson where they verifiably meet a NSPORTS criterion, but various levels of effort have not yielded significant sourcing (especially for older athletes or athletes from non-Anglophone locations)
*The possible cut-offs for "older" or "non-Anglophone" in connection with the above question
*Proposed specific changes for the criteria in each sports-specific substandard 
As with the [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=&oldid=767023947#RfC_on_secondary_school_notability RfC on secondary school notability], this should not be an invitation to {{tq|flood AfD with indiscriminate or excessive nominations}}.
<small>([[Wikipedia:Non-admin closure|non-admin closure]])</small>
[[User:Eggishorn|Eggishorn]] [[User talk:Eggishorn|(talk)]] [[Special:Contributions/Eggishorn|(contrib)]] 19:26, 6 June 2017 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_5C4A9F3|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-06-06 22:01 ===
* Id: 5C4A9F3
* User: Giraffedata
* Date: 2017-06-05 02:25:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|784157578|UNSORTED 784157578}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|784175144|UNSORTED 784175144}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
== Labeling illegal (or undocumented) immigrants correctly '''

{{archive top|result=
Consensus is not to have a policy or guideline requiring the use of "illegal alien" or "illegal immigrant".

The terminology should be decided on a case by case basis, and the argument should be about what term reliable sources use to refer to the persons in question and not based on the terms used in law.

And there is a weak auxiliary consensus against using the word "alien".

[[User:Giraffedata|Bryan Henderson (giraffedata)]] ([[User talk:Giraffedata|talk]]) 02:25, 5 June 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Screenshot/fodder#rfc_B9B5E4D|Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Screenshot/fodder]] expired 2017-06-08 22:01 ===
* Id: B9B5E4D
* Date: 2017-06-07 20:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|784523788|POLICY 784523788}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|784523791|TECH 784523791}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|784542955|POLICY 784542955}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|784542959|TECH 784542959}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{REMOVE THIS TEMPLATE WHEN CLOSING THIS AfD|I}}

:{{la|Screenshot/fodder}} – (<includeonly>[[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Screenshot/fodder|View AfD]]</includeonly><noinclude>[[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Log/2017 June 7#{{anchorencode:Screenshot/fodder}}|View log]]</noinclude>{{int:dot-separator}} <span class="plainlinks">[https://tools.wmflabs.org/jackbot/snottywong/cgi-bin/votecounter.cgi?page=Wikipedia:Articles_for_deletion/Screenshot/fodder Stats]</span>)
:({{Find sources AFD|Screenshot/fodder}})
This page is not an article at all, but an apparent technical workaround to address an issue with VisualEditor, discussed on the talk page. I don't pretend to understand the technical issue, but this does seem to be an inappropriate use of mainspace, which is strictly reserved for encyclopedic content. I think we'd need to see a ''very'' good reason that this page needs to exist, in order to supersede that principle. —[[user:swpb|<u>swpb</u>]]<sup>[[user talk:swpb|''T'']]</sup> 20:15, 7 June 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Dismissal of James Comey#rfc_EE6B3BF|Talk:Dismissal of James Comey]] expired 2017-06-10 07:01 ===
* Id: EE6B3BF
* User: 2605:6000:ec16:c000:38c1:c602:9adc:a4c7

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been lots of discussion over mentioning the name "Tuesday Night Massacre" in the article. It has been discussed in a few different places in different contexts (in fact some individuals attempted to use that phrase as an excuse to delete this article).

For the record: This phrase is widely used and notable. Certain individuals have attempted to purport that this is an obscure phrase that was invented by a random WP editor. However the widespread usage of this name has been well established:
* WP discussions:
** [[Wikipedia:Redirects_for_discussion/Log/2017_May_10#Tuesday_Night_Massacre Link deletion proposal]]
** [[Talk:Dismissal_of_James_Comey#.22Massacre.22]]
* Usage by the media:
** [http://www.jacksonsun.com/story/opinion/columnists/2017/05/13/trumps-totally-predictable-tuesday-night-massacre/319159001/ Jackson Sun] (May 13)
** [http://www.timesargus.com/articles/with-comey-gone-what-now/ Times Argus] (May 13)
** [https://www.usnews.com/opinion/op-ed/articles/2017-05-12/we-need-an-impeachment-investigation-after-donald-trump-fired-james-comey U.S. News] (May 12)
** [http://www.bostonherald.com/opinion/op_ed/2017/05/rachelle_cohen_fbi_chief_s_firing_flunks_the_smell_test Boston Herald] (May 11)
** [http://www.slate.com/articles/podcasts/gabfest/2017/05/comey_conservatism_under_trump_and_utah_on_the_political_gabfest.html Slate] (May 11)
** [http://nation.foxnews.com/2017/05/11/comeys-firing-rod-rosensteins-justice Fox News] (May 11)
** [https://www.wsj.com/articles/rod-rosensteins-justice-1494458376 Wall Street Journal] (May 10)
** [http://fortune.com/2017/05/09/comey-trump-tuesday-night-massacre/ Fortune] (May 9)
** [http://www.irishtimes.com/opinion/trump-s-tuesday-night-massacre-another-blow-for-american-democracy-1.3077960 The Irish Times]
** [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-05-09/five-things-you-need-to-know-to-start-your-day-j2i44nvw Bloomberg News]
** [http://www.mediaite.com/online/nixons-saturday-night-massacre-and-tuesdaynightmassacre-blow-up-on-twitter-after-comey-firing/ Mediate]
** [http://www.latimes.com/politics/washington/la-na-essential-washington-updates-for-the-second-time-since-trump-took-1494375627-htmlstory.html LA Times]
** [http://www.sfchronicle.com/opinion/editorials/article/Trump-s-Tuesday-night-massacre-11133931.php SF Chronicle]
** [http://www.philly.com/philly/blogs/attytood/Trumps-Tuesday-Night-Massacre-sends-US-teetering-toward-banana-republic-status.html Philadelphia Inquirer]

* Discussions of trending in social media:
** [http://www.latimes.com/politics/washington/la-na-essential-washington-updates-for-the-second-time-since-trump-took-1494375627-htmlstory.html]
** [http://www.mediaite.com/online/nixons-saturday-night-massacre-and-tuesdaynightmassacre-blow-up-on-twitter-after-comey-firing/]
** [http://mashable.com/2017/05/09/donald-trump-fbi-james-comey-nixon-tuesday-massacre/#axUkpNAgt5qt]

Nevertheless, it seems there is an agenda by some individuals to continue trying to hide this name from Wikipedia.

=== [[Talk:Dick Cheney#rfc_E0AB71F|Talk:Dick Cheney]] expired 2017-06-11 03:02 ===
* Id: E0AB71F
* User: MB298
* Date: 2017-05-12 01:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|779958034|POL 779958034}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|785004757|POL 785004757}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{ping|Visnvoisnvo}} also pinging {{ping|Sleyece}} and {{ping|CFCF}} since both were involved in the previous discussion: Should the position of Acting President be included in the infobox? Cheney held the position for several hours on two occasions: June 29, 2002 and July 21, 2007. It should be noted that never did Cheney actually hold the position of President, he merely assumed the powers and duties of the role while Bush was undergoing surgery. Visnvoisnvo recently added the position in the infobox, noting, "Do not change without discussion. This is an historical event. Check out: https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Dick_Cheney_Letter_2007-07-21." I have since reverted the changes.

'''Options'''
* A) The position of Acting President is included in the infobox
* B) The position of Acting President is entirely omitted from the infobox
* C) While the position is not displayed along with other political offices, a footnote is included in the infobox which notes he acted as President
[[User:MB298|MB298]] ([[User talk:MB298|talk]]) 01:02, 12 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Bahá'í Faith#rfc_29DD441|Talk:Bahá'í Faith]] expired 2017-06-12 00:01 ===
* Id: 29DD441
* User: Cuñado
* Date: 2017-05-17 22:50:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|780916969|RELI 780916969}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|785158080|RELI 785158080}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I'm requesting comment on the first two paragraphs on the [[Baha'i Faith]]. We have had about a month of edit warring, and discussions don't seem to be going anywhere. Here are the first two paragraphs in the current version (which the majority of editors are reverting to):

{{quote|The '''Bahá'í Faith''' ({{lang-fa |بهائی}} ''{{transl|fa|Bahā'i}}'') is a religion teaching the essential worth of all religions, and the unity and equality of all people.{{sfn|Dictionary|2017}} Established by [[Bahá'u'lláh]] in 1863, it initially grew in the [[Middle East]] and now has between 5-7 million adherents, known as '''Bahá'ís''', spread out into most of the world's countries and territories, with the highest concentrations in [[India]] and [[Iran]].{{sfn|Encyclopædia Britannica|2002}}

The Bahá'í Faith formed from the [[Bábism|Bábí religion]], a [[19th century]] outgrowth of [[Shia Islam]] that faced persecution by [[Persian Empire|Persian]] authorities. In 1853, Bahá'u'lláh was imprisoned and exiled from his native [[Iran]]. He spent time in [[Baghdad]] before being further exiled, spending over a decade in the prison city of [[Acre, Israel|Akka]] in the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] province of Syria, in what is now [[Israel]]. Following Bahá'u'lláh's death in 1892, leadership of the religion fell to his son [[`Abdu'l-Bahá]] (1844-1921), and later his great-grandson [[Shoghi Effendi]] (1897-1957). Bahá'ís around the world annually elect local, regional, and national [[Spiritual Assembly|Spiritual Assemblies]] that govern the affairs of the religion, and every five years the members of all National Spiritual Assemblies elect the [[Universal House of Justice]], the nine-member supreme governing institution of the worldwide Bahá'í community, which sits in [[Haifa, Israel]] near the [[shrine of Bahá'u'lláh]].}}

It has been adjusted and improved upon over this time, but there are a few sticking points. Please read the previous section on this talk page: [[Talk:Bahá'í Faith#Edit conflicts in the lead]]. If I may summarize the issues, they focus on how much detail should go into discussing the persecution of early Bábís and an attempted assassination of the Shah by some Bábís in order to briefly explain why Baha'u'llah was imprisoned and exiled from Iran. [[User:A35821361]], in particular, thinks that mentioning persecution and exile should also mention the assassination attempt. Others believe that mentioning the assassination attempt presents its own problematic POV by leading the reader to think Baha'u'llah was behind the attempted murder (he was not). Regardless, all of the information is further below in the article and on sub-pages explaining all the details. This is a question about what is appropriate to summarize in the lead paragraphs to convey important concepts while not going into extraneous detail. [[User:Cuñado|<font color="#AF7817">'''Cuñado'''</font>]] ☼ - [[User talk:Cuñado|<font size="-3">Talk</font>]] 22:50, 17 May 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Deity#rfc_3D1C00D|Talk:Deity]] expired 2017-06-13 05:01 ===
* Id: 3D1C00D
* User: Septegram
* Date: 2017-06-11 17:58:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|785106722|RELI 785106722}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|785371435|RELI 785371435}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I have been engaged in a discussion with [[user:Music314812813478|Music314812813478]] regarding whether the term "deity" should be applied neutrally to all beings discussed on this page, or whether monotheistic ones should be called by some other name (specifically, "God"). Please see the foregoing discussion "[[Talk:Deity#Nomenclature|Nomenclature]]."

It is my assertion that whether deities are monotheistic or otherwise does not matter, and that a [[WP:NPOV|neutral point of view]] requires that they all be given the same appellation on this page. [[user:Music314812813478|Music314812813478]] disagrees, arguing that the term "deity" is not "appropriate." We have not been able to reach a conclusion despite much spillage of virtual ink. I have refrained from re-editing to avoid [[WP:WAR|edit warring]], which I think would probably happen if I did, but have also been unable to persuade [[user:Music314812813478|Music314812813478]].

I am therefore requesting assistance from other parties to review this situation, engage in the discussion, and perhaps raise points that we have not discussed.

Respectfully,

<font face="strong" color="green">*[[user:Septegram|Septegram]]*[[user_talk:Septegram|Talk]]*[[Special:Contributions/Septegram|Contributions]]*</font> 17:58, 11 June 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:First Cameron ministry#rfc_FCD7E02|Talk:First Cameron ministry]] expired 2017-06-13 16:01 ===
* Id: FCD7E02
* User: Neve-selbert
* Date: 2017-05-22 07:35:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|781620599|HIST 781620599}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|781620601|POL 781620601}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|781620603|SOC 781620603}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|785448628|HIST 785448628}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|785448632|POL 785448632}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|785448635|SOC 785448635}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Debate has been raging over whether or not the title of this article is adequate for several years now. Most discussants have opposed the status quo in the past, mostly due to a lack of reliable sources supporting it and the fact that it's not the common name for the subject. The trouble is that editors have found it difficult to agree on a better name for this article. I proposed ''Cameron&ndash;Clegg coalition'' above, yet support for it failed to gain much traction. Indeed, the RM itself was mostly ignored until a couple of days ago. Nevertheless, I do believe there is consensus to rename this article, but rename it to what remains an open question. Here are a few alternatives that have been put forth, which all abide by the guidelines set out at [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Politics of the United Kingdom/Ministries]]:
{{colbegin}}
* ''Cameron coalition ministry''
** [https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&q=%22Cameron+coalition+ministry%22 Practically 0 results]
* ''Cameron&ndash;Clegg coalition''
** [https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&q=%22Cameron+Clegg+coalition%22 About 472 results]
* ''Cameron&ndash;Clegg coalition ministry''
** [https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&q=%22Cameron+Clegg+coalition+ministry%22 No results found]
* ''Cameron&ndash;Clegg ministry''
** [https://www.google.com/search?tbm=bks&q=%22Cameron+Clegg+ministry%22 Practically 0 results]
{{colend}}
I have stated the case as to why I believe ''Cameron&ndash;Clegg coalition'', given its popularity among reliable sources. {{relisted}} --[[User:Neve-selbert|Nev&eacute;]][[Special:Contributions/Neve-selbert|&ndash;]][[User talk:Neve-selbert|selbert]] 07:35, 22 May 2017 (UTC)}}
