=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Capital letters#rfc_48985AA|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Capital letters]] expired 2017-10-10 09:01 ===
* Id: 48985AA
* User: SMcCandlish
* Date: 2017-09-21 17:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|801770618|STYLE 801770618}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|801770619|POLICY 801770619}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|806386143|STYLE 806386143}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|806386146|POLICY 806386146}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Given all that's been said in the general-discussion RfC above, it is proposed here to change the third bullet of [[MOS:JOBTITLES]], on when to capitalize titles, to the following, including some additional examples (to make it clearer there isn't a different rule for civic and noble titles on Wikipedia):
* When a formal title (or conventional translation thereof) is addressed as a title or position in and of itself, is not plural, is not preceded by a modifier (including a definite or indefinite article), and is not a reworded description:
** {{xt|Richard Nixon was re-elected President of the United States on November 7, 1972.}} But: {{xt|Nixon was the 37th president of the United States.}} {{xt|Nixon was one of the more controversial American presidents.}} {{xt|Controversial US president Richard Nixon resigned.}}
** {{xt|Louis XVI became King of France and Navarre in 1774, later styled King of the French (1791–1792).}} But: {{xt|Louis XVI was a king of France.}}  {{xt|Louis XVI was the king of France when the French Revolution began.}} {{xt|French king Louis XVI was beheaded.}}

The present wording of this line item is:
* {{tq|When the correct formal title is treated as a [[Proper name (linguistics)|proper name]] (e.g., {{xt|King of France}}; it is correct to write {{xt|Louis XVI was King of France}} but {{xt|Louis XVI was the French king}})}}
It has been termed confusing and disputed, in multiple ways, including: perceptions of self-contradiction; conflicts between [[Proper name (linguistics)|linguistics]] and [[Proper name (philosophy)|philosophy]] conceptions of the meaning of "proper name"; complaints that "correct formal title" is PoV or simply meaningless; lack of guidance about cases of the form "<var>Name</var> was a/the <var>title</var>"; and implication that every occurrence of something like "King of France" should be capitalized regardless of context (e.g. use as a common-noun phrase or plural). <small>[This is not my personal opinion, but a summary of debate above and of previous discussions.]</small>

{{collapse top|left=y|title=The current wording of the entire section}}
{{fake heading|Titles of people}}
Offices, titles, and positions such as ''president'', ''king'', ''emperor'', ''pope'', ''bishop'', ''abbot'', and ''executive director'' are common nouns and therefore should be in lower case when used generically: {{xt|Mitterrand was the French president}} or {{xt|There were many presidents at the meeting.}} They are capitalized only in the following cases:
* When followed by a person's name to form a title, i.e., when they can be considered to have become part of the name: {{xt|President Nixon}}, not {{!xt|president Nixon}}
* When a title is used to refer to a specific and obvious person as a substitute for their name, e.g., {{xt|the Queen}}, not {{!xt|the queen}}, referring to [[Elizabeth&nbsp;II]]
* When the correct formal title is treated as a [[Proper name (linguistics)|proper name]] (e.g., {{xt|King of France}}; it is correct to write {{xt|Louis XVI was King of France}} but {{xt|Louis XVI was the French king}})

When an unhyphenated compound title such as ''vice president'' or ''chief executive officer'' is capitalized (unless this is simply because it begins a sentence),<ref>This includes headings, entries in tables and the like, where sentence case is used rather than title case.</ref> each word begins with a capital letter: {{xt|On October 10, 1973, Vice President Agnew resigned and Gerald Ford was appointed to replace him.}} This does not apply to unimportant words such as the "of" in {{xt|White House Chief of Staff John Doe}}. When hyphenated, as ''Vice-president'' is in some contexts other than U.S.&nbsp;politics, the second (and any subsequent) elements are not capitalized. 

Honorifics and [[Royal and noble styles|styles of nobility]] should normally be capitalized, e.g., {{xt|Her Majesty}}, {{xt|His Holiness}}, but see also {{section link|WP:Manual of Style/Biographies|Honorifics}}.
{{talkref}}
{{collapse bottom}}

I believe this proposal will be about the best compromise we can achieve any time soon, while the current wording is definitely confusing to a lot of editors and leading to recurrent dispute, while off-Wikipedia style guides do not give consistent advice on the matter, though they mostly lean in this direction, and the proposed solution should be stable for a long time.<br /><span style="white-space:nowrap;font-family:'Trebuchet MS'"> — [[User:SMcCandlish|'''SMcCandlish''' ☺]] [[User talk:SMcCandlish|☏]] [[Special:Contributions/SMcCandlish|¢]] ≽<sup>ʌ</sup>ⱷ҅<sub>ᴥ</sub>ⱷ<sup>ʌ</sup>≼ </span> 17:16, 21 September 2017 (UTC)}}


=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Capital letters#rfc_05A4BE1|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Capital letters]] expired 2017-10-10 09:01 ===
* Id: 05A4BE1
* User: Great scott
* Date: 2017-09-10 08:46:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|799869333|STYLE 799869333}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|804648668|STYLE 804648668}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
<s>'''[[WP:JOBTITLES]] currently offers us conflicting advice with regard to capitalization.''' A general rule is stated that titles are “common nouns and therefore should be in lower case when used generically.” This includes “king” and “French king,” but not “King of France,” at least according to this puzzling example: “{{xt|Louis XVI was King of France}} but {{xt|Louis XVI was the French king}}." This example goes against the advice of ''The Chicago Manual of Style'', which gives "King Abdullah; the king of Jordan" (8.21) and “Charles I (king of England)” (16.98). This mistake has been in the Manual of Style for a long time. It at one point, it was [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Capital_letters&oldid=212130034 supported by bogus CMOS and ''Guardian'' references]. In the archive, I found a history of editors puzzling over this passage, but no one who could explain what it means or where it came from. Various editors have, in good faith, interpreted the “King of France” example to mean that Wikipedia style is to upper case titles. This interpretation is in opposition to the rule the example is supposed to be illustrating. '''I propose that we resolve the conflict by removing the bulleted section with the “King of France” example.''' [[User:Great scott|Great scott]] ([[User talk:Great scott|talk]]) 08:46, 10 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Turkey#rfc_692DDFD|Talk:Turkey]] expired 2017-10-10 09:01 ===

* Date: 2017-10-08 08:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|804648675|UNSORTED 804648675}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
, despite your excellent contributions and somewhat personal-involvement with certain aspects of the topic, you are strongly cautioned to maintain [[WP:CIVILITY|civility]].</small>
*'''Way forward''':--An RFC should be re-launched by the discussant(s), each side necessarily mentioning the sources ''for'' and ''against'' mentioning each particular word and asking the editorial community to instate their opinion on the topic w.r.t to a proper evaluation of the sources on both side of the table.The close  of that RFC will supercede this closure and the closer of the subsequent RFC may wish to resume the ''status-quo'' <u>before</u> ''this'' RFC i.e. let the statement be included per his/her discretion.This non-typical scope is devised to address the many shortcomings of this disc. where ''sources'' played a minimal part.Unless such an RFC is closed,  re-addition of any info pertaining to the particular words in the lead, that were removed as a result of ''this'' RFC, shall be rejected lest they regain a local consensus at this talk-page.(irrespective of the grammatical formatting of the sentence and whether that is uni-sourced/multi-sourced/un-sourced.) <small>Slightly edited the prev. close and added this sub-part. [[User:Godric on Leave|<span style= "color:green">''Winged Blades of Godric''</span>]]<sup>[[User  talk:Godric on Leave|On leave]]</sup> at 08:15, 8 October 2017 (UTC)}}

I refer to the following edits: [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Historicity_of_Jesus&diff=prev&oldid=799942409] [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Historicity_of_Jesus&diff=next&oldid=799942409] [[User:Dlabtot|Dlabtot]] ([[User talk:Dlabtot|talk]]) 19:23, 10 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:The Great British Bake Off#rfc_961B21D|Talk:The Great British Bake Off]] expired 2017-10-11 14:01 ===

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should details of personnel changes of a TV show be moved from the lead to the main body of the article with only a summary in the lead?

I moved the details of personnel changes of a TV show to the main body of text in the article - [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=The_Great_British_Bake_Off&type=revision&diff=799990038&oldid=799639979], so that it only gives a concise summary of personnel changes in the lead as summary is the recommendation per [[WP:LEAD]]. However another editor objected and wanted a consensus, hence the request for comment. [[User:Hzh|Hzh]] ([[User talk:Hzh|talk]]) 13:45, 11 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:University of Notre Dame#rfc_CD167FD|Talk:University of Notre Dame]] expired 2017-10-12 00:01 ===
* Id: CD167FD
* User: Corkythehornetfan
* Date: 2017-09-11 23:12:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|799991666|MEDIA 799991666}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|804928082|MEDIA 804928082}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
{{Gallery
|title=Seals used around the University of Notre Dame
|width=160 | height=160
|align=center
|File:University of Notre Dame seal (2).svg
 |'''{{center|Seal 1}}'''
|File:University of Notre Dame seal.svg
 |'''{{center|Seal 2}}'''
}}
The University of Notre Dame apparently uses two different seals (as shown above). Current university publications linked here use Seal 2 as far back as [http://www.csm.ornl.gov/SC2007/pres/White_Collaborators_Judy/Collaborators%20logos/RAMS%20Univ%20Partners/Univ%20of%20Notre%20Dame/orig%20from%20web/NotreDameLogoSports.pdf August 2003], and the website as far back as [https://web.archive.org/web/20111009070543/http://onmessage.nd.edu:80/notre-dame-brand-standards/logos/ October 2011].

# [https://medicine.iu.edu/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/SouthBend_015-min-1900x950.jpg IU Medicine plaque]
# [https://news.nd.edu/stylesheets/images/news-og-image.jpg Bronze plaque]
{{Col-end}}

'''Differences''' between the two seals include:
# Seal 2 has horizontal lines in the field of the shield (possibly [[hatching (heraldry)|hatching]] for the color blue) that are absent in Seal 1
# Seal 1 is full color while Seal 2 is black and white
# Seal 1 has a blue border around the shield while the shield in Seal 2 has no border
# The star in the top left corner of the shield is larger on Seal 2 than on Seal 1
'''Question:''' Which seal should be used: '''Seal 1''' or '''Seal 2''' based off of the above? <span style="background:black; color:#FFFFFF; border:1px solid black">Corkythe</span><span style="background:#BB8D0A; color:#FFFFFF; border:1px solid black">[[User talk:Corkythehornetfan|<span style="color:white">hornetfan</span>]]</span> (ping me) 23:12, 11 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Days of the year#rfc_DBD1E0A|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Days of the year]] expired 2017-10-12 17:01 ===
* Id: DBD1E0A
* User:  Toddst1
* Date: 2017-09-12 16:23:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|800296012|POLICY 800296012}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|805033964|POLICY 805033964}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The guidelines at [[WP:DAYS#Style]] state:
{{quotation|"References are not needed in Wikicalendar articles. However, references to support listed entries must be found in linked Wikipedia articles and not external links."}}
This seems to have been added years ago and is now taken as an obvious tenet.  However it seems to fly in the face of [[WP:V]] and specifically [[WP:BURDEN]].  I propose that this be changed to the wording from [[WP:BURDEN]]:
{{quotation|"Any material lacking a reliable source '''directly supporting it''' may be removed and should not be restored without an inline citation to a reliable source."}}
I think the exemption from references should be struck from this guideline.
:<small>Rfc initiated by [[User:Toddst1|Toddst1]] <small>([[User talk: Toddst1|talk]])</small> at 16:23, 12 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of monuments and memorials of the Confederate States of America#rfc_9F0A7B3|Talk:List of monuments and memorials of the Confederate States of America]] expired 2017-10-12 19:01 ===
* Id: 9F0A7B3

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|800319931|HIST 800319931}}

* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the article include the following graph of monument construction based on SPLC data? [[File:Chart concerning Confederate monuments.png|thumb|right|300px|Number of Confederate monuments, schools and other iconography established by year. Most of these were put up either during the [[Jim Crow]] era or during the [[Civil Rights movement]], times of increased racial tension.<ref>[https://www.splcenter.org/sites/default/files/whoseheritage_splc.pdf]</ref>  The year 1911 saw the largest number constructed, which was the 50th anniversary of the Civil War.]] [[User:D.Creish|D.Creish]] ([[User talk:D.Creish|talk]]) 18:37, 12 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:2017 Berkeley protests#rfc_1B47C57|Talk:2017 Berkeley protests]] expired 2017-10-13 17:01 ===
* Id: 1B47C57
* User: BoogaLouie
* Date: 2017-09-13 16:57:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|800453731|POL 800453731}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|805185941|POL 805185941}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the fourth paragraph of the [[2017 Berkeley protests#April 15|April 15 section]] mention... 
:1. that the woman who was punched in the face by Nathan Damigo was 
::a) [[Doxing|doxxed]] by right-wing groups (the doxing parties revealed or claimed to have revealed very personal information about the woman along with assorted insults. No mention of this will be included in the proposed edit) and 
::b) accused by those groups of putting one or more M80 explosives inside glass bottles and throwing them at the pro-Trump marchers before being punched? 
::c) but that the fact-checking site [[Snopes]] found no reports of explosions in bottle during the rally, that photographic evidence (a close-up of the bottle) appears to show that it’s empty and that there is no record of Damigo claiming the woman did such a thing?  
:2. ... and also mention one or more of the name(s) of the woman punched (who uses a number of pseudonyms) which have appeared in [[Snopes]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Was a Protester Throwing Explosives Into a Berkeley Crowd Before She Was Punched? |url=http://www.snopes.com/antifa-protestor-punch-m80/ |website=Snopes |accessdate=19 August 2017}}</ref> [[Mother Jones]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=BAUER|first1=SHANE|title=A Punch in the Face Was Just the Start of the Alt-Right’s Attack on a Berkeley Protester|journal=Mother Jones|date=27 April 2017|url=http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2017/04/berkeley-rally-alt-right-antifa-punch/|accessdate=19 August 2017}}</ref>  [[CBS News]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Woman seen getting punched in viral video speaks out|url=https://www.cbsnews.com/news/berkeley-protest-louise-rosealma-describes-melee-after-being-punched/|accessdate=19 August 2017|agency=CBS News|date=18 April 2017}}</ref> and recently the  [[New York Times]], which called her “a symbol of the antifa movement”.<ref>{{cite news|title=‘Antifa’ Grows as Left-Wing Faction Set to, Literally, Fight the Far Right |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/17/us/antifa-left-wing-faction-far-right.html?mcubz=1&_r=0 |agency=''New York Times'' |date=17 August 2017 | accessdate=24 August 2017}}</ref> --[[User:BoogaLouie|BoogaLouie]] ([[User talk:BoogaLouie|talk]]) 16:57, 13 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not#rfc_9C07B48|Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not]] expired 2017-10-13 20:01 ===
* Id: 9C07B48
* User: Jd22292
* Date: 2017-10-13 18:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|805200338|UNSORTED 805200338}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|805207602|UNSORTED 805207602}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is currently an active consensus at [[WP:FOOTY]], and I notice several of its members reverting edits on this consensus, that no match result should be updated live, but rather when the match is over. I've had a discussion similar to this over at [[WP:DISCORD]] and had some users say this could be expanded to other sports and topics like award shows or live competition, i.e. [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. My proposal is to expand on this consensus so that it covers all forms of live coverage, not just football matches, award ceremonies, or live shows with voting. The proposed shortcut would be something along the lines of [[WP:NOTBROADCAST]] and/or [[WP:NOTLIVEFEED]]. Please feel free to share your thoughts below. [[User:Jd22292|jd22292]] <span style="background-color:#368ec9; color:black; font-family:Papyrus">([[Special:Contributions/Jd22292|Jalen D. Folf]])</span> ([[User talk:Jd22292|talk]]) 18:44, 13 October 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Requests for adminship#rfc_F3DB210|Wikipedia talk:Requests for adminship]] expired 2017-10-14 09:01 ===

* Date: 2017-10-14 07:58:00

** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|805275952|POLICY 805275952}}
* RFC Text:

I do not want to set the agenda -- that, friends, is up to you -- but the vote in question was not vandalism, and was not ''directly'' insulting {{u|Megalibrarygirl}}. Therefore, '''is it acceptable for !votes which are not blatant vandalism or personal attacks to be removed?''' [[User:My name continues to not be dave|My name continues to not be dave]] ([[User talk:My name continues to not be dave|talk]]) 07:58, 14 October 2017 (UTC)}}

[[User:JSH-alive|JSH-alive]]/<sup>[[User talk:JSH-alive|talk]]/[[Special:Contributions/JSH-alive|cont]]/[[Special:Emailuser/JSH-alive|mail]]</sup> 16:00, 15 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Recent years#rfc_FAC330B|Wikipedia talk:Recent years]] expired 2017-10-15 20:01 ===
* Id: FAC330B
* User: AlasdairEdits
* Date: 2017-09-15 19:09:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|800814736|POLICY 800814736}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|805497123|POLICY 805497123}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I know there is another RFC still open but it does not seem to be going anywhere meaningful. I propose to replace the section "Inclusion and exclusion criteria" with the following: 

*"Recent years pages are intended to provide an overview of events of ''international'' and ''lasting'' notability that occur during that year:
*In general, events meeting this criterion should recieve significant independent news reporting from at least three continents or should recieve coverage by multiple reliable sources as one of the most significant global events to have occured during that year. (For example in a year in review article in a major newspaper).
*Births or Deaths which recieve significant independent news reporting from three continents or recieve coverage by multiple reliable sources as one of the most important global events to have occured during that year are included in this criterion. 
*Some categories of  reccuring events often recieve significant international coverage but are still not usually of ''lasting'' notability. We have special additional rules to deal with these categories. If such events recieve coverage by multiple reliable sources as one of the most significant global events to have occured during that year this may be evidence that they are of unusual importance and should be included.

Then, we would retain the other sub-sections - with the exception of  the three continent rule, births and deaths which would be subsumed above. 

I think that this change would improve the balance of recent years articles. Dramatically reduce squabbling over dumb things and give a more balanced overall picture. There might be a lag with a few things until reliable sources start to round up a year but I think that is emmiently preferable to the current arbitrary standards which manage to be both too flexible (to allow random dead musicians and athletes who happen to be [[WP:BIAS]] beneficiaries) and too inflexible (not allowing election of Donald Trump on [[2016]] even though we can now clearly see it was one of the most significant events of the year.)

I am not a wiki policy wonk and I am sure there are some flaws in what i have put above, but we can correct small things later. I hope this would be a positive change that would fix a lot of the big issues we nearly all seem to acknowledge. [[User:AlasdairEdits|AlasdairEdits]] ([[User talk:AlasdairEdits|talk]]) 19:09, 15 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)#rfc_4A017D4|Wikipedia:Village pump (policy)]] expired 2017-10-15 22:01 ===
* Id: 4A017D4
* User: Mjroots
* Date: 2017-10-13 13:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|805163652|TECH 805163652}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|805514067|TECH 805514067}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Following discussion at [[WP:AN#The Rambling Man]] and [[WP:VPP#Editing through protection]], I'd like to propose a system which will give editors with the Template Editor privilege (TEs) the ability to indirectly edit the Main Page (MP). 

There are five main templates that make up the MP. All of them are protected at admin level, and cascade protected. AFAIUI, it means that it is impossible to grant TEs the ability to directly edit the templates. However, it would appear that the is a way around this. If there were subpages of these templates, protected at TE level but outside cascade protection, TEs could edit them. Each template could take the name of the main template with /TE as its subtemplate name. An admin-level bot could then copy across any changes to the relevant template (it would also need to copy over any changes made to the main templates to the subtemplate). Thus allowing TEs to indirectly edit the MP without impinging on the cascade protection. This would increase the number of editors who are able to respond to issues raised at [[WP:ERRORS]].
TEs are obviously a trusted bunch of editors. The risk of vandalism to the main page would be very low, and any such instances could be swiftly dealt with by immediate removal of the privilege and other administrative action. Please indicate your support/objection below. [[User:Mjroots|Mjroots]] ([[User talk:Mjroots|talk]]) 13:02, 13 October 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:List of 2010s one-hit wonders in the United States#rfc_49E99EC|Talk:List of 2010s one-hit wonders in the United States]] expired 2017-10-18 18:01 ===
* Id: 49E99EC
* User: Binksternet
* Date: 2017-10-18 15:16:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|805943830|UNSORTED 805943830}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Unsorted|prev|805952598|UNSORTED 805952598}}
* RFC Text:

Condensing the choices from the above discussion, should we:
*'''1''' – Do nothing, the group of articles remains a statistically derived list in seven parts for seven decades, from the 1950s to the 2010s, or
*'''2''' – Keep the statistics-based inclusion criteria but move all seven articles so that they do not have the culturally distinct term "one-hit wonder" in the article name, or
*'''3''' – Redirect all seven decade articles back to [[List of one-hit wonders in the United States]] while changing the inclusion criteria of the main article from any maths or statistics derivation to instead be a list of artists that have been called one-hit wonders in multiple reliable sources, with two sources cited for each entry. 

'''Survey'''

*'''3'''. I would like to retain the culturally loaded term "one-hit wonder" but I don't think the statistically derived approach fits very well. [[User:Binksternet|Binksternet]] ([[User talk:Binksternet|talk]]) 15:16, 18 October 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Talk page guidelines#rfc_6D355EA|Wikipedia talk:Talk page guidelines]] expired 2017-10-19 04:01 ===
* Id: 6D355EA
* User: Flyer22 Reborn
* Date: 2017-09-19 03:18:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|801353549|POLICY 801353549}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|806021104|POLICY 806021104}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There has been substantial discussion at [[Wikipedia talk:Talk page guidelines#Guidance against interleaving replies]] about whether or not interleaving should be discouraged. Please refer to that discussion and its subsections for in-depth details. Editors have defined interleaving as breaking up another editor's text to reply to individual points. One argument is that this is problematic because it confuses who said what and obscures the original editor's intent. The other argument is that interleaving can be beneficial and that there [[Wikipedia talk:Talk page guidelines#Visually illustrating the difference between useful and disruptive interleaving|is a difference between useful and disruptive interleaving]]. 

Thoughts? [[User:Flyer22 Reborn|Flyer22 Reborn]] ([[User talk:Flyer22 Reborn|talk]]) 03:18, 19 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Algerian War#rfc_642CBED|Talk:Algerian War]] expired 2017-10-19 17:01 ===
* Id: 642CBED
* Date: 2017-09-19 16:03:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|796452009|HIST 796452009}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|806092235|HIST 806092235}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I am seeking comments on a proposal to make the result parameter in the Infobox comply with Wikipedia's guidelines and policies.

*Per [[Template:Infobox_military_conflict]]: The result parameter may use one of several standard terms: "X victory", "Decisive X victory" or "Inconclusive". The choice of term should reflect what the sources say.

*'''The proposal''': change the result parameter to "FLN victory". Optionally, add the consequences of the victory (independence, etc.).

*Some of the reliable sources describing the final outcome of the war either as a "FLN victory" or a "French defeat":<ref name="Connelly2002">{{cite book|author=Matthew James Connelly|title=A Diplomatic Revolution: Algeria's Fight for Independence and the Origins of the Post-cold War Era|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I9ffptE_r4YC&pg=PA263|year=2002|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-514513-7|pages=263–277|quote=<u>The Algerians' victory</u> enabled the French to become free--free from their colonial charges, and free from the United States....... Although <u>France</u> was obviously eager to get out, it <u>had to accept the terms of its defeat</u>.}}</ref><ref name="Horne2012">{{cite book|author=Alistair Horne|title=A Savage War of Peace: Algeria 1954-1962|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f4-UHiZTlpMC&pg=PP11|date=9 August 2012|publisher=Pan Macmillan|isbn=978-1-4472-3343-5|page=11|quote=The war in Algeria (which lasted nearly eight years - almost twice as long as the "Great War" of 1914-18) toppled six French prime ministers and the Fourth Republic itself. It came close to bringing down General de Gaulle and his Fifth Republic and confronted metropolitan France with the threat of civil war. Yet, when <u>defeat</u> led to the cession of this cornerstone of her empire where she had been "chez elle" for 132 years, out of it arose an incomparably greater France than the world had seen for many a generation.}}</ref><ref name="Naylor2000">{{cite book|author=Phillip Chiviges Naylor|title=France and Algeria: A History of Decolonization and Transformation|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZMUb8R3Cs-MC&pg=PA263|date=December 2000|publisher=University Press of Florida|isbn=978-0-8130-3096-8|page=263|quote=De Gaulle managed with difficulty to persuade the French that decolonization did not equate with decadence. He prided himself on being wedded to the twentieth century and being able to replace colonialism with cooperation, satisfying essentialist imperatives. Still, this master mythmaker (witness in his manipulation of the image of France's Resistance during the Second World War) could not alter the reality or purge the memory of <u>France's defeat in Algeria</u>.}}</ref><ref name="McCormack2010">{{cite book|author=Jo McCormack|title=Collective Memory: France and the Algerian War (1954-1962)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DbnhuiJ8pEgC&pg=PA1|year=2010|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=978-0-7391-4562-3|pages=1–3|quote=<u>The French defeat in the war</u> effectively signaled the end of the French empire... The resentment and the bitterness of <u>defeat in the Algerian War</u> continue to feed into racism and to a general ignorance of this period of French history that is inhibiting Algerian French being able to find a home in France.}}</ref><ref name="Malley1996">{{cite book|author=Robert Malley|title=The Call From Algeria: Third Worldism, Revolution, and the Turn to Islam|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DYUD5v52CNUC&pg=PA81|date=20 November 1996|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-91702-6|page=81|quote=Then, in 1962, came the <u>FLN's victory in Algeria</u>, a defining moment in the history of the Third Worldism, for the battle had lasted so long, had been so violent, and had been won by a movement so acutely aware of its international dimension.}}</ref><ref name="DijkGray2013">{{cite book|author1=Ruud van Dijk|author2=William Glenn Gray|author3=Svetlana Savranskaya|title=Encyclopedia of the Cold War|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QgX0bQ3Enj4C&pg=PA16|date=13 May 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=1-135-92311-6|page=16|quote=During this war of independence, Algeria was at the center of world politics. <u>The FLN's victory</u> made the country one of the most prominent in the Third World during the 1960s and 1970s.}}</ref><ref name="Shrader1999">{{cite book|author=Charles R. Shrader|title=The First Helicopter War: Logistics and Mobility in Algeria, 1954-1962|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=be9xestT67sC&pg=PA231|date=1 January 1999|publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group|isbn=978-0-275-96388-0|page=231|quote=the path to independence was strewn with many obstacles, not all of which the leaders of the FLN were able to overcome. Nevertheless, they succeeded in creating ex nihilo an effective political structure able to suppress internal dissent and gain the support of outside forces. That same newly created political entity also proved itself able to raise, organize, equip, train, and direct military forces capable of posing a significant threat to French control inside Algeria. At the same time it could create a conventional army of imposing presence which, although retained in Tunisia and never fully committed in battle, played an important role in achieving <u>the overall victory</u>.}}</ref>

{{Reftalk}}
<small>Relisted by [[User:Godric on Leave|<span style= "color:green">''Winged Blades of Godric''</span>]]<sup>[[User  talk:Godric on Leave|On leave]]</sup> at 16:03, 19 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Countries#rfc_9C03061|Wikipedia talk:WikiProject Countries]] expired 2017-10-19 22:01 ===
* Id: 9C03061
* User: Brandmeister
* Date: 2017-09-20 20:42:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|801628428|HIST 801628428}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|806129230|HIST 806129230}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This stems from the [[Talk:Iran#Trimming_the_Intro_Section|current disagreement]] about the inclusion of the [[Republic of Artsakh]] (Nagorno-Karabakh Republic) among bordering countries in [[Iran]]'s lead. It raises the question of including also other [[List of states with limited recognition|self-proclaimed countries not recognized by any UN member]] (Pridnestrovian Moldavian Republic, Republic of Somaliland, Donetsk People's Republic, Luhansk People's Republic and, in future, potentially others) among bordering countries in other articles on countries (which AFAIK is not directly covered by any relevant policy or guideline, such as [[WP:LEAD]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject_Countries#Lead_section|WikiProject Countries#Lead section]]). 

Should the articles about countries mention self-proclaimed entities not recognized by any UN member among bordering countries? [[User:Brandmeister|Brandmeister]]<sup>[[User talk:Brandmeister|talk]]</sup>   20:42, 20 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not#rfc_A9668F7|Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not]] expired 2017-10-20 02:01 ===
* Id: A9668F7
* User: Jd22292
* Date: 2017-10-13 18:44:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|805207595|POLICY 805207595}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|806155364|POLICY 806155364}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
There is currently an active consensus at [[WP:FOOTY]], and I notice several of its members reverting edits on this consensus, that no match result should be updated live, but rather when the match is over. I've had a discussion similar to this over at [[WP:DISCORD]] and had some users say this could be expanded to other sports and topics like award shows or live competition, i.e. [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. My proposal is to expand on this consensus so that it covers all forms of live coverage, not just football matches, award ceremonies, or live shows with voting. The proposed shortcut would be something along the lines of [[WP:NOTBROADCAST]] and/or [[WP:NOTLIVEFEED]]. Please feel free to share your thoughts below. [[User:Jd22292|jd22292]] <span style="background-color:#368ec9; color:black; font-family:Papyrus">([[Special:Contributions/Jd22292|Jalen D. Folf]])</span> ([[User talk:Jd22292|talk]]) 18:44, 13 October 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Template talk:Unreferenced#rfc_9E0D96F|Template talk:Unreferenced]] expired 2017-10-20 14:01 ===
* Id: 9E0D96F
* User: SoWhy
* Date: 2017-09-20 13:05:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|801570363|TECH 801570363}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|806213984|TECH 806213984}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In 2010, an RFC at [[Template talk:Refimprove]] ([[Template talk:Refimprove/Archive_3#RFC:_Should_a_link_to_a_commercial_search_engine_be_included_in_the_template_Refimprove|archive link]]) was used as a reason to [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Unreferenced&diff=388782191&oldid=388050033 remove] the addition of a {{tl|find sources}} style text in this template. The question of this RFC is: '''Should ''this'' template include {{tl|find sources}} or a text similar to {{tl|find sources}}'''? (test example: [[Template:Unreferenced/sandbox]]) Regards '''[[User:SoWhy|<span style="color: #7A2F2F; font-variant:small-caps">So</span>]][[User talk:SoWhy|<span style="color: #474F84; font-variant:small-caps">Why</span>]]''' 13:05, 20 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Multiverse#rfc_2F374BC|Talk:Multiverse]] expired 2017-10-20 15:01 ===
* Id: 2F374BC
* User: Jytdog
* Date: 2017-10-06 01:19:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|804004440|SCI 804004440}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|806220836|SCI 806220836}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
In [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Multiverse&type=revision&diff=799749716&oldid=799689172 this diff], [[User:Jimjohnson222]] added a citation to a paper he wrote, (no change to content) so that the content looked like this: 

<blockquote>The structure of the multiverse, the nature of each universe within it, and the relationships among these universes differ from one multiverse hypothesis to another.<ref>{{cite journal |title = Creating a Universe, a Conceptual Model | journal = The Journal of Philosophy and Cosmology | url = http://ispcjournal.org/journals/2016-17/PC_vol_17-86-105.pdf | volume = 17 | pages = 86-105 | year = 2016 | last = Johnson | first = James }} </ref>  </blockquote>
{{reflist-talk}}

The edit note was {{tq|Add a specific reference that explains, from a philosphical perspective, multiverse possibilities}}.  I [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Multiverse&diff=next&oldid=799790482 reverted], with edit note {{tq|one example; we need a review. pretty clear refspam too}}

There was discussion above, and a DRN [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Dispute_resolution_noticeboard#multiverse here] that ended with a suggestion for an RfC. 

Should we use the reference, or not? [[User:Jytdog|Jytdog]] ([[User talk:Jytdog|talk]]) 01:19, 6 October 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Old Norse religion#rfc_5AAE7F0|Talk:Old Norse religion]] expired 2017-10-20 20:01 ===
* Id: 5AAE7F0
* User: Midnightblueowl
* Date: 2017-09-20 19:37:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|803667054|RELI 803667054}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|806129230|HIST 806129230}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|806258523|HIST 806258523}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Religion_and_philosophy|prev|806258590|RELI 806258590}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
'''Simple question:''' Which citation style should this article employ? 
*Option (1): <code><nowiki>{{sfn|Andren|2011|p=56}}</nowiki></code>
*Option (2): "Andren 2011: 56" (as plain text)
*Option (3): "Andren, p. 56." 
*Option (4): "Andren, "Old Norse and Germanic Religion", p. 56."
*Option (5): "Andren 2011, p. 56."
*Option (6): <code><nowiki>{{sfn|''Old Norse and Germanic Religion''|p=56}}</nowiki></code>

'''Further explanation:''' According to [[WP:CITEVAR]], "citations within any given article should follow a consistent style". As this article existed up till August 2017 ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Norse_religion&oldid=792420751]), that was not the case, with a wide variety of different citation styles being employed. As there was no community of editors active on the page, I was [[WP:BOLD]] and in my expansion of the article standardised the referencing using Option 1, the sfn/harv style ([https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Norse_religion&oldid=796906735]). I considered it particularly appropriate given that this is the citation system employed at thematically linked articles like [[Norse mythology]] and the FA-rated [[Heathenry (new religious movement)]]. [[User:Yngvadottir]] has since started rewriting the article's prose, replacing instances of option 1 with a mix of options 3 and 4, on the basis that these are easier to edit with. Concerns have been raised by [[User:PBS]] that option 3 generates confusion in the context of this article, because "Andren, p. 56" does not stipulate which of Andren's works (for instance) is being referred to (multiple works by the same author are cited in this article). As per Wikipedia policy, there needs to be a standardised system introduced and the decision which to adopt should be made via [[WP:Consensus]], after which all editors should abide by it in their edits. [[User:Midnightblueowl|Midnightblueowl]] ([[User talk:Midnightblueowl|talk]]) 19:37, 20 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:The Philosopher's Stone (album)#rfc_E675BE0|Talk:The Philosopher's Stone (album)]] expired 2017-10-21 10:01 ===
* Id: E675BE0
* User: SilkTork
* Date: 2017-09-21 09:53:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|801706894|MEDIA 801706894}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|806336955|MEDIA 806336955}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
The officially given recording dates on this album have been challenged by one of Morrison's biographers, [[Clinton Heylin]], in the 2003 book ''Can You Feel The Silence?''.[https://aux.avclub.com/clinton-heylin-van-morrison-can-you-feel-the-silence-1798198989]. Heylin's research is noted in the article (in the [[The_Philosopher%27s_Stone_(album)#Recording_dates|Recording dates]] section), and the alternative dates, with rationales, are given. However, Heylin's dates are also given in the [[The_Philosopher%27s_Stone_(album)#Track_listing|Track listing]] section as though authoritative. There has been some discussion on this matter  [[User_talk:Kitchen_roll#The_Philosopher.27s_Stone|here]]. 

The question for this RFC is: '''Is it appropriate for Wikipedia to place Heylin's dates on the track listing?''' '''[[User:SilkTork|<span style="color:purple; font-family: Segoe Script">SilkTork</span>]]''' '''[[User talk:SilkTork|<font color="#347C2C"><sup>✔Tea time</sup></font>]]''' 09:53, 21 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Ducati Monster#rfc_7728132|Talk:Ducati Monster]] expired 2017-10-22 21:01 ===
* Id: 7728132
* User: Dennis Bratland
* Date: 2017-09-22 20:56:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|801930270|ECON 801930270}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|801930271|SCI 801930271}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|801930277|SOC 801930277}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Economy,_trade,_and_companies|prev|806564162|ECON 806564162}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|806564166|SCI 806564166}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Society,_sports,_and_culture|prev|806564228|SOC 806564228}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the Ducati Monster be primarily described as a [[Types of motorcycles#Standard|standard motorcycle]], [[naked bike]] or [[muscle bike]]? Or none of the above? Example approximate phrasing options:
*  The '''Ducati Monster''' (called ''Il Mostro'' in Italian) is a [[Muscle bike (motorcycle)|muscle bike]] designed by [[Miguel Angel Galluzzi]] and produced by [[Ducati]] in [[Bologna]], Italy, since 1993. It is a [[naked bike]], characterized by an exposed engine and frame. 
*[...] is a [[naked bike|naked]] (or more generally, a standard or roadster) [[motorcycle]] characterized by an exposed engine and frame, originally designed by [[Miguel Angel Galluzzi]] and made by [[Ducati]] in [[Bologna]], Italy since 1993.
*[...] is a [[Types of motorcycles#Standard|standard]] [[motorcycle]], originally designed by [[Miguel Angel Galluzzi]] and made by [[Ducati]] in [[Bologna]], Italy since 1993. [...] The larger-displacement Monsters such as the M900 have been called [[muscle bike]]s, and it is frequently called a [[naked bike]].
*[...] is a [[motorcycle]], originally designed by [[Miguel Angel Galluzzi]] and made by [[Ducati]] in [[Bologna]], Italy since 1993. 

Actual wording and article layout and organization are left to later editorial discretion. The RfC question is only which term to emphasize. Please read the sources cited in the lead of the [https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ducati_Monster&oldid=801458688 current version], and the footnotes at [[Types of motorcycles#Standard|standard motorcycle]] ad [[Sport_bike#Variations]]. Copies of [[WP:offline|offline sources]] can be emailed upon request or via [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Resource Exchange/Resource Request]]. --[[User:Dennis Bratland|Dennis Bratland]] ([[User talk:Dennis Bratland|talk]]) 20:56, 22 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Film#rfc_66BD50A|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Film]] expired 2017-10-24 07:01 ===
* Id: 66BD50A
* User: Deathawk
* Date: 2017-10-23 05:15:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|806629848|MEDIA 806629848}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|806629867|POLICY 806629867}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|806801789|MEDIA 806801789}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|806801794|POLICY 806801794}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the production section writeup in the manual of style be changed to state the following:

''Production sections [[WP:INDISCRIMINATE|should not be a indiscriminate list of news and trivia associated with the making of the film]], but rather should instead be focused on how the film got from point A to the screen. As such the section should focus on events that impacted it as opposed to merely day to day business operation.

''Although announcements to the public can be notable, production sections should primary focus on how things unfolded from a production standpoint.  Similarly revaluations about when plot elements or settings were revealed should, most of the time, not be included, instead focus on how these elements came about.''

''Readability should be of a high importance. [[Wikipedia:Proseline|Sentences should avoid repetitive phrasing]] and information should be presented in a clear manner. Exact dates, are usually not needed unless there is a significance to it.

--[[User:Deathawk|Deathawk]] ([[User talk:Deathawk|talk]]) 05:15, 23 October 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)#rfc_54B1EA3|Wikipedia:Village pump (proposals)]] expired 2017-10-24 15:01 ===
* Id: 54B1EA3
* User: Doniago
* Date: 2017-10-13 19:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|805207597|TECH 805207597}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|805215312|PROP 805215312}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|806849553|TECH 806849553}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|806849554|PROP 806849554}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Pursuant to [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Bot_requests#Bot_for_automatically_dating_redlinks this discussion], I'm opening an RfC to hopefully gain consensus on the creation of a bot that will automatically date redlinks.

My idea is that, similar to how [[:Template:Citation needed]] without specifying additional params will lead a bot to automatically date the template, a similar template be created to mark redlinks, which a bot (perhaps even the same bot) could then tag with the current month and year (if there's a way to forego the template and just have a bot detect and tag redlinks, even better). I feel it would be useful to be able to see, when editing an article, whether a redlink has been relatively newly-created, or has existed for some time, so that editors can make more informed decisions as to whether a redlink is really merited. Even if this was only applied to redlinks going forward (i.e. no searching through existing ones) I feel it would be an improvement over the current approach, where it can be difficult if not impossible to determine when a redlink was created. 

The linked discussion includes some thoughts on indexing redlinks and more advanced functionality, but for the purposes of this RfC I would consider that out of scope. If others feel the advanced options should be pursued, I would encourage them to say so in any ensuing discussion, or initiate a subsequent RfC.

Please indicate your support or opposition for the creation of such a bot (and associated template if necessary), and feel free to bring up any questions or concerns in the discussion section. Thank you for your participation! [[User:Doniago|DonIago]] ([[User talk:Doniago|talk]]) 19:45, 13 October 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Film#rfc_87FB547|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style/Film]] expired 2017-10-24 22:01 ===
* Id: 87FB547
* User: Deathawk
* Date: 2017-10-24 07:27:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|806806722|MEDIA 806806722}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|806812183|POLICY 806812183}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Media,_the_arts,_and_architecture|prev|806849548|MEDIA 806849548}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|806849552|POLICY 806849552}}
* RFC Text:

Should the production section writeup in the manual of style be changed to state the following:
{{talk quote|1=A production section should not be an [[WP:INDISCRIMINATE|indiscriminate]] list of news and trivia associated with the making of a film, but should instead focus on how the film was developed. The section should be limited to events that impacted the production, not merely day-to-day business operations.

Although announcements to the public can be noteworthy, production sections should primarily cover events from a production standpoint.  For example, dates of when plot elements, settings, or casting choices were revealed should not be included; instead, include how the noteworthy elements of the production came about.

Readability should be given high priority. Avoid sentences with [[Wikipedia:Proseline|repetitive phrasing]]. Present information in a clear and logical manner. Exact dates are usually not needed, except for the most significant production milestones and any unusual events that attracted coverage in reliable sources.}}
--[[User:Deathawk|Deathawk]] ([[User talk:Deathawk|talk]]) 07:27, 24 October 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style#rfc_444ACBF|Wikipedia talk:Manual of Style]] expired 2017-10-25 01:01 ===
* Id: 444ACBF
* User: SMcCandlish
* Date: 2017-10-11 20:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|804906487|STYLE 804906487}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_style_and_naming|prev|806935467|STYLE 806935467}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
I propose to include the following footnote in MoS, which has various explanatory footnotes (keeps the main text more concise):

{{talk quote|1=A general term for the <code>.</code> character is ''full point'' or just ''point'', while the ''full stop'' is the role the character plays in terminating a sentence; not all style guides and dictionaries maintain it today {{crossref|(see {{section link|Full stop|History}} for more information)}}. In North American usage, it is usually referred to as a ''period'' regardless of role; in mathematics as a ''decimal point'' or ''point''; and in computer jargon often as a ''dot''. Use the same character for all of these roles. In particular, English Wikipedia does not use alternative [[decimal marks]].
}}

{{collapse top|left=y|bg=LightGrey|title=Ealier draft, revised above to account for some comments below:}}
{{talk quote|1=Technically, the term for the <code>.</code> character in general is ''full point'' or just ''point'', while the ''full stop'' is the role the character plays in terminating a sentence; while the distinction has been drawn since at least 1897, not all style guides and dictionaries maintain it today {{crossref|(see {{section link|Full stop|History}} for more information)}}. In North American usage it is usually referred to as a ''period'' regardless of role; in mathematics as a ''decimal point'' or ''point''; and in computer jargon often as a ''dot''.
}}
{{collapse bottom}}

The rationales for this are
*It's actually important that everyone be clear that ''full point'', ''full stop'', ''period'', ''decimal point'', and ''dot'' all refer to the same <code>.</code> glyph in different contexts. We take such care with various other punctuation matters, such as: quotation mark glyphs; the differences between different bracket types; distinctions between dashes of two kinds, the hyphen, and the minus; and so on.
*Two editors in two days have reverted previous attempts at clarification, with the counterfactual assertions that ''full point'' isn't correct or is somehow confusing, despite being what ''New Hart's Rules'' (the British counterpart to ''Chicago Manual of Style'') among other sources call the character in an overall sense.
My theory is it is better to have a clarifying footnote and precise terminology used contextually, than to have a slow editwar to force the same term (''full stop'') to be used in every context when this term is not universally used that way.

An editor has reverted the addition of this footnote, as well, so I'm opening this discussion about it.<br /><span style="white-space:nowrap;font-family:'Trebuchet MS'"> — [[User:SMcCandlish|'''SMcCandlish''']] [[User talk:SMcCandlish|☏]] [[Special:Contributions/SMcCandlish|¢]] &gt;<sup>ʌ</sup>ⱷ҅<sub>ᴥ</sub>ⱷ<sup>ʌ</sup>&lt; </span> 20:55, 11 October 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Help talk:IPA/English#rfc_63C44D8|Help talk:IPA/English]] expired 2017-10-26 02:01 ===
* Id: 63C44D8
* User: Mr KEBAB
* Date: 2017-09-26 01:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|802421077|LANG 802421077}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Language_and_linguistics|prev|807125643|LANG 807125643}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Currently [[Help:IPA for English|our IPA transcription system for English]] acknowledges the phoneme/[[diaphoneme]] {{IPA|/ɔər/}}, which is used only by a minority of General American speakers and no Received Pronunciation speakers (which are the only accents that are encoded by major dictionaries). Furthermore, it is transcribed in only some dictionaries and so transcribing it puts an unnecessary burden on editors who'd like to use e.g. ''Cambridge English Pronouncing Dictionary'' to source their IPA. For details, see [[Help_talk:IPA/English#Maybe_we_should_just_deprecate_.2F.C9.94.C9.99r.2F.3F|this discussion]]. [[User:Mr KEBAB|Mr KEBAB]] ([[User talk:Mr KEBAB|talk]]) 01:45, 26 September 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:IPhone 8#rfc_57835CE|Talk:IPhone 8]] expired 2017-10-26 05:01 ===
* Id: 57835CE
* User: EoRdE6
* Date: 2017-10-12 06:17:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|804970943|SCI 804970943}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Maths,_science,_and_technology|prev|807143558|SCI 807143558}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
 A very small number of iPhone 8 and iPhone 8 Plus buyers have suggested there could be an issue with the battery inside some of the devices swelling.<ref>{{cite web|title=Some iPhone 8 Plus owners report swelling battery problem|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2017/10/06/tiny-number-iphone-8-plus-owners-report-swelling-battery-problem/741750001/|website=USA TODAY|language=en}}</ref> Apple confirmed it is was looking into the issue, although a spokeswoman declined to comment further when asked how many devices are affected.<ref>{{cite web|title=Apple is ‘looking into’ why some iPhone 8 batteries are swelling|url=https://www.theverge.com/2017/10/6/16437790/iphone-8-swollen-battery-issue-apple-investigating|website=The Verge}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Apple checks iPhone 8 Plus battery issue|url=http://www.bbc.com/news/technology-41551596|website=BBC News|date=9 October 2017}}</ref> As of October 7th 2017 there were only 8 reports of this defect.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/10/06/apple-is-looking-into-reports-of-iphone-8-batteries-swelling/|title=Apple is looking into reports of iPhone 8 batteries swelling|last=Lomas|first=Natasha|work=TechCrunch|access-date=2017-10-07|language=en}}</ref>
{{Collapse|{{reflist}}|References}}

This is what I propose we add to the standard Reception section, not under any special heading that would lend undue weight. I am proposing this addition because this issue has been widely covered in the media including BBC, NBC and basically every single "tech" outlet, therefore warranting it at least a small mention in the article. '''[[User:EoRdE6|EoRdE6]]'''<sup><small>([[User talk:EoRdE6|Come Talk to Me!]])</small></sup> 06:17, 12 October 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Catalan supremacism#rfc_A333F77|Talk:Catalan supremacism]] expired 2017-10-26 15:01 ===
* Id: A333F77
* User: Sonrisas1
* Date: 2017-10-25 03:02:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|806963055|HIST 806963055}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|807199888|HIST 807199888}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
This is an extensive article about the history of the current of thought in Catalan nationalism in the late 19th and 20th century which held/developed the ideology that the Catalans were a superior, more racially pure and more European nationality than other ethnicities in Spain. The body of the article contains secondary academic sources and discussions and direct quotes from early and late Catalan intellectuals and Catalanist politicians expressing and developing such beliefs, such as [https://books.google.com.af/books?id=InmEAwAAQBAJ this one] in English (most other ones are in Spanish and Catalan). Certain editors claim the exact term "Catalan supremacism" is not being used in most of the sources (even though they all explain the ideology of catalan racial superiority with direct quotes), so having it in lead is POV and OR. The question is: Do sources which explain ideas of racial superiority and purity support the title (Catalan Supremacism) and the use of the term in the lead, or do we need the exact term "Catalan Supremacism" to be used in all of them? Reading the body of the article is suggested, since the technical issue to address is link between body and title/lead.[[User:Sonrisas1|Sonrisas1]] ([[User talk:Sonrisas1|talk]]) 03:02, 25 October 2017 (UTC)}}

For citations that emit [[Wikipedia:COinS|metadata]] for publication dates, is it necessary that the value of the date agree with the calendar that the metadata purports to use? For example, if a publication is 1 July 1750 Julian calendar, and the metadata emits it as 1 July 1750, Gregorian calendar, is this acceptable? While the notion of intelligent design has yet to be proven and is based primarily upon [[deductive reasoning]],<ref>Frank S. Ravitch, [https://books.google.co.il/books?id=NI7ywI7RkqIC&pg=PA148&lpg=PA148&dq=intelligent+design+based+on+deductive+reasoning&source=bl&ots=GE7TB-joSs&sig=xzslmaLZAgcDGCKMDN2QpJEOhPs&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwin7tvS5o7XAhWjDMAKHUYxCo4Q6AEISjAF#v=onepage&q=intelligent%20design%20based%20on%20deductive%20reasoning&f=false Marketing ''Intelligent Design: Law and the Creationist Agenda''], Cambridge University Press:New York 2011, p. 148 {{ISBN|978-0-521-19153-1}}</ref> it has neither been disproved. Moreover, science has yet to understand how the universe exists, noting how that, in the Standard Model of Physics, for the universe to exist after the alleged "Big Bang", "equal parts of matter and antimatter were produced and they cancel each other out" whenever these two parts naturally meet. <ref name="">{{cite news | last =Parnell | first =Brid-Aine | coauthors = | title = Science Still Doesn't Know How The Universe Exists | work = | pages = | language =English | publisher =Forbes | date =26 October 2017 | url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/bridaineparnell/2017/10/26/science-still-doesnt-know-how-the-universe-exists/#4fd4877337f8 | accessdate =26 October 2017}}</ref>}}

=== [[Talk:Catalan Republic (2017)#rfc_01CE236|Talk:Catalan Republic (2017)]] expired 2017-10-30 22:01 ===

* User: HapHaxion

The Democratic Party is one of the few remaining political parties to not list a position in the infobox, and each time someone tries to bring it up again to possibly change it, people come in from both sides and it ends in no new consensus. === [[Talk:Catalonia#rfc_4D4EF94|Talk:Catalonia]] expired 2017-11-01 01:01 ===
* Id: 4D4EF94
* User: Baidelan
* Date: 2017-10-29 15:45:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|807693342|POL 807693342}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Politics,_government,_and_law|prev|808124655|POL 808124655}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Based on the international opinion and that there is another page for the Catalan Republic, I suggest changing the first two introductory paragraph to: 

"Catalonia (Catalan: Catalunya, Occitan: Catalonha, Spanish: Cataluña) is a region of Spain in the northeast of the Iberian Peninsula between the Mediterranean coast and the Pyrenees. Politically, Catalonia is considered by the Kingdom of Spain and the international community as one of 17 autonomous communities of Spain and has the designation of a Historic Nationality (Spanish nacionalidad histórica) by its Statute of Autonomy. However, the regional Catalan parliament views it as an independent state following a unilateral declaration of independence on 27 October 2017.

Catalonia consists of four provinces: Barcelona, Girona, Lleida, and Tarragona. The capital and largest city is Barcelona, the second-most populated municipality in Spain and the core of the seventh most populous urban area in the European Union. Catalonia comprises most of the territory of the former Principality of Catalonia (with the remainder Roussillon now part of France's Pyrénées-Orientales). It is bordered by France and Andorra to the north, the Mediterranean Sea to the east, and the Spanish autonomous communities of Aragon to the west and Valencia to the south. The official languages are Catalan, Spanish, and the Aranese dialect of Occitan."

In the late 8th century..."

Let me know what you think.[[User:Baidelan|Baidelan]] ([[User talk:Baidelan|talk]]) 15:45, 29 October 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia:Village pump (technical)#rfc_6F7C914|Wikipedia:Village pump (technical)]] expired 2017-11-04 11:01 ===
* Id: 6F7C914
* User: A Den Jentyl Ettien Avel Dysklyver
* Date: 2017-10-18 15:55:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|805943828|TECH 805943828}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_technical_issues_and_templates|prev|808671024|TECH 808671024}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
It is proposed that the ''Timeless'' skin available at [[:mw:Skin:Timeless]] is added to the en-wikipedia configuration as a optional skin which could be enabled in user preferences. There are currently 5 skins available in preferences. This will be the sixth.

The current default skin that controls how most people see Wikipedia is ''Vector''; this '''will not change'''.

Unless an individual user wants to use the ''Timeless'' skin and enables it in their preferences, it will not be visible or change the user interface in any way. This skin has been tested and is currently enabled as a non-default preference on other Wikipedia including the French language Wikipedia, Wiktionary (fr), Wikinews (fr) and on the MediaWiki wiki.

Please don't oppose this just because you don't like it; you never have to know it is there, it will not affect any other skins or appearance settings. It is a completely optional choice, new users will still use Vector, and everyone who doesn't change their settings will still use Vector (or their other skin choice such as Monobook).
> [[User talk:A Den Jentyl Ettien Avel Dysklyver|<span style="color:blue;">''Dysklyver''</span>]] 15:55, 18 October 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not#rfc_78CA23C|Wikipedia talk:What Wikipedia is not]] expired 2017-11-04 18:01 ===
* Id: 78CA23C
* User: Robert McClenon
* Date: 2017-10-20 00:56:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|806148564|POLICY 806148564}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|806148565|PROP 806148565}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_policies_and_guidelines|prev|808716873|POLICY 808716873}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/Wikipedia_proposals|prev|808716875|PROP 808716875}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
Should the following paragraph be added to [[WP:NOT|What Wikipedia Is Not]]?  

'''Wikipedia is not a laboratory'''

{{policy shortcut|WP:NOTLAB}}
There has been much scholarship involving Wikipedia,<ref>See [[Meta:Research]], [[Wikipedia:Academic studies of Wikipedia]], [[Meta:Research:Newsletter]], and the [https://blog.wikimedia.org/c/foundation/research/wikimedia-research-newsletter/ Wikimedia Foundation research blog].</ref> but Wikipedia is not a public laboratory and editors are not lab rats.  Research that analyzes content or editor behavior needs no permission, because the ''content'' of Wikipedia is open to everyone. Research that is interventional—that involves surveying editors or making changes in content—should be conducted only with prior [[WP:CONSENSUS|consensus]] at <s>relevant [[WP:WikiProject|WikiProjects]],</s> the [[WP:VPR|Village Pump]], <s>or at [[WP:AN|the administrators' noticeboard]],</s> and should be disclosed clearly on the editor's [[WP:UP|user page]].<ref>See also [[Wikipedia:Researching Wikipedia]] and [[Wikipedia:Ethically researching Wikipedia]]</ref>  Researchers must disclose outside connections under the [[WP:COI|conflict of interest guideline]]. If their work on Wikipedia is conducted in the course of their employment, they '''must''' disclose this under the [[WP:PAID|paid editing policy]]. Editing directed at any goal other than [[WP:NOTHERE|building an encyclopedia]], or [[WP:PURPOSE| improving the experience of editors and readers]], is likely to be seen by the community as [[WP:DISRUPTIVE|disruptive]] and will likely entail time-wasting cleanup by our volunteers.  Editors who disregard community norms regarding design, transparency, or conduct may face sanctions, including [[WP:BLOCK|the loss of editing privileges]].

Please include your !votes in the Survey section.  Discussion may take place in the Threaded Discussion. [[User:Robert McClenon|Robert McClenon]] ([[User talk:Robert McClenon|talk]]) 00:56, 20 October 2017 (UTC)}}

I would like to request a formal RfC on the topic of whether [[OpenCritic]] is a '''reliable source'''. There is much vitriol on both sides. === [[Talk:Catalan Countries#rfc_A417B3E|Talk:Catalan Countries]] expired 2017-11-05 10:01 ===
* Id: A417B3E
* User: Sonrisas1
* Date: 2017-11-02 04:26:00
* Revisions affecting this RFC:
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|808333558|HIST 808333558}}
** {{Diff|Wikipedia:Requests_for_comment/History_and_geography|prev|808813713|HIST 808813713}}
* RFC Text:

{{rfcquote|text=
*Rename to Catalan-speaking territories as per [[WP:NPOV]], [[WP:RELIABLE]],[[WP:FRINGE]]

*'''Rename/Support''' "Catalan countries" is a highly politicized and controversial name which is used in most English and Spanish language sources as "so-called Catalan countries" - normally referring to Catalan political expansionism. It is highly controversial in most areas it purports to include and its use is avoided even by many Catalan nationalists to avoid alienating its neighbors. As such it is a POV term. I don't think the article should be deleted but title should at least be NPOV. There is no such thing as Catalan countries except as an irredentist political project which is extremely unpopular everywhere outside Catalonia. However, there are territories where Catalan is spoken - this is a reality. The only sources which use it without a qualifier (which implies it is controversial) are those under the orbit of the Catalan independence movement. So rename as per WP:NPOV.[[User:Sonrisas1|Sonrisas1]] ([[User talk:Sonrisas1|talk]]) 04:26, 2 November 2017 (UTC)}}

=== [[Talk:Antifa (United States)#rfc_38FC5C1|Talk:Antifa (United States)]] expired 2017-11-05 22:01 ===
* Id: 38FC5C1
* User: Darkness Shines

*The Antifa (English: /ænˈtiːfə/ or /ˈæntiˌfɑː/)[1] movement is a political movement of autonomous, self-styled anti-fascist groups in the United States.

To this

*Antifa (English: /ænˈtiːfə/ or /ˈæntiˌfɑː/)[1] is a far-left militant [2] political movement of autonomous, self-styled anti-fascist groups in the United States
